componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Barry Jeffery, Vice President.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Kelly Whitley, who has recently joined us as
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Kelly Whitley, who has recently joined us as Vice President of Investor Relations and Communications. 
Please refer to the informational slides we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with our webcast today. 
Today's call will follow our usual format. John will begin by providing a review of second quarter 2015 financial results. Roger will then follow with an operational update, after which, questions will be taken.
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussion of risk factors, see Murphy's 2014 annual report on Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy takes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
I'll now turn the call over to John.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Barry, and good afternoon, everyone. The consolidated results of Murphy Oil Corporation in the second quarter of 2015 were a loss of $73.8 million, which equates to $0.42 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $129.4 million or a p
componenttext:
Thank you, Barry, and good afternoon, everyone. The consolidated results of Murphy Oil Corporation in the second quarter of 2015 were a loss of $73.8 million, which equates to $0.42 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $129.4 million or a profit of $0.72 per diluted share a year ago. Excluding discontinued operations in the United Kingdom, continuing operations had a loss of $89 million or $0.51 per diluted share in the second quarter of '15, again, compared to the second quarter of 2014 of a profit of $142.7 million or $0.79 per diluted share. The second quarter current year results from continuing operations included a $23.8 million charge or at least a 2% tax rate increase in Alberta. This change will increase future tax rates for operations in the net Canadian province to a total of 12% tax beginning in 2016. Additionally, we had after-tax severance and other changes of $7.5 million in the quarter. 
Since the beginning of 2015, we have had overall staffing reductions of about 7% associated with the company reorganization plan. The savings from these staffing reductions will benefit us going forward. The quarter also included a benefit of $19.3 million from post-closing settlements associated with our earlier combined sale of 30% of our interest in Malaysia, and that sale occurred in late 2014 and early 2015. These and other items affecting comparability of earnings between periods are listed in our schedule of adjusted earnings, which is included as a part of our earnings release. Amounts and the schedule are reported on an after-tax basis. 
Earnings in the 2015 second quarter were negatively impacted by a significantly lower realized sales process per crude oil and natural gas liquids and natural gas compared to the same quarter in 2014. The company's average realized price for all of its crude oil production fell more than $37 per barrel, amounting to a 40% drop. Natural gas prices also were weaker in the second quarter of 2015 compared to the prior year's quarter with average North American gas price realizations dropping $1.61 per Mcf or a decline of 41%. Net natural gas profit offshore at Sarawak fell similarly. Our oil-weighted in the first portfolio of assets benefits our company as 52% of our second quarter production was sold off of Brent and LLS benchmarks which continued to bring stronger prices compared to the West Texas intermediate base volumes. Sales priced have further softened in July and, therefore, revenues continue to be under pressure as 2015 prices remain significantly below prices from a year ago. 
Crude oil and gas liquids production in the 2015 second quarter was lower than 2014 levels primarily due to the 30% sale of interest in Malaysia. Taking the Malaysia sale into account, our liquids production in the 2015 second quarter actually increased 6% compared to a pro forma total for the prior year.  Total oil and gas liquids production in the second quarter of 2015 was just over 131,000 barrels per day. Natural gas volumes were 425 million cubic feet per day in the 2015 quarter, flat to '14. However, again, factoring in the pro forma effects of the 30% sale in Malaysia, gas production actually increased 17% in the second quarter 2015, primarily due to higher production from the Montney area in Western Canada. 
Capital expenditures for continuing operations for the first 6 months of 2015 totaled $1.15 billion, which was a 34% decline from the comparable 2014 period. We continue to project our total 2015 capital expenditures at $2.3 billion [ph]. At June 30, 2015, into the second quarter, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to approximately $3.3 billion, 29% of total capital employed, while net debt amounted to just over 20% at the end of the second quarter. In July, we moved $150 million of funds from the U.K. following the sale of the U.K. downstream assets back to the United States. And these funds have been used to repay a portion of our outstanding debt early in the third quarter. 
That concludes my comments, and I'll turn it now over to Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Before we get started on our operational review today, I want to welcome Kelly to Murphy and her new role overseeing IR and Communications. Kelly brings many years of experience in this position. We look forward to working with her. Bar
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Before we get started on our operational review today, I want to welcome Kelly to Murphy and her new role overseeing IR and Communications. Kelly brings many years of experience in this position. We look forward to working with her. 
Barry has done a great job for us over the past 5 years in Investor Relations. He will move into a new role and lead 3 combined corporate functions as Vice President of Insurance, Security and Risk. The combination of these 3 corporate functions was word. Post the recent organizational study that John just mentioned. 
As far as reorganization, we split exploration to 2 regional groups, each reporting to Gene Coleman, the current EVP of Offshore Business. We restructured exploration to reduce focus areas, improve capital allocation and lower costs. 
Looking back at a pretty solid quarter for us, we have the following highlights. Our company remains in favor financial position with balance sheet flexibility, took advantage of opportunities and carryout capital and corporate programs. We initiated $250 million stock repurchase in May and completed it in July, this past quarter, with just under 6 million shares retired or 3% of the company. This represents buying our own proved reserves at near $12 per BOE in this tranche. 
Since 2012, we repurchased a total of $1.375 billion of company stock or 12.4%. We continue to make progress on the portfolio completing the sale of U.K. downstream business. The Malaysia sale down was timely hedged, the falling oil prices, and we still have many levers remaining to reposition the company going forward. We're currently reviewing the value of our midstream assets in Canada, Montney, Eagle Ford Shale and the Gulf of Mexico. 
Operationally, we made a nice gas discovery in Permai well and Block H Malaysia. This 200-plus Bcf resource will fit nicely with our Floating LNG development plans going forward. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, we achieved first production from the two-well Medusa subsea expansion ahead of schedule and on budget. And at Kodiak, we completed the first of 2 subsea wells ahead of schedule with drilling results to plan significantly in derisking the project returns. 
In shallow water Sarawak Malaysia, we continued a 5-well drilling campaign at the Belum gas field plant and are now drilling at the Permas oilfield. 
In our onshore business. Liquid shale continue to perform well, we have delivered 36 new wells online in the second quarter, and have recently completed wells in the Montney continue to deliver above planned results. 
As we look at our operating metrics, our global lease operating expense for Q2 2015, excluding Syncrude, is $10.90 per BOE, showing an improvement of 9% from quarter 2 '14 and 30% down from 2013. We are pleased with the overall effort and the company is making in cost reductions and this effort will continue throughout the year. 
The eagle Ford Shale had a second quarter operating expense near [ph] $10 per BOE and we expect to see further improvements in the second half of the year. 
We entered a price collapse last year and are currently in a good position relative to cash flow per barrel metrics. While the price drop this metric, we have not had any significant impairments which is impacting many of the peer group. 
We recently finished drilling our first well with the sixth generation rig Ocean Black Rhino in the Gulf of Mexico which strong operational execution of this well at 20% below budget. The punchline for me here is improved returns ahead in deepwater, especially in the drilling completion delineation wells, we have planned and a major deepwater developments in the future. 
In Eagle Ford Shale, we continue to lower cost and drop over efficiency gains. Our average well cost is now down by 21% from last year, and we're focused on getting that down to 25% overall by year end. 
Second quarter production averaged 201,952 barrel equivalents per day, exceeding our guidance of 197,000. The near 5,000 barrel equivalents per day variance was primarily attributed to new well performance in Eagle Ford Shale, rich start-up of the Medusa subsea expansion project and higher-than-forecasted heavy oil production from Seal. 
Looking ahead to the third quarter. Production guidance is estimated 200,000 barrel equivalents per day. The decrease from second quarter is primarily attributed to lower Malaysia production with the planned maintenance of the Kakap-Gumusut facility, risking of Sarawak and Kikeh gas volumes, and lower Canadian onshore production due to normal well decline, partially offset by higher Syncrude and Medusa subsea volumes for the quarter. 
We've increased our full year production guidance to a range of 200,000 to 208,000 barrel equivalents per day. 
As we reach the midpoint of the year, we remain on track with our capital spend budgets, some 34% below last year's level. That significant reduction capital we're targeting production growth this year of around 2%. The year-on-year growth is led by new well performance in Eagle Ford Shale and Montney. 
In Western Canada, our natural gas production from the Montney in the second quarter was 192 million cubic feet per day, our new completion is continue to deliver strong well performance with EURs now in the 8 to 10 Bcf range, well ahead of the regional Montney sanctions that call for 4 Bcf per well. We have a refracked pilot underway on some of the older wells at Tupper and have inventory of 9 previously drilled wells and currently completing 5 of them to maintain production rates and keep unit operating expenses low. 
At word, we continue to progress our long-term commercial steam project regulatory applications for essential thermo project were submitted in quarter 1 this year and we recently sanctioned feed work for the project. We're seeing some positive results from primary production from multilateral horizontal wells and have line in that area. 
In Eagle Ford Shale, second quarter 2015 production was comprised of 9% liquids averaging near 60,800 barrels equivalent per day. As planned, we continue to operate 4 rigs and 2 completion spreads and current plan is to stay at that level activity for the rest of the year. With about 36 wells, new wells online in the second quarter and we brought on near 60% of our total estimated wells for the year in the first half. We're planning on delivering 36 wells in quarter 3 and 25 wells in quarter 4 with the program being front-end loaded as per guidance and plans. 
Production in the third quarter of 2015 is estimated to be near 60,000 equivalents per day with the 2015 full year outlook not expected to exceed 59,000, some 2,000 barrel equivalents a day ahead of our annual production for 2014. 
We continue to optimize our frac designs and are seeing strong results from recent super slick completions and occurrence until areas. We have now begun a new trial of high intensity completions for volumes in spacing. Our major oil field were always searching for additional production zones. We're assessing the potential Shockley in our Eagle Ford Shale acreage. We have begun a three-well appraisal plan in the play with the first well coming online in October. 
Our current assessment shows a minimum of 70 Austin Chalk locations in the Carnes area with potential for additional locations of depending on the results of this appraisal. 
Murphy's well positioned in Eagle Ford Shale with their production mix compared to many peers, our limited exposure to lower NGL and natural gas prices gives us leverage in an oil price recovery. Murphy's well ramped up strategy focuses on maximizing value by balancing early production rates with ultimate recovery. The strategy has led Murphy to have one of the highest levels of 2-year recovery per well across the play. 
Eagle Ford Shale's a viable asset within our portfolio. The value of Eagle Ford Shale to Murphy is enhanced by early ground entry in the play of over 2,000 potential well locations remaining, now estimate the total resource at near 750 million barrels equivalent, which is very similar to the entire reserve base of Murphy today. We used to say that fields is going very, very well for us. 
The Malaysian second quarter, we completed a five-well drilling program for natrual gas at Belum field in shallow water offshore Sarawak. The Belum field has low nitrogen content that will blend into our current gas production, allow us to derisk our 250 million per day contractual volume on demand going forward. We're currently drilling oil wells in the Permas shallow water development, and this operation is going well with cost trending 20% under budget. 
Sarawak gas production for the second quarter was 111 [indiscernible] per day net, supported by strong guest nominations and liquid production at near 14,700 barrels of oil per day. 
We successfully completed the planned outage in early second quarter at our Sarawak facilities to complete required inspections in major maintenance. 
Production offshore Sabah, averaging a 30,900-barrel equivalent per day from second quarter with 85% liquids, planned maintenance activity of Kakap-Gumusut main facility to install gas handling and injection system commenced on June 9 and recently been completed. 
Earlier this month, we had a gas discovery of Permai exploration well in Block H, where we operate the well with 42% working metrics, our eighth consecutive success in area around that deal. 
This 200-plus Bcf discovery will allow optimization of Floating LNG project to lower our development cost. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, production for the quarter was over 22,900 barrel equivalents per day with 61% liquids. The Medusa 2-well expansion achieved first oil in the second quarter with the well starting up late April and mid-June, respectively.  We've exceeded our projected daily volumes and beat our scheduled targets. Word at the nonoperating Kodiak project continued to the first 2 wells have been drilled and completed plant and modification top subsea executions underway. 
The steel prospect of Mississippi Canyon Block 692 failed to encounter commercial quantities of hydrocarbon and will be word of dry hole. The well which we operate, it was a 35% working interest, was not included in our second quarter guidance. It was able to expected to reached total depth in the third quarter. Our drilling operations team completed the well 30 days ahead of schedule and $25 million gross under budget. 
We have expanded into a new area in the Gulf of Mexico where we're entering to the Wilcox play. There were 22% working interest ground foreman into the nonoperated Solomon prospect and word Ridge by 2 25. The well has a gross pre- estimate of over 300 million barrels. 
Looking at our drilling program for the rest of 2015 in the Gulf of Mexico, the Solomon well, which is currently projected to reach total depth sometime in near the end of third quarter, early fourth quarter, has been included in our dry hole exposure for the third quarter. 
[indiscernible] was moving to drilling low-risk prospect the Dalmatian South No. 2. The Transocean Discoverer Deep Seas expected to complete required inspection of the middle of August, and the word sidetrack the Thunderbird discovery, which shall be a subsea tieback to a nearby Thunder Hawk facility. 
Recognizing our lack of exploration success, we plan to focus recommitments on our lower risk appraisal wells and blocks where we have had prior exploration success. We'll allocate capital to higher return opportunities there existing infrastructure, not invest further in higher risk, high-cost wells at this time. 
In Malaysia, we will focus on our gas discovery at Permai and deepwater Block H with 2 shallow water oil prospects, Maracas 5 and Maracas and SK 314A, adjacent to our very successful Sarawak oil and gas developments. 
Late in the quarter, we'll drilled the word in Block SK 2C out of Sarawak. This well is near prior discovery on the block and is located in our new focus areas. We plan to finish off the year with a nonoperated appraisal of our gas discoveries in Brunei. Our form well commitments through 2016 are primarily in Malaysia, Brunei and Vietnam, which is one of our focus areas with lower-cost exploration. Post 2016, we have only one required well commitment in the entire company, and an estimated net cost of only $4 million. We'll have capital allocation options for exploration in 2016 and beyond as we have worked off commitments made in the prior years. We, like all deepwater operators, have deepwater rig commitments. The end of our rig commitments with the Black Rhino and Discoverer Deep Seas are expiring in February and November 2016, respectively. 
Production for the third quarter is estimated to be 200,000 equivalents per day. We have increased our full year production guidance with the range of 200,000 to 208,000 barrel equivalents per day. Capital expenditures remain unchanged from our previous guidance, and accounting for custody to be $2.3 billion in 2015. 
Murphy Oil has returned significant value to its shareholders over the last 6 years through regular dividends, a special dividend, a spin-off of Murphy U.S. and share repurchases. Our strong balance sheet supports the current regular dividend and allows the company to carry out its capital programs and review opportunities. 
At current prices, our dividend yield is near 4% above industry peer average. Share repurchases since 2012 have acquired our own proved reserves below our FND cost and competitive to other acquisitions. While many companies are issuing equity or taking major impairments from their assets, Murphy, through its conservative nature, has been able to avoid significant write-downs in the business. 
Let's take aways today. Our strong operational performance this year has allowed us to increase our production guidance for the year while staying within our capital spending budget. Our oil-weighted price advantage portfolio provides us with the cash flow per BOE benefit over many of our peers. We're driving cost lower in our business through cost reductions and efficiency improvements in both our offshore and onshore segments. Our conservative balance sheet is a positive for us, and the second price collapse in 9 months, it allows Murphy to maintain a continued focus on our shareholders' carryout capital programs and look for opportunities to improve our company going forward. 
We'll now take your questions. Thank you.

componenttext: Just longer-term question here on expansion. Obviously, you guys are sort of winding down some of the activities, it sounds like you'll have some activity next year as well and minimal commitments. Are you guys considering replacing that exploration component of the budget longer-term as we get out into 2017, '18 with acquisitions, your onshore leasing, or how should we think about strategy shift here?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think, the results, Leo, as you know should know, we're not where want to be, and we got back into the Gulf here and had 3 unsuccessful wells a row. Let's take a pause there, we're not stopping exploration around the world, we're taking a
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think, the results, Leo, as you know should know, we're not where want to be, and we got back into the Gulf here and had 3 unsuccessful wells a row. Let's take a pause there, we're not stopping exploration around the world, we're taking a pause on the drilling so that we can replenish our portfolio and make sure these investments make sure the partners we're in and what type of wells, where will cost go, I think drilling rig cost will come down and policy is warranted. It also go, as you brought up, this will allow us many capital allocation advantages whether we would consider M&A in lieu of exploration, where we consider a component of production and exploration from that company. And I like to think of it as another price collapse coming, another budget year coming, not the success I needed, less commitments, very significantly low commitment in '17, practically none. And I think that just it's an advantage to regroup and allows us our capital allocation across the spectrum.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's about 3 opportunities near Dalmatian that are like F&D around $15 and have $40 to $50 breakeven, full life cycle, 10% rate of return. So we consider those very good. It allows us to take a pause in the really expensive deep exploration wells for a
componenttext: There's about 3 opportunities near Dalmatian that are like F&D around $15 and have $40 to $50 breakeven, full life cycle, 10% rate of return. So we consider those very good. It allows us to take a pause in the really expensive deep exploration wells for a while until those costs come down further, it allows the regrouping of our partnering and our data and our total review of that business. I like this opportunity a lot. They're very accretive economically to us, but we've seen a lot of success here with Medusa subsea expansion. We're going to have a nice success at Kodiak from an entry be made into that project, and Dalmatian has been successful. So these have been around, and we have allocated capital to some exploration, and now we're reviewing that putting our capital into these projects that fit in well with low price environment in my view.

componenttext: It's on that slide, and our debt today, I think, it's a little over 100 today for the wells that we need to drill with international oil companies, some of these are very nice wells to drill in shallow water, Sarawak, Malaysia. So I don't consider it a very high risk program. At this time, it gives us a lot of flexibility in our CapEx for '16, an enormous flexibility in '17.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Roger, you made an interesting comment that you see improved returns ahead in the deepwater. I believe you've mentioned before that you had been seeing a lot of deflation offshore, so I was just hoping for an update on the deflation side, and then some mo
componenttext: Roger, you made an interesting comment that you see improved returns ahead in the deepwater. I believe you've mentioned before that you had been seeing a lot of deflation offshore, so I was just hoping for an update on the deflation side, and then some more detail behind your comments calling for better returns. How much of that is due to self-help and Murphy getting more efficient? How much is due what you're seeing on the macro side from a deflationary perspective? And then does that change the way you plan to allocate capital at all?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, like I said, from capital allocation exploration perspective, we have these wells that we just ask about Leo here about some lower breakeven price wells that we can take a pause in exploration, which I think is nice, especially if rig rates are high
componenttext: Well, like I said, from capital allocation exploration perspective, we have these wells that we just ask about Leo here about some lower breakeven price wells that we can take a pause in exploration, which I think is nice, especially if rig rates are high. I'm a deepwater present, I've been deepwater my whole career, I understand the business fairly well, it's really a days business, more than a vendor cost-reduction business with the onshore, it's a lot about vendor time and efficiency. But offshore is a day business. And I was a big believer in these big generation rigs, I thought they were too complex, too big, too much going on, wells I've ever seen in my career. And if we get that kind of performance to produce these days with all the subsea handling and the off-line work that these rigs can do, and you put that with lower day rates for these rigs, I'm absolutely certain that's going to lead to better returns, that's going to fit in better with our pause in exploration, the kind of wells we can get into out in out in the '17, '18 time frame after we have the appropriate recalibration of our work in that effort.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Very helpful. And then I have a couple of CapEx questions. What you've all done a great job in keeping the CapEx down obviously, and then with the lower pace of completions in Eagle Ford over the back half of the year, I'm just wanting to und
componenttext: Okay, great. Very helpful. And then I have a couple of CapEx questions. What you've all done a great job in keeping the CapEx down obviously, and then with the lower pace of completions in Eagle Ford over the back half of the year, I'm just wanting to understand if there's perhaps downside to the existing capital spending guidance for this year or for missing something and perhaps increases internationally or elsewhere that were not fully appreciating? And then as you think about 2016, understanding that it's early and that the macro environment is fluid, can you help us just kind of understand the framework as we try to gauge our expectations for 2016 CapEx, perhaps what the moving parts are, if there's anything going on internationally moving one way or the other, and how your thinking about Eagle Ford in the 4 rig program going to 2016?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a lot of stuff there. Allow someone to get to '16, we've only been 10 minutes. First on first question, our CapEx is pretty firm where we are. It could be down slightly, but I can tell you they're doing everything not to increase it at all, especia
componenttext: That's a lot of stuff there. Allow someone to get to '16, we've only been 10 minutes. First on first question, our CapEx is pretty firm where we are. It could be down slightly, but I can tell you they're doing everything not to increase it at all, especially with the latest price. The Eagle Ford Shale is doing very, very well for us. We probably going to end the year with a little bigger inventory than we normally carry at Murphy and we'll probably looking at the typical front-end loading again next year. And we would have optionality there if the Eagle Ford continues to be efficient as it has been then we want to use some of that to maintain our CapEx. That will be harder to do with prices low like this, but we feel comfortable with our guidance and our CapEx, and I would say slightly down, but we're not anticipating that to be that big. From a 2016 perspective, of course, that's very difficult to answer today. We were deal a couple of months ago with $65, $66 WTI in our business. We were, at that time, forecasting CapEx to be lower than we have a this year, slightly lower. We're now looking at $50 case, a lower case, if you will, I think it's a misnomer that our CapEx will be very high in that case. And as I look at it today, I don't have the break out around the world and looking at the total cash flow CapEx perspective in a way I look at this in the reductions of that type of $50 case would cost is that our debt levels as to our revolver, would have 2.25 billion of the bonds, and we have $2 billion revolver. We would stay inside our revolver levels without repatriation of cash abroad, which we have cash, of course, in Canada, Malaysia, complex and timely oriented to repatriate that money which gives us optionality. And we're allowed to maintain our dividend, lower CapEx, below this year and survived at a $50 world without changing really almost at debt levels that Murphy has today. So happy about that, and really not offering a lot more color than that this time.

componenttext: Well, it's still a tough business for us. It's incredible operating facility and word facility we've doubled our sanctioned Bcf there per well. It's going very well for us in that perspective, very disciplined, I guess, agco per day is CAD 2 40, CAD 2 50, I'd say breakeven 10% return, get caught in a situation where if you do not drill some were you on the production ghost dawn and OpEx. We do have some of our production sold, for lack of a better word, others use our facility. And that's a kind of economics we're in, and that's why it's a sale of a midstream would add return on capital employed to a situation that we swap [indiscernible] OpEx commitment, if you will. Bringing that EBITDA forward. Also though, on a macro basis, I mean we do still have LNG around United States and exporting what will that do to the big gas picture, what will happen to be LNG of the West Coast they're both Canadian and U.S. side. And from a long-term macro perspective, when I first went to Malaysia in 1999, I was told we'd never sell gas, and the gas system took word. And I think we sold 304 million a day-to-day there. So there's a big LNG machine there that's being built they don't have everything organized, but will be an optionality for us one day, you never know it.

componenttext: We're just not ready to say we originally thought will have to go to 6 rigs to maintain it, just probably a little less than that now, probably with prices we'll not be able to do that. Too early in the game to see production Eagle Ford in August. Looking pretty good.

componenttext: Our CapEx there has been a little over $800 million now a year, our efficiencies are going very well and I just got off the phone here with we're just building up a little higher inventory than we normally keep. That's even with the 2 frac spreads. So the drilling is doing very well for us there. We have different parts of the play, some drill faster than others, all of which are coming down below 5 million per cost normalize across the field. Just maintaining our CapEx and having slightly higher production for the year. I think that's a good story. I think I have some worry about dropping things and losing the efficiency gains ahead. And as I've said far back earlier in the questions here today, I think the offshore business, the day's business, but they've been enormous of savings from the vendors in the onshore business. So the cost if cheaper than it was last year and the year before and I just feel real comfortable with team make up in size and efficiency and machine we got rolling down there right now.

componenttext: Well, moving forward, economics got no trouble in today's prices in the Eagle Ford Shale because we are on old player, not an NGO player at all, not a gas player or a condensate player there. Not far away from there, but the cost are getting better. We're starting to have some very high rates, come out of some wells in these larger completions even with our chopping techniques that we have, which should lead to some higher EUR and some of layers and lowering the DD&A and of this Austin Chalk opportunity so kind of a macro thing now looking pretty good and the main point is if you think everybody else is looking good, Montney's looking good too.

componenttext: Well, when we do have another 2 50 available to us, it is sometimes nice, in my mind, it takes off the table this low price, especially when it gets down below some recent announced M&A, and we all know what those M&A deals are in onshore, especially, which are heavy later and we're heavy oil BOE outfit. It is a nice thing to do occasionally, and it's one of the things we're considering as we're maintaining our CapEx of this year and get into next year than we want to do that, and we do have an ample balance sheet to do it, you're absolutely correct. And it is something that's constantly reviewed with our board here at Murphy and my executive team.

componenttext: We're, like I said, taking a pause from the real deep sub-salt expensive wells in the Gulf post what we have the right now, and of course, the Solomon well we're committed to negotiated our partner there with these on that outcome. We were looking at shallower Mexico and part the like shallower Malaysia place very underexplored, nice place to work, we're trying to focus back in Houston with lower G&A and West Africa, less international farm that, of course, is international we run out of Houston. We participated, it was a situation there where you did various work programs and economic parts of the bid. As part of that, the government then released their minimum government take after the bids were submitted, and we were slightly below what they requested. So therefore, a bid that work out, and it didn't workout, and there are many bid rounds ahead there, there's deepwater coming. I think it's a very underexplored, nice play to work if you're concentrating people and costing to the Gulf of Mexico, it will be something out in time for well commitment where we have virtually 0. So would be a big issue at the capital or full prices will stay down lower longer. So I like the timing of it, like bit more further interviewed going forward, like we do other low-cost ruling opportunities internationally.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you're right and we've looked at a lot of opportunities here and we look at 3 or 4 all the time in both offshore and onshore all the time here. So we have a big team working on this, we're very interested, we market very closely and the way to think
componenttext: Well, you're right and we've looked at a lot of opportunities here and we look at 3 or 4 all the time in both offshore and onshore all the time here. So we have a big team working on this, we're very interested, we market very closely and the way to think about Murthy in that world we have a strict price rate of return, and we have oil price recovery rate of return we would like. And if we can't get the strip price rate of return we like then we won't be unsuccessful anything that early on, just a timing issue. We had a very nice hedging of oil for our shareholders at Murphy with the sell down in Malaysia. Then we come in to a collapse in prices accumulating last Thanksgiving. And then we never saw the bid-ask spread organized for us to participate at that time, and here we are again with another collapse again or a lot of volatility, a lot of noise around the mid-40s and things of that nature. A bid ask spread rate closer this time around I would say, yes, hope so. But we're not interested in taking on the sell down in Malaysia and also our balance sheet, which is very strong, we have a lot of ample room there to hold our peers. We're not interested in doing this unless you get to return we need, Roger. And that's kind of where that these right now, but we're very active in place.

componenttext: Well, we're a company that is doing okay in that environment. Our balance sheet are oily in nature, our cash flow for BOE is very good. Real misnomer about Murphy is collapses without the exploration is not true, it's flat for long, long time. It's never going to be the leader, but it's very, very highly acceptable from a cash flow BOE basis. As you would look at our onshore business, for example, you would find things that would be an outlier, primarily in Canada. And do we want to look at some of those assets, I've talked about some of that before publicly. But when you have another price collapse in a few months, it's difficult to bid-ask spread for sale, and it's difficult to bid-ask spread for buying. So I think that we have to continue to execute and look what we have and take on the opportunities when opportunities come, we need to then do things post that to get the portfolio in a more concentrated pure play basis, I think would be best. But again, not interested in just doing that for the sake of doing it at this time and probably won't. So I guess, that answers your question, Ryan.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Kelly Whitley, who has recently joined us as
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Kelly Whitley, who has recently joined us as Vice President of Investor Relations and Communications.
Please refer to the informational slides we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with our webcast today. 
Today's call will follow our usual format. John will begin by providing a review of second quarter 2015 financial results. Roger will then follow with an operational update, after which, questions will be taken.
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussion of risk factors, see Murphy's 2014 annual report on Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy takes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements.
I'll now turn the call over to John.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Barry, and good afternoon, everyone. The consolidated results of Murphy Oil Corporation in the second quarter of 2015 were a loss of $73.8 million, which equates to $0.42 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $129.4 million or a p
componenttext:
Thank you, Barry, and good afternoon, everyone. The consolidated results of Murphy Oil Corporation in the second quarter of 2015 were a loss of $73.8 million, which equates to $0.42 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $129.4 million or a profit of $0.72 per diluted share a year ago. Excluding discontinued operations in the United Kingdom, continuing operations had a loss of $89 million or $0.51 per diluted share in the second quarter of '15, again, compared to the second quarter of 2014 of a profit of $142.7 million or $0.79 per diluted share. The second quarter current year results from continuing operations included a $23.8 million charge or at least a 2% tax rate increase in Alberta. This change will increase future tax rates for operations in net Canadian province to a total of 12% tax beginning in 2016. Additionally, we had after-tax severance and other changes of $7.5 million in the quarter.
Since the beginning of 2015, we have had overall staffing reductions of about 7% associated with the company reorganization plan. The savings from these staffing reductions will benefit us going forward. The quarter also included a benefit of $19.3 million from post-closing settlements associated with our earlier combined sale of 30% of our interest in Malaysia, and that sale occurred in late 2014 and early 2015. These and other items affecting comparability of earnings between periods are listed in our schedule of adjusted earnings, which is included as a part of our earnings release. Amounts in this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis. 
Earnings in the 2015 second quarter were negatively impacted by a significantly lower realized sales process per crude oil and natural gas liquids and natural gas compared to the same quarter in 2014. The company's average realized price for all of its crude oil production fell more than $37 per barrel, amounting to a 40% drop. Natural gas prices also were weaker in the second quarter of 2015 compared to the prior year's quarter with average North American gas price realizations dropping $1.61 per Mcf or a decline of 40%. Net natural gas prices offshore Sarawak fell similarly. Our oil-weighted diverse portfolio of assets benefits our company as 52% of our second quarter production was sold off of Brent and LLS benchmarks which continue to bring stronger prices compared to the West Texas Intermediate base volumes. Sales prices have further softened in July and therefore, revenues continue to be under pressure as 2015 prices remain significantly below prices from a year ago.
Crude oil and gas liquids production in the 2015 second quarter was lower than 2014 levels primarily due to the 30% sale of interest in Malaysia. Taking the Malaysia sale into account, our liquids production in the 2015 second quarter actually increased 6% compared to a pro forma total for the prior year.  Total oil and gas liquids production in the second quarter of 2015 was just over 131,000 barrels per day. Natural gas volumes were 425 million cubic feet per day in the 2015 quarter, flat to '14. However, again, factoring in the pro forma effects of the 30% sale in Malaysia, gas production actually increased 17% in the second quarter 2015, primarily due to higher production from the Montney area in Western Canada.
Capital expenditures for continuing operations for the first 6 months of 2015 totaled $1.15 billion, which was a 34% decline from the comparable 2014 period. We continue to project our total 2015 capital expenditures at $2.3 billion. At June 30, 2015, into the second quarter, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to approximately $3.3 billion, 29% of total capital employed, while net debt amounted to just over 20% at the end of the second quarter. In July, we moved $150 million of funds from the U.K. following the sale of the U.K. downstream assets back to the United States. And these funds have been used to repay a portion of our outstanding debt early in the third quarter.
That concludes my comments, and I'll turn it now over to Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Before we get started on our operational review today, I want to welcome Kelly to Murphy and her new role overseeing IR and Communications. Kelly brings many years of experience to the position. We look forward to working with her.Barry
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Before we get started on our operational review today, I want to welcome Kelly to Murphy and her new role overseeing IR and Communications. Kelly brings many years of experience to the position. We look forward to working with her.
Barry has done a great job for us over the past 5 years in Investor Relations. He'll be moving into a new role and will lead 3 combined corporate functions as Vice President of Insurance, Security and Risk. The combination of these 3 corporate functions was developed post the recent organizational efficiency study that John just mentioned. 
As far as reorganization, we have split exploration to 2 regional groups, each reporting to Gene Coleman, the current EVP of Offshore Business. We've restructured exploration to reduce focus areas, improve capital allocation and lower costs.
Looking back at a pretty solid quarter for us, we have the following highlights. Our company remains in favorable financial position with balance sheet flexibility, take advantage of opportunities and carryout capital and corporate programs. We initiated $250 million stock repurchase in May and completed it in July, this past quarter, with just under 6 million shares retired or 3% of the company. This represents buying our own proved reserves at near $12 per BOE in this tranche.
Since 2012, we repurchased a total of $1.375 billion of company stock or 12.4%. We continue to make progress on the portfolio completing the sale of the U.K. downstream business. The Malaysia sale down was timely hedged to falling oil prices, and we still have many levers remaining to reposition the company going forward. We're currently reviewing the value of our midstream assets in Canada, Montney, Eagle Ford Shale and in the Gulf of Mexico.
Operationally, we made a nice gas discovery in Permai well in Block H Malaysia. This 200-plus Bcf resource will fit nicely with our Floating LNG development plans going forward.
In the Gulf of Mexico, we achieved first production from the 2-well Medusa subsea expansion ahead of schedule and on budget. And at Kodiak, we completed the first of 2 subsea wells ahead of schedule with drilling results to plan significantly derisking the project returns.
In shallow water Sarawak Malaysia, we completed a 5-well drilling campaign at the Belum gas field plant and are now drilling at the Permas oilfield.
In our onshore business. Liquid shale continue to perform well, we have delivered 36 new wells online in the second quarter, and have recently completed wells in the Montney continue to deliver above planned results. 
As we look at our operating metrics, our global lease operating expense for Q2 2015, excluding Syncrude, is $10.90 per BOE, showing an improvement of 9% from quarter 2 '14 and 30% down from 2013. We are pleased with the overall effort that the company is making in cost reductions and this effort will continue throughout the year.
The Eagle Ford Shale had a second quarter operating expense near $10 per BOE, and we expect to see further improvements in the second half of the year.
We entered the price collapse last year and are currently in a good position relative to cash flow per barrel metrics. While the price drop has served this metric, we have not had any significant impairments which is impacting many of the peer group.
We recently finished drilling our first well with the sixth generation rig Ocean BlackRhino in the Gulf of Mexico with strong operational execution on this well at 20% below budget. The punchline for me here is improved returns are ahead in deepwater, especially in the drilling and completion of delineation wells we have planned and major deepwater developments in the future.
In Eagle Ford Shale, we continue to lower cost to drop forward efficiency gains. Our average well cost is now down by 21% from last year, and we're focused on getting that down to 25% overall by year end.
Second quarter production averaged 201,952 barrel equivalents per day, exceeding our guidance of 197,000. The near 5,000 barrel equivalents per day variance which primarily attributed to new well performance in Eagle Ford Shale, rich start-up of the Medusa subsea expansion project and higher-than-forecasted heavy oil production from Seal.
Looking ahead to the third quarter. Production guidance is estimated 200,000 barrel equivalents per day. The decrease from second quarter is primarily attributed to lower Malaysia production with the planned maintenance of the Kakap-Gumusut main facility, risking of Sarawak and Kikeh gas volumes and lower Canadian onshore production due to normal well decline, partially offset by higher Syncrude and Medusa subsea volumes for the quarter.
We've increased our full year production guidance to a range of 200,000 to 208,000 barrel equivalents per day.
As we reach the midpoint of the year, we remain on track with our capital spend budgets, some 34% below last year's level. But that significant reduction in capital we're targeting production growth this year of around 2%. The year-on-year growth is led by new well performance in Eagle Ford Shale and Montney.
In Western Canada, our natural gas production from the Montney in second quarter was 192 million cubic feet per day. Our new completion designs continue to deliver strong well performance with EURs now in the 8 to 10 Bcf range, well ahead of the regional Montney sanctions that call for 4 Bcf per well. We have a refracked pilot underway on some of the older wells at Tupper and have an inventory of 9 previously drilled wells and are currently completing 5 of them to maintain production rates and keep unit operating expenses low.
At Seal, we continue to progress our long-term commercial steam project regulatory applications for essential thermal project that were submitted in quarter 1 this year, and we recently sanctioned feed work for the project. We're seeing some positive results from primary production from multilateral horizontal wells and have a running room in that area.
In Eagle Ford Shale, second quarter 2015 production was comprised of 9% liquids, averaging near 60,800 barrels equivalent per day. As planned, we continue to operate 4 rigs and 2 completion spreads, and the current plan is to stay at that level activity for the rest of the year. We brought 36 wells, new wells online in the second quarter and it brought on near 60% of our total estimated wells for the year in the first half. We're planning on delivering 36 wells in quarter 3 and 25 wells in quarter 4 with the program being front-end loaded as per guidance and plans.
Production in the third quarter of 2015 is estimated to be near 60,000 equivalents per day with the 2015 full year outlook not expected to exceed 59,000, some 2,000 barrel equivalents a day ahead of our annual production for 2014.
We continue to optimize our frac designs and are seeing strong results from recent super slick completions and in the Karnes and Tilden areas. We have now begun a new trial of high intensity completions with larger sand volumes and tighter stage spacing. Like any major oil field, we're always searching for additional production zones. We're assessing the potential of the Austin Chalk play in our Eagle Ford Shale acreage. We have begun a three-well appraisal plan in the play with the first well coming online in October.
Our current assessment shows a minimum of 70 Austin Chalk locations in the Carnes area with potential for additional locations depending on the results of this appraisal.
Murphy's well-positioned Eagle Ford Shale, with our oil-weighted production mix compared to many peers, our limited exposure to lower NGL and natural gas prices gives us leverage in an oil price recovery. Murphy's well-ramped up strategy focuses on maximizing the value by balancing early production rates with ultimate recovery. This strategy has led Murphy to have one of the highest levels of 2-year recovery per well across the play.
The eagle Ford Shale's a valuable asset within our portfolio. The value of Eagle Ford to Murphy is enhanced by early ground for entry in the play of over 2,000 potential well locations remaining, now estimate the total resource at near 750 million barrels equivalent, which is very similar to the entire reserve base of Murphy today. We used to say that field's going very, very well for us.
The Malaysian second quarter, we completed a five-well drilling program for natural gas at the Belum field in shallow water offshore Sarawak. The Belum field has low nitrogen content that will blend into our current gas production, allow us to derisk our 250 million per day contractual volume on demand going forward. We're currently drilling oil wells in the Permas shallow water development, and this operation's going well with cost trending 20% under budget.
Sarawak gas production for the second quarter was 111 million cubic feet per day net, supported by strong gas nominations and liquid production at near 14,700 barrels of oil per day.
We successfully completed the planned outage in early second quarter at our Sarawak facilities to complete required inspections and major maintenance. 
Production offshore Sabah, averaging a 30,900-barrel equivalent per day for the second quarter with 85% liquids, planned maintenance activities with Kakap-Gumusut main facility to install gas handling and injection system commenced on June 9 and have recently been completed.
Earlier this month, we had a gas discovery of Permai exploration well in Block H, where we operate the well with 42% working interest, our eighth consecutive success in the area around that field.
This 200-plus Bcf discovery will allow optimization of the Floating LNG project and lower our development cost.
In the Gulf of Mexico, production for the quarter was over 22,900 barrel equivalents per day with 61% liquids. The Medusa two-well expansion achieved first oil in the second quarter with the well starting up late April and mid-June, respectively. We've exceeded our projected daily volumes and beat our scheduled targets. Field development work at the nonoperating Kodiak project continued towards the first of 2 wells and have been drilled and completed the plan and modification of top subfacilites and subsea executions underway.
The Sea Eagle prospect in Mississippi Canyon Block 692 failed to encounter commercial quantities of hydrocarbon and will be expensed as a dry hole. The well, which we operated with a 35% working interest, was not included in our second quarter guidance as it was expected to reach total depth in the third quarter. Our drilling operations team completed the well 30 days ahead of schedule and $25 million gross under budget.
We have expanded into a new area in the Gulf of Mexico with our entry to the Wilcox play through a 20% working interest ground floor farm-in foreman into the nonoperated Solomon prospect and Walker Ridge by 225. The well has a gross pre-drill of over 300 million barrels.
Looking at our drilling program for the rest of 2015 in the Gulf of Mexico, the Solomon well, which is currently projected to reach total depth sometime near the end of third quarter or early fourth quarter, has been included in our dry hole exposure for the third quarter.
BlackRhino has moved into a drill at lower risk prospect at Dalmatian South 2#. The Transocean Discoverer Deep Sea is expected to complete required inspections by the middle of August, and the slated to sidetrack the Thunder Bird discovery, which shall be a subsea tieback to a nearby Thunder Hawk facility.
Recognizing our lack of exploration success, we plan to focus rig commitments on our lower risk appraisal wells and blocks where we have had prior exploration success. We'll allocate capital to higher return opportunities near existing infrastructure, not invest further in higher risk, higher cost wells at this time.
In Malaysia, we will focus on our gas discovery at Permai and deepwater Block H with 2 shallow water oil prospects, Merapuh 5 and Marakas and Block SK 314A adjacent to our very successful Sarawak oil and gas developments.
Later in the quarter, we will drill the Paus East in Block SK 2C offshore Sarawak. This well is near prior discovery from the block and is located in our new focus areas. We plan to finish off the year with a nonoperated appraisal of our gas discoveries in Brunei. Our former well commitments through 2016 are primarily in Malaysia, Brunei and Vietnam, which is one of our focus areas with lower cost exploration. Post 2016, we have only one required well commitment in the entire company, and an estimated net cost of only $4 million. We'll have capital allocation options for exploration in 2016 and beyond as we have worked off commitments made in prior years. 
We, like all deepwater operators, have deepwater rig commitments. The end of our rig commitments with the BlackRhino and Discoverer Deep Seas are expiring in February and November 2016, respectively.
Production for the third quarter is estimated to be 200,000 equivalents per day. We've increased our full year production guidance with the range of 200,000 to 208,000 barrel equivalents per day. Capital expenditures remain unchanged from our previous guidance and are currently forecasted to be $2.3 billion in 2015.
Murphy Oil has returned significant value to its shareholders over the last 6 years through regular dividends, a special dividend, a spin-off of Murphy U.S.A. and share repurchases. Our strong balance sheet supports the current regular dividend and allows the company to carry out its capital programs and review opportunities.
At current prices, our dividend yield is near 4% above industry peer average. Share repurchases since 2012 have acquired our own proved reserves below our F&D cost and competitive to other acquisitions. While many companies are issuing equity or taking major impairments from their assets, Murphy, through its conservative nature, has been named to avoid significant write-downs in the business.
As takeaways today, our strong operational performance this year has allowed us to increase our production guidance for the year while staying within our capital spending budget. Our oil-weighted price advantage portfolio provides us with the cash flow per BOE benefit over many of our peers. We're driving cost lower in our business through cost reductions and efficiency improvements in both our offshore and onshore segments. Our conservative balance sheet is a positive for us, and the second price collapse in 9 months, it allows Murphy to maintain a continued focus on our shareholders' carryout capital programs and look for opportunities to improve our company going forward.
We'll now take your questions. Thank you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Leo Mariani with RBC.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Leo Mariani with RBC.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just longer-term question here on exploration. Obviously, you guys are sort of winding down some of the activities, it sounds like you'll have some activity next year as well and minimal commitments. Are you guys considering replacing that exploration com
componenttext: Just longer-term question here on exploration. Obviously, you guys are sort of winding down some of the activities, it sounds like you'll have some activity next year as well and minimal commitments. Are you guys considering replacing that exploration component of the budget longer-term as we get out into 2017, '18 with acquisitions, your onshore leasing, or how should we think about the strategy shift here?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think, the results, Leo, as you know, are not where we want to be, and we got back into the Gulf here and had 3 unsuccessful wells in a row. Let's take a pause there. We're not stopping exploration around the world, we're taking a pause on
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think, the results, Leo, as you know, are not where we want to be, and we got back into the Gulf here and had 3 unsuccessful wells in a row. Let's take a pause there. We're not stopping exploration around the world, we're taking a pause on the drilling to -- we can replenish our portfolio and make sure these investments, make sure the partners we're in and what type of wells, where will cost go, I think drilling rig cost will come down and policy is warranted. It also, though, as you brought up, does allow us many capital allocation advantages whether we would consider M&A in lieu of exploration, what we consider a component of production and exploration from that company. And I like to think of it as a another price collapse coming, another budget year coming, not the success I needed, less commitments, very significantly low commitment in '17, practically none. And I think it just gives an advantage to regroup and allows us to a capital allocation across the spectrum there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And could you elaborate a little bit more in acquisitions? You guys are still looking at sort of offshore Gulf of Mexico and kind of onshore oily stuff?
componenttext: Okay. And could you elaborate a little bit more in acquisitions? You guys are still looking at sort of offshore Gulf of Mexico and kind of onshore oily stuff?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that would be fair. That would be fair. Probably not north of Oklahoma and Gulf of Mexico still a place. Our unique strategy of offshore and onshore allows us to look at both. We have the ability to operate in both. And we look at many opportunities,
componenttext: Yes, that would be fair. That would be fair. Probably not north of Oklahoma and Gulf of Mexico still a place. Our unique strategy of offshore and onshore allows us to look at both. We have the ability to operate in both. And we look at many opportunities, but we like to have a bit of return and strip pricing, Leo. We're not interested in doing it for store.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess with respect to your comment about moving some of the deepwater drilling to kind of lower risk opportunities, you had talked about sidetrack kind of offset at Dalmatian and also some work at Thunder Bird. Is this just kind of -- are thos
componenttext: Okay. And I guess with respect to your comment about moving some of the deepwater drilling to kind of lower risk opportunities, you had talked about sidetrack kind of offset at Dalmatian and also some work at Thunder Bird. Is this just kind of -- are those kind of one-off well opportunities there? Is there more inventory behind that in the next few years?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's about 3 opportunities near Dalmatian that are like F&D around $15 and have $40 to $50 breakeven, full life cycle, 10% rate of return. So we consider those very good. It allows us to take a pause in the really expensive deep exploration wells for a
componenttext: There's about 3 opportunities near Dalmatian that are like F&D around $15 and have $40 to $50 breakeven, full life cycle, 10% rate of return. So we consider those very good. It allows us to take a pause in the really expensive deep exploration wells for a while until those costs come down further, it allows the regrouping of our partnering and our data and our total review of that business. I like these opportunities a lot. They're very accretive economically to us. We've seen a lot of success here with Medusa subsea expansion. We're going to have a nice success at Kodiak from an entry we made into that project, and Dalmatian's been successful. So these have been around, and we have allocated capital to some exploration, and now we're reviewing that and putting our capital into these projects that fit in well with low price environment in my view.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. And I guess, you've kind of outlined your exploration commitment in 2016. We've got some obligation wells and your deepwater rigs are going to roll off, I guess, in February, November. You threw the dollar number in 2017, $4 million. Is there a
componenttext: All right. And I guess, you've kind of outlined your exploration commitment in 2016. We've got some obligation wells and your deepwater rigs are going to roll off, I guess, in February, November. You threw the dollar number in 2017, $4 million. Is there a dollar number for '16 on exploration?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's on that slide in our deck today. I think it's a little over 100 today for the wells that we need to drill with national oil companies. Some of these are very nice wells to drill in shallow water Sarawak, Malaysia. There's some further commitment well
componenttext: It's on that slide in our deck today. I think it's a little over 100 today for the wells that we need to drill with national oil companies. Some of these are very nice wells to drill in shallow water Sarawak, Malaysia. There's some further commitment wells in Block H, where we've been very, very successful. There's some commitment wells found in Brunei where we we've had success. So I don't consider it a very high risk program. At this time, it gives us a lot of flexibility in our CapEx for '16, and enormous flexibility in '17.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Guy Baber with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Guy Baber with Simmons & Company.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Roger, you made an interesting comment that you see improved returns ahead in the deepwater. I believe you've mentioned before that you hadn't been seeing a lot of deflation offshore, so I was just hoping for an update on the deflation side, and then some
componenttext: Roger, you made an interesting comment that you see improved returns ahead in the deepwater. I believe you've mentioned before that you hadn't been seeing a lot of deflation offshore, so I was just hoping for an update on the deflation side, and then some more detail behind your comments calling for better returns. How much of that is due to self-help and Murphy getting more efficient? How much is due to what you're seeing on the macro side from a deflationary perspective? And then does that change the way you plan to allocate capital at all?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, like I said, from capital allocation exploration perspective, we have these wells that we were just asking about Leo here about some lower breakeven price wells that we can take a pause in exploration, which I think is nice, especially when rig rate
componenttext: Well, like I said, from capital allocation exploration perspective, we have these wells that we were just asking about Leo here about some lower breakeven price wells that we can take a pause in exploration, which I think is nice, especially when rig rates are high. I'm a deepwater person. I've been in deepwater my whole career, I understand the business fairly well. It's really a days business, more than a vendor cost-reduction business where the onshore is a lot about vendor time and efficiency. But offshore is a day business. And I was a big believer in these big generation rigs, I thought they were too complex, too big, too much going on. I visited the one we had. It's one of the best wells I've ever seen in my career. And if we get that kind of performance to produce these days with all the subsea handling and the off-line work that these rigs can do, and you put that with lower day rates for these rigs, I'm absolutely certain that's going to lead to better returns, that's going to fit in better with our pause in exploration, the kind of wells we can get into out in out in the '17, '18 time frame after we have the appropriate recalibration of our work in that effort.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Very helpful. And then I have a couple of CapEx questions. What you all have done a great job in keeping the CapEx down obviously, and then with the lower pace of completions in Eagle Ford over the back half of the year, I'm just wanting to u
componenttext: Okay, great. Very helpful. And then I have a couple of CapEx questions. What you all have done a great job in keeping the CapEx down obviously, and then with the lower pace of completions in Eagle Ford over the back half of the year, I'm just wanting to understand if there's perhaps downside to the existing capital spending guidance for this year or for missing something and perhaps there are increases internationally or elsewhere that were not fully appreciating? And then as you think about 2016, understanding that it's early and that the macro environment is fluid, can you help us just kind of understand the framework as we try to gauge our expectations for 2016 CapEx, perhaps what the moving parts are, if there's anything going on internationally moving one way or the other, and how your thinking about Eagle Ford in the 4-rig program going to 2016?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Golly, Guy, that's a lot of stuff there. I wonder how long it will take for someone to get to '16, we've only been 10 minutes. First, on your first question, our CapEx is pretty firm where we are. It could be down slightly, but I can tell you they're doin
componenttext: Golly, Guy, that's a lot of stuff there. I wonder how long it will take for someone to get to '16, we've only been 10 minutes. First, on your first question, our CapEx is pretty firm where we are. It could be down slightly, but I can tell you they're doing everything not to increase it at all, especially with the latest price. The Eagle Ford Shale is doing very, very well for us. We are probably going to end the year with a little bigger inventory than we normally carry at Murphy, and we'll probably looking at the typical front-end loading again next year. And we would have optionality there if the Eagle Ford continues to be efficient as it has been, then we'd want to use some of that to maintain our CapEx. That will be harder to do with prices low like this, but we feel comfortable with our guidance and our CapEx, and I would say it's slightly downward but I'm not anticipating that to be that big. From a 2016 perspective, of course, that's very difficult to answer today. We were dealing a couple of months ago with $65, $66 WTI in our business. We were, at that time, forecasting CapEx to be lower than we have a this year, slightly lower. We're now looking at $50 case, a lower case, if you will, I think it's a misnomer that our CapEx will be very high in that case. And as I look at it today, I don't have the break out around the world. I'm looking at the total cash flow CapEx perspective, and the way I look at this in the reductions of that type of $50 case would cost is that our debt levels, as to our revolver, we have 2.25 billion of the bonds, and we have $2 billion revolver. We would stay inside our revolver levels without repatriation of cash abroad, which we have cash, of course, in Canada, Malaysia, complex and timely oriented to repatriate that money which gives us optionality. And we're allowed to maintain our dividend, lower CapEx, below this year and survived at a $50 world without changing really almost the debt levels that Murphy has today. So happy about that, and really not offering a lot more color than that this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
