componenttext: CapEx is a key issue for everyone as you go into next year but I'll wait for your update. We'll see what the prices do. You mentioned midstream assets, EBITDA for those? And how you monetize it?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't have it and -- I have it, but I'm not talking about the EBITDA right now with you. I mean, it would be a similar multiple that you would see, but I've seen nice multiples in that business. And when you see nice multiples and things happening, Murp
componenttext: I don't have it and -- I have it, but I'm not talking about the EBITDA right now with you. I mean, it would be a similar multiple that you would see, but I've seen nice multiples in that business. And when you see nice multiples and things happening, Murphy -- you see other people doing things with nice multiples, we have it too here. So we have a very nice gas plant situation in Montney, a great infrastructure there. It's very high uptime, an incredible asset. We also have, I mean, the old facilities in the Eagle Ford Shale and we're contacted from time to time for our sparse and pipelines that the own in Gulf of Mexico. So those typical multiples you would see will cause other things to be similar to us and we're intrigued by this and are reviewing.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think, it makes sense to get cash in the door in these types of environment because you'd still be able to do something with it. Just -- you mentioned the gas pump up in the Montney and given the liability, I mean, obviously, along with tha
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think, it makes sense to get cash in the door in these types of environment because you'd still be able to do something with it. Just -- you mentioned the gas pump up in the Montney and given the liability, I mean, obviously, along with that is where do you reckon your equity in Montney now compete in terms of gas price?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's still a tough business for us. It's incredible to operate a facility and manage a facility. We've doubled our sanctioned Bcf there per well. It's going very well for us in that perspective, very disciplined. I guess AECO today is CAD 2.40, CAD
componenttext: Well, it's still a tough business for us. It's incredible to operate a facility and manage a facility. We've doubled our sanctioned Bcf there per well. It's going very well for us in that perspective, very disciplined. I guess AECO today is CAD 2.40, CAD 2.50. I'd say our breakeven 10% return. You get caught in a situation where if you do not drill some level of wells you're allowed, the production goes down and that impacts the OpEx. We do have some of our production sold, for lack of a better word, to others, to use to our facility. And that's the kind of economics we're in, and that's why this sale of a midstream would add return on capital employed to a situation that we would swap DD&A for OpEx commitment, if you will and bringing that EBITDA forward. Also though, on a macro basis, I mean, we do still have LNG around United States and exporting and what will that do to the big gas picture, what will happen to be LNG of the West Coast there on both Canadian and U.S. sides. And from a long-term macro perspective, when I first went to Malaysia in 1999, I was told we'd never sell gas in the gas system to Petronas. And I think we sold them 304 million a day-to-day there. So there's a big LNG machine there that's being built, they don't have everything organized on it. But will that be an optionality for us one day? You never know, Ed.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a small question around the Eagle Ford. I mean, obviously, running full rigs, you can see from your charts that you would build a bit of inventory towards year end. But what sort of -- if you round that level through next year, what kind of
componenttext: Okay. And then a small question around the Eagle Ford. I mean, obviously, running full rigs, you can see from your charts that you would build a bit of inventory towards year end. But what sort of -- if you round that level through next year, what kind of production do you think you'd get from the Eagle Ford?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're just not ready to say. We originally thought we'd have to go to 6 rigs to maintain it, just probably a little less than that now. Probably with the prices that they are, we won't be able to do that. Someone say we should cut back some of our rigs no
componenttext: We're just not ready to say. We originally thought we'd have to go to 6 rigs to maintain it, just probably a little less than that now. Probably with the prices that they are, we won't be able to do that. Someone say we should cut back some of our rigs now and protect CapEx there, but I feel that our 4-rig, 2-spread deal is really, really working well for us. Maybe some level of size to be in the game to continue with incredible efficiency. Such where we are now and see, I mean, these inventory wells we've drilled, see what our options are. I'm a little early in the game to say production in Eagle Ford in August, but looking pretty good.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question, you guys decide to retain the second frac crew in Eagle Ford. I mean, is that a function of higher number of wells drilled due to drilling efficiencies and a desire not to build DUCs? Is that what drove that retention?
componenttext: My first question, you guys decide to retain the second frac crew in Eagle Ford. I mean, is that a function of higher number of wells drilled due to drilling efficiencies and a desire not to build DUCs? Is that what drove that retention?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So our CapEx there has been a little over $800 million now a year, our efficiencies are going very well and I just got off the phone here with Ed, we're just building up a little higher inventory than we normally keep. That's even with the 2 frac spreads.
componenttext: So our CapEx there has been a little over $800 million now a year, our efficiencies are going very well and I just got off the phone here with Ed, we're just building up a little higher inventory than we normally keep. That's even with the 2 frac spreads. So the drilling is going really well very for us there. We have different parts of the play. Some drill faster than others, all of which are coming down below 5 million per D&C cost normalized across the field. Just maintaining our CapEx and having slightly higher production for the year. I think that's a good story. And I think I have some worry about dropping things and losing the efficiency gains ahead. And as I've said far back earlier in the questions here today, I think the offshore business is a day's business, but they've been enormous savings from the vendors in the onshore business. So the cost for that equipment's cheaper, of course, than it was last year and the year before. And I just feel real comfortable with our team make up, in size and efficiency and machine we got rolling down there right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. That makes sense. I mean, in the Eagle Ford, do you have any kind of breakdown on the economics on your 2,000 locations? I mean, would you consider them economic on the strip or any kind of breakdown as you think about that?
componenttext: Great. That makes sense. I mean, in the Eagle Ford, do you have any kind of breakdown on the economics on your 2,000 locations? I mean, would you consider them economic on the strip or any kind of breakdown as you think about that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, point forward economics, we got no trouble in today's prices in the Eagle Ford Shale on anything we have because we're on old player, not an NGL player at all, not a gas player or condensate player there. So that's not the issue. I think to get full
componenttext: Well, point forward economics, we got no trouble in today's prices in the Eagle Ford Shale on anything we have because we're on old player, not an NGL player at all, not a gas player or condensate player there. So that's not the issue. I think to get full on in income across your G&A and your amortization of leases, et cetera, et cetera, it's in the above $55 level. Not far away from there, but the cost are getting better. We're starting to have some very high rates come out of some wells in these larger completions even with our choking techniques that we have, which should lead to some higher EUR in some of the layers and lowering DD&A, and we have this Austin Chalk opportunity, so just kind of a macro thing looking pretty good and if -- the main point is if you think everybody else is looking good, mine's looking good too.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's right. That was just a question across all the locations, if that was the case.
componenttext: That's right. That was just a question across all the locations, if that was the case.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not worried so much about that today.
componenttext: I'm not worried so much about that today.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sounds good. I mean, just one other question, if I could. You guys, you completed the accelerated buyback in the quarter for $250 million, you've got more authorized, ample balance sheet. Can you just talk about your decision making process there for
componenttext: Yes, sounds good. I mean, just one other question, if I could. You guys, you completed the accelerated buyback in the quarter for $250 million, you've got more authorized, ample balance sheet. Can you just talk about your decision making process there for further buybacks as you look at the different opportunities you have as well as your funding?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we do have another $250 million available to us. It is sometimes nice, in my mind. It takes some off the table with these low price, especially when it gets down below some recent announced M&A, and we all know what those M&A deals are in onshore, e
componenttext: Well, we do have another $250 million available to us. It is sometimes nice, in my mind. It takes some off the table with these low price, especially when it gets down below some recent announced M&A, and we all know what those M&A deals are in onshore, especially, which are heavy P2-related and we're heavy oil BOE outfit. It is a nice thing to do occasionally, and it's one of the things we're considering as we maintain our CapEx this year and get into next year, do we want to do that, and we do have an ample balance sheet to do it. You're absolutely correct. And it is something that's constantly reviewed with our board here at Murphy and my executive team.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe I could slip one more, if I could. I know you guys recently had been in the shallow round for Mexico with partner. I mean, any kind of color on how that process and opportunity played out? And are there any other readthroughs as you think about an e
componenttext: Maybe I could slip one more, if I could. I know you guys recently had been in the shallow round for Mexico with partner. I mean, any kind of color on how that process and opportunity played out? And are there any other readthroughs as you think about an eventual deepwater round or is that related to your reduction comments on offshore before?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're, like I said, taking a pause from the real deep subsalt Miocene expensive wells in the Gulf post what we have committed to right now, and of course, this Solomon well we're committed to, took many, many months to negotiate with our partner there whi
componenttext: We're, like I said, taking a pause from the real deep subsalt Miocene expensive wells in the Gulf post what we have committed to right now, and of course, this Solomon well we're committed to, took many, many months to negotiate with our partner there which are phased with that outcome. We were looking at shallow water Mexico and thought of it like a shallow water Malaysia play. it's very underexplored, a nice place to work. We're trying to focus back into Houston with lower G&A and less -- West Africa, less international farm that, of course, is international being run out of Houston. We participated, it was a situation there where you did various work programs and economic parts of the bid. As part of that, the government then released their minimum government take after the bids were submitted, and we were slightly below what they requested. So therefore, our bid didn't work out, and it didn't workout. And there are many bid rounds ahead there, there's deepwater coming. I think it's a very underexplored, nice place to work if you're concentrating people and cost into the Gulf of Mexico, it will be something out in time for well commitments for us, where we have virtually 0. So it wouldn't be a big issue to capital if oil prices were to stay down lower longer. So I like the timing of it, I like the underexplored nature of it. It didn't work out that time. And we're going to review it going forward, like we do other low-cost drilling opportunities internationally.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Roger Read with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Roger Read with Wells Fargo.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd like to ask you a little more on the acquisition front. About this time last year, when the sale of the Malaysian assets was announced, expectation was a redeployment. Now I recognize quite a lot of things have changed since this time last yea
componenttext: I guess I'd like to ask you a little more on the acquisition front. About this time last year, when the sale of the Malaysian assets was announced, expectation was a redeployment. Now I recognize quite a lot of things have changed since this time last year. You mentioned south of Oklahoma, but maybe you could talk a little bit about just how things are moving from sort of a bid-ask spread standpoint, I mean, with this double dip move here in crude prices.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, you're right and we've looked at a lot of opportunities here and we look at 3 or 4 all the time in both offshore and onshore all the time here. So we have a big team working on this, we're very interested. We monitor it very closely. And the
componenttext: Well, I mean, you're right and we've looked at a lot of opportunities here and we look at 3 or 4 all the time in both offshore and onshore all the time here. So we have a big team working on this, we're very interested. We monitor it very closely. And the way to think about Murphy in that world is we have a strip price rate of return minimum we would like, and we have a pause, an oil price recovery rate of return we would like. And if we can't get that strip price rate of return we like, then we're going to be unsuccessful, and I think that early on, just a timing issue. We had a very nice hedging of oil for our shareholders at Murphy with the sell down in Malaysia. Then we come in to a collapse in prices accumulating last Thanksgiving. And then we never saw the bid-ask spread organized for us to participate at that time, and here we are again with another collapse again or a lot of volatility, a lot of noise around the mid-40s and things of that nature. And will that bid-ask spread be -- worked closer this time around, I would say, yes, I hope so. But we're not interested in taking on the sell down in Malaysia and also our balance sheet, which is very strong. We have a lot of ample room there to hold our peers. We're not interested in doing this unless we get the return we need, Roger. And that's kind of where that is right now, but we're very active in the plays.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks. And I guess as a follow-up on that and Evan's question about this year repurchases created large enough transaction, you're probably willing to use equity as well as cash and debt. But should we think about anything you do as putting more of the b
componenttext: Thanks. And I guess as a follow-up on that and Evan's question about this year repurchases created large enough transaction, you're probably willing to use equity as well as cash and debt. But should we think about anything you do as putting more of the balance sheet in play and not putting equity to work at this point?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would hate to fence myself in on one way or another. We pride ourselves, I mean, the company, it hasn't offered equity since our initial public offering in 1956. So we're not a big believer in that. I prefer not to do it that way. And I think it matters
componenttext: I would hate to fence myself in on one way or another. We pride ourselves, I mean, the company, it hasn't offered equity since our initial public offering in 1956. So we're not a big believer in that. I prefer not to do it that way. And I think it matters a lot on who you're working with on the other side of the transaction. Are they private equity-backed and would like cash? Are they a shareholder or some type of merger? They maybe would like shares. And what has happened to that as to debt or certain situations there in that onshore and both offshore businesses and I think each deal is different, I'd hate to say you would never use it, but we'd prefer not to, Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Going back to the exploration, just to summarize, do you view the exploration prospect is not where you want to be to, the exploration strategy is not where you want to be or both, i.e. is it just a matter of replenishing the prospect inventory or is it b
componenttext: Going back to the exploration, just to summarize, do you view the exploration prospect is not where you want to be to, the exploration strategy is not where you want to be or both, i.e. is it just a matter of replenishing the prospect inventory or is it bigger than that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have to take a pause and replenish our portfolio into wells that are moving up. And we have a detailed capital allocation process here where we rank every opportunity in the breakeven oil pricing, NPV over I, et cetera, risk NPV in that game. We need t
componenttext: We have to take a pause and replenish our portfolio into wells that are moving up. And we have a detailed capital allocation process here where we rank every opportunity in the breakeven oil pricing, NPV over I, et cetera, risk NPV in that game. We need to take another look at all the technical work that we've done and all the prospects that we have and form in opportunities, our data sets, and take a pause in the Gulf of Mexico because today, with the rigs that we have, the wells are very expensive and we haven't done well like we need to do and we have to take a break in that business. We, at Murphy, though have a very diverse portfolio and business. We have some very low cost wells. This discovery in Block H Malaysia probably costs $15 million gross or something like that. You can drill $40-million deepwater wells in Malaysia where we've been very successful with the wells, and the Gulf of Mexico is very expensive. And we're not having the results I would like and I think it's a replenishment, a total relook at staff, processes and data and where we are in more that just a -- where our prospects are, Brian.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the Eagle Ford, as a percent of the total, you have some of the most oilier Eagle Ford out there. One thing we have noticed is that the percent oil from a very, very high base has been coming down slightly, and just wondered particularly
componenttext: Okay. And then on the Eagle Ford, as a percent of the total, you have some of the most oilier Eagle Ford out there. One thing we have noticed is that the percent oil from a very, very high base has been coming down slightly, and just wondered particularly if the rig count falls, if you have any projections or what you're thinking about the oiliness and if it kind of goes back to the 80%, 82% range or if it keeps coming down.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's only because we're gathering and capturing more gas. We had a lot of gas flaring when we started as per emission standards in the State of Texas. And we now have hardly any gas flaring in across all of that play with hundreds and hundreds of we
componenttext: Well, it's only because we're gathering and capturing more gas. We had a lot of gas flaring when we started as per emission standards in the State of Texas. And we now have hardly any gas flaring in across all of that play with hundreds and hundreds of wells, and it's so oily, and Brian, even you are going to have to start liking it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. I mean, one other question is certainly, did the gas rates and the mix start to go up over time? But your point is that you're not seeing it and you're not expecting it?
componenttext: That's great. I mean, one other question is certainly, did the gas rates and the mix start to go up over time? But your point is that you're not seeing it and you're not expecting it?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. And Brian, we got a long way to go to get some of your favorites.
componenttext: No. And Brian, we got a long way to go to get some of your favorites.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So maybe a high level one on strategy, you mentioned in the presentation that the remaining levers, the levers that remain on the portfolio adjustment. If you take a high look at your current portfolio, you've done a great job executing on the current ass
componenttext: So maybe a high level one on strategy, you mentioned in the presentation that the remaining levers, the levers that remain on the portfolio adjustment. If you take a high look at your current portfolio, you've done a great job executing on the current assets. But when you look at the portfolio in kind of a moderate crude world, is the portfolio weight what it needs to be or what you want it to be? What sort of levers outside of a potential acquisition is there? Or is there a larger restructuring or something that needs to take place to be competitive in a low to moderate crude price environment?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're a company that is doing okay in that environment. Our balance sheet are oily in nature. Our cash flow for BOE is very good. And a real misnomer about Murphy is that our R over P collapses without the exploration. It's not true. It's flat for l
componenttext: Well, we're a company that is doing okay in that environment. Our balance sheet are oily in nature. Our cash flow for BOE is very good. And a real misnomer about Murphy is that our R over P collapses without the exploration. It's not true. It's flat for long, long time. It's never going to be the leader, but it's very, very highly acceptable from a cash flow BOE basis. As you would look at our onshore business, for example, you would find things that would be an outlier, primarily in Canada. And do we want to look at some of those assets, I've talked about some of that before publicly. But when you have another price collapse and 2 in a few months, it's difficult to bid-ask spread for selling, it is difficult to bid-ask spread for buying. So I think that we have to continue to execute and look what we have and take on the opportunities when opportunities come in their balance sheet. And then -- we need to then do things post that to get the portfolio in a more concentrated pure play basis, I think would be best. But again, not interested in just doing that for the sake of doing it at this time and probably won't. So I guess, that answers your question, Ryan.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then maybe on the -- one more on the Eagle Ford. You guys have had a great performance up to this point. You've been beating numbers. The outperformance that we've seen up to this point, is that largely a function of additional c
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then maybe on the -- one more on the Eagle Ford. You guys have had a great performance up to this point. You've been beating numbers. The outperformance that we've seen up to this point, is that largely a function of additional completions? Is it better well performance, a combination of both? And maybe could you talk a little bit more in terms of potential for what you're seeing on improved well performance and some of the potential for additional resource and stacked plays and stuff?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're hitting on all cylinders there. We're very pleased with our EUR per wells. It's probably looking to increase in certain areas if we just get data on these new completions. Higher sand concentration completion is basically what they are, no mat
componenttext: Well, we're hitting on all cylinders there. We're very pleased with our EUR per wells. It's probably looking to increase in certain areas if we just get data on these new completions. Higher sand concentration completion is basically what they are, no matter what the fancy name is. The more sand, the concentrate is allowing us to open a well little more aggressive in having to pass. We have a methodology around doing that with our folks there in Houston. And to maintain the same type of reservoir performance with the larger sand concentration, that's allowing us to have, for the first time, some really namebrand type of rate without having the oil in a massive decline. As you would see from some from our peers, they're supported by this 2-year production data advantage that Murphy carries forward. So we're pleased with that, I think that's something that -- our new data and our new fracs are just coming in. We are obviously doing very well in the upper Eagle Ford situation there. We like all players in that field. That massive field have data that shows upper wells going along with lower wells. We have all those slides, and we have that too. It's going well for us. Our Catarina areas are flatter, longer than we originally thought. Very cheap drilling out in that part. Very -- from a capital allocation, just up there with Karnes. A totally different type of EUR shape but very economic. So doing really well there upper Eagle Ford, Lower Eagle Ford, stacked on top of each other, new completion design, another new completion design conning. Really doing well down there, Ryan.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. And are you guys testing -- are you testing the spacing at all, or do you feel like you've downspaced about as far as it potentially can at this point?
componenttext: That's great. And are you guys testing -- are you testing the spacing at all, or do you feel like you've downspaced about as far as it potentially can at this point?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. When you across a big play like us, an oil player like us and you have various things invested, we haven't gotten below the 40s. We consider 40 pretty standard, and I think there's a lot of data around 40s, and we're in that type of development mode.
componenttext: No. When you across a big play like us, an oil player like us and you have various things invested, we haven't gotten below the 40s. We consider 40 pretty standard, and I think there's a lot of data around 40s, and we're in that type of development mode. And I guess you would say it's 20 if you 40s on top of each other. And we have some of that going on, not a lot but when we do, the wells produce as you anticipate and we're pleased with those results. We don't have any negative pulldown of any kind going on in the Eagle Ford.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Cheng with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Cheng with Barclays.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Several quick questions. Sounds to me in your exploration program, you're just taking a pause and you still believe the company, at the core, is an international explorer. Is that a fair characterization of the company?
componenttext: Several quick questions. Sounds to me in your exploration program, you're just taking a pause and you still believe the company, at the core, is an international explorer. Is that a fair characterization of the company?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's fair, Paul. But I believe today, that we will be continuing to focus down more in the Gulf of Mexico, East Coast of Canada where would have tax benefits from international exploration, a very big focus area between Sarawak and Sabah, Malaysia all t
componenttext: That's fair, Paul. But I believe today, that we will be continuing to focus down more in the Gulf of Mexico, East Coast of Canada where would have tax benefits from international exploration, a very big focus area between Sarawak and Sabah, Malaysia all the way to Vietnam. Have a big office in KL, an advantage on G&A and cost of exploration. I think you will consider a major pause in the real expensive wells in the Gulf as we recalibrate going forward, and continuing to focus down, knowing more about less areas. And in the past, I felt that we knew less about more areas, and we're getting totally away from that concept. So what you say, yes, but in a different way.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And secondly, that I think a lot of your peers started asking the same questions: what is the -- what is the right split on the capital allocation between the short cycle and the long-cycle projects or assets? Roger, where do you stand on that? What
componenttext: Okay. And secondly, that I think a lot of your peers started asking the same questions: what is the -- what is the right split on the capital allocation between the short cycle and the long-cycle projects or assets? Roger, where do you stand on that? What are you thinking is the proper split for Murphy?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've -- this year, we've been about $2.3 billion CapEx. $800 million, close to $900 million, in Eagle Ford, and we had about $300 million for exploration, I suppose, and the rest has to do with timing of various offshore projects in Malaysia and of
componenttext: Well, we've -- this year, we've been about $2.3 billion CapEx. $800 million, close to $900 million, in Eagle Ford, and we had about $300 million for exploration, I suppose, and the rest has to do with timing of various offshore projects in Malaysia and offshore Gulf. I would say the step down from that with less exploration next year and if we get in a $50 price, where we have very limited exploration next year because like I said, we're taking a pause and that in some of the higher cost areas. So I would say that split's about the same. We're a 50-50 onshore, offshore player. We do have discontinued development work in Malaysia and shallow water where we have been very successful. Our Eagle Ford is doing really well. I think it's a good story to -- maybe $800 million plus CapEx there and maintain production there. So I don't have some big significant split out in things changing there, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And in Eagle Ford, just curious, Roger. I mean, you clearly have tremendous success in the efficiency gains and everything, and they're showing in the data. Do you think that Murphy is alone or that it's way ahead of the industry trend? Or that you're see
componenttext: And in Eagle Ford, just curious, Roger. I mean, you clearly have tremendous success in the efficiency gains and everything, and they're showing in the data. Do you think that Murphy is alone or that it's way ahead of the industry trend? Or that you're seeing your peers also have that kind of success? Because it certainly makes a big difference in terms of what the resiliency of their U.S. oil production may look like.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is true. Sometimes, I feel like we're part of the problem we're so successful. I do see it flattening in U.S. onshore production in the last couple of months, which I think is positive for the long-term situation there. I know that when we cut back o
componenttext: That is true. Sometimes, I feel like we're part of the problem we're so successful. I do see it flattening in U.S. onshore production in the last couple of months, which I think is positive for the long-term situation there. I know that when we cut back our completed wells, we do see a decline. It is strictly from that, it's nothing to do with that well performance. So if the oil price continues here and people do have that, and I see how it impacts Murphy and we're very, very proud of our acreage and very happy with the results. It will cause less production even though there has been efficiency. I think that we're a top quartile player in onshore. I think it shows that we built this team from scratch and can deliver. We are a very operationally-focused company. I'm very proud of that. I'm an operation-focused person. We have been successful in that play and I think we're just as good as anyone in that play. And I think the misnomer, because we're not just an onshore player, that we're not a very good executor in the onshore, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Okay, final question. Based on the comment -- 2 final questions. One, can you share with us how much is the capital you invest in the infrastructure in Eagle Ford?

componenttext: Don't have that number off top of my head right now, Paul, to be honest with you.

componenttext: Is that something that you would be willing to share or maybe have Kelly to give me a -- shoot me an email? I know you are not ready to talk about EBITDA, that kind of things, but I want to see if...

componenttextpreview: No, no. Just trying to understand the concept that, based on what you say, is that you're trying to keep year 2016 as cash flow neutrality, whatever is the oil price. Is that the overall concept?
componenttext: No, no. Just trying to understand the concept that, based on what you say, is that you're trying to keep year 2016 as cash flow neutrality, whatever is the oil price. Is that the overall concept?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to get too much further in '16. I would tell you, just to be straightforward with you, it's difficult for us to be cash flow/CapEx parity in a $50 world. That level of shortfall is probably not as significant as you think. We would make enor
componenttext: I'm not going to get too much further in '16. I would tell you, just to be straightforward with you, it's difficult for us to be cash flow/CapEx parity in a $50 world. That level of shortfall is probably not as significant as you think. We would make enormous cuts to our budget, do so, and I've already said, we're taking a pause in the expensive part of the world. And so as I said earlier, we, today, from a macro high level haven't been -- it certainly hasn't been agreed with out board, we can keep our debt levels about -- within our revolver and have flexibility that's to repatriation of a lot of cash we have abroad, Paul. And I think that's a pretty good situation if this thing goes $50 for the rest of the year and all of next year.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
