headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Barry Jeffery, Vice President.
componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Barry Jeffery, Vice President.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Kelly Whitley, who has recently joined us as
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Kelly Whitley, who has recently joined us as Vice President of Investor Relations and Communications.
Please refer to the informational slides we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with our webcast today. 
Today's call will follow our usual format. John will begin by providing a review of second quarter 2015 financial results. Roger will then follow with an operational update, after which, questions will be taken.
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussion of risk factors, see Murphy's 2014 annual report on Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy takes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements.
I'll now turn the call over to John.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Barry, and good afternoon, everyone. The consolidated results of Murphy Oil Corporation in the second quarter of 2015 were a loss of $73.8 million, which equates to $0.42 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $129.4 million or a p
componenttext:
Thank you, Barry, and good afternoon, everyone. The consolidated results of Murphy Oil Corporation in the second quarter of 2015 were a loss of $73.8 million, which equates to $0.42 per diluted share, and that compares to a profit of $129.4 million or a profit of $0.72 per diluted share a year ago. Excluding discontinued operations in the United Kingdom, continuing operations had a loss of $89 million or $0.51 per diluted share in the second quarter of '15, again, compared to the second quarter of 2014 of a profit of $142.7 million or $0.79 per diluted share. The second quarter current year results from continuing operations included a $23.8 million charge for a recent 2% tax rate increase in Alberta. This change will increase future tax rates for operations in that Canadian province to a total of 12% tax beginning in 2016. Additionally, we had after-tax severance and other changes of $7.5 million in the quarter.
Since the beginning of 2015, we have had overall staffing reductions of about 7% associated with the company reorganization plan. The savings from these staffing reductions will benefit us going forward. The quarter also included a benefit of $19.3 million from post-closing settlements associated with our earlier combined sale of 30% of our interest in Malaysia, and that sale occurred in late 2014 and early 2015. These and other items affecting comparability of earnings between periods are listed in our schedule of adjusted earnings, which is included as a part of our earnings release. Amounts in this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis. 
Earnings in the 2015 second quarter were negatively impacted by significantly lower realized sales prices for crude oil, natural gas liquids and natural gas compared to the same quarter in 2014. The company's average realized price for all of its crude oil production fell more than $37 per barrel, amounting to a 40% drop. Natural gas prices also were weaker in the second quarter of 2015 compared to the prior year's quarter, with average North American gas price realizations dropping $1.61 per Mcf or a decline of 40%. Net natural gas prices offshore Sarawak fell similarly. Our oil-weighted diverse portfolio of assets benefits our company, as 52% of our second quarter production was sold off of Brent and LLS benchmarks, which continue to bring stronger prices compared to the West Texas Intermediate base volumes. Sales prices have further softened in July and therefore, revenues continue to be under pressure as 2015 prices remain significantly below prices from a year ago.
Crude oil and gas liquids production in the 2015 second quarter was lower than 2014 levels, primarily due to the 30% sale of interest in Malaysia. Taking the Malaysia sale into account, our liquids production in the 2015 second quarter actually increased 6% compared to a pro forma total for the prior year.  Total oil and gas liquids production in the second quarter of 2015 was just over 131,000 barrels per day. Natural gas volumes were 425 million cubic feet per day in the 2015 quarter, flat to '14. However, again, factoring in the pro forma effects of the 30% sale in Malaysia, gas production actually increased 17% in the second quarter 2015, primarily due to higher production from the Montney area in Western Canada.
Capital expenditures for continuing operations for the first 6 months of 2015 totaled $1.15 billion, which was a 34% decline from the comparable 2014 period. We continue to project our total 2015 capital expenditures at $2.3 billion. At June 30, 2015, into the second quarter, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to approximately $3.3 billion, 29% of total capital employed, while net debt amounted to just over 20% at the end of the second quarter. In July, we moved $150 million of funds from the U.K. following the sale of the U.K. downstream assets back to the United States. And these funds have been used to repay a portion of our outstanding debt early in the third quarter.
That concludes my comments, and I'll turn it now over to Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Before we get started on our operational review today, I want to welcome Kelly to Murphy in her new role overseeing IR and Communications. Kelly brings many years of experience to the position. We look forward to working with her.Barry
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Before we get started on our operational review today, I want to welcome Kelly to Murphy in her new role overseeing IR and Communications. Kelly brings many years of experience to the position. We look forward to working with her.
Barry has done a great job for us over the past 5 years in Investor Relations. He'll be moving to a new role and will lead 3 combined corporate functions as Vice President of Insurance, Security and Risk. The combination of these 3 corporate functions was developed post the recent organizational efficiency study that John just mentioned. 
As part of our reorganization, we have split exploration into 2 regional groups, each reporting to Gene Coleman, the current EVP of our offshore business. We've restructured exploration to reduce focus areas, improve capital allocation and lower costs.
Looking back at a pretty solid quarter for us, we have the following highlights. Our company remains in favorable financial position with balance sheet flexibility to take advantage of opportunities and carry out capital and corporate programs. We initiated $250 million stock repurchase in May and completed it in July, this past quarter, with just under 6 million shares retired or 3% of the company. This represents buying our own proved reserves at near $12 per BOE in this tranche.
Since 2012, we repurchased a total of $1.375 billion of company stock or 12.4%. We continue to make progress on the portfolio, completing the sale of the U.K. downstream business. The Malaysia sell down was timely hedged to falling oil prices, and we still have many levers remaining to reposition the company going forward. We're currently reviewing the value of our midstream assets in Canada, Montney, Eagle Ford Shale and in the Gulf of Mexico.
Operationally, we made a nice gas discovery in Permai well in Block H Malaysia. This 200-plus Bcf resource will fit nicely with our Floating LNG development plans going forward.
In the Gulf of Mexico, we achieved first production from the 2-well Medusa subsea expansion ahead of schedule and on budget. And at Kodiak, we completed the first of 2 subsea wells ahead of schedule, with drilling results to plan significantly derisking the project returns.
In shallow water Sarawak Malaysia, we completed a 5-well drilling campaign at the Belum gas field to plan and are now drilling at the Permas oilfield.
In our onshore business, Eagle Ford Shale continued to perform well. We have delivered 36 new wells online in the second quarter, and our recently completed wells in the Montney continue to deliver above plan results. 
As we look at our operating metrics, our global lease operating expense for Q2 2015, excluding Syncrude, is $10.90 per BOE, showing an improvement of 9% from quarter 2 '14 and 30% down from 2013. We are pleased with the overall effort that the company is making in cost reductions and this effort will continue throughout the year.
The Eagle Ford Shale had a second quarter operating expense near $10 per BOE, and we expect to see further improvements in the second half of the year.
We entered the price collapse last year and are currently in a good position relative to cash flow per barrel metrics. While the price drop has hurt this metric,  we have not had any significant impairments which is impacting many in the peer group.
We recently finished drilling our first well with the sixth-generation rig Ocean BlackRhino in the Gulf of Mexico. We had strong operational execution on this well at 20% below budget. The punchline for me here is improved returns are ahead in deepwater, especially in the drilling and completion of delineation wells we have planned in major deepwater developments in the future.
In Eagle Ford Shale, we continue to lower cost to drive forward efficiency gains. Our average well cost is now down by 21% from last year, and we're focused on getting that down to 25% overall by year end.
Second quarter production averaged 201,952 barrel equivalents per day, exceeding our guidance of 197,000. The near 5,000 barrel equivalents per day variance, which primarily attributed to new well performance in Eagle Ford Shale, rich start-up of the Medusa subsea expansion project and higher-than-forecasted heavy oil production from Seal.
Looking ahead to the third quarter. Production guidance is estimated at 200,000 barrel equivalents per day. The decrease from second quarter is primarily attributed to lower Malaysia production with the planned maintenance of the Kakap-Gumusut main facility, risking of Sarawak and Kikeh gas volumes and lower Canadian onshore production due to normal well decline, partially offset by higher Syncrude and Medusa subsea volumes for the quarter.
We've increased our full year production guidance to a range of 200,000 to 208,000 barrel equivalents per day.
As we reach the midpoint of the year, we remain on track with our capital spend budget, some 34% below last year's level. With that significant reduction in capital, we're targeting production growth this year of around 2%. The year-on-year growth is led by new well performance in Eagle Ford Shale and Montney.
In Western Canada, our natural gas production from the Montney in second quarter was 192 million cubic feet per day. Our new completion designs continue to deliver strong well performance, with EURs now in the 8 to 10 Bcf range, well ahead of the original Montney sanctions that call for 4 Bcf per well. We have a refracked pilot underway on some of the older wells at Tupper and have an inventory of 9 previously drilled wells and are currently completing 5 of them to maintain production rates and keep unit operating expenses low.
At Seal, we continue to progress our long-term commercial steam project. Regulatory applications for Central Thermal Project were submitted in quarter 1 this year, and we recently sanctioned feed work for the project. We're seeing some positive results from primary production from multilateral horizontal wells and have running room in that area.
In Eagle Ford Shale, second quarter 2015 production was comprised of 9% liquids, averaging near 60,800 barrels equivalent per day. As planned, we continue to operate 4 rigs and 2 completion spreads, and the current plan is to stay at that level of activity for the rest of the year. We brought 36 wells, new wells online in the second quarter and have brought on near 60% of our total estimated wells for the year in the first half. We're planning on delivering 36 wells in quarter 3 and 25 wells in quarter 4, with the program being front-end loaded as per guidance and plans.
Production in the third quarter of 2015 is estimated to be near 60,000 equivalents per day, with the 2015 full year outlook not expected to exceed 59,000, some 2,000 barrel equivalents a day ahead of our annual production for 2014.
We continue to optimize our frac designs and are seeing strong results from recent super slick completions in the Karnes and Tilden areas. We have now begun a new trial of high intensity completions with larger sand volumes and tighter stage spacing. Like any major oil field, we're always searching for additional productive zones. We're assessing the potential of the Austin Chalk play in our Eagle Ford Shale acreage. We have begun a three-well appraisal plan in the play, with the first well coming online in October.
Our current assessment shows a minimum of 70 Austin Chalk locations in the Karnes area, with potential for additional locations depending on the results of this appraisal.
Murphy is well-positioned in the Eagle Ford Shale, with our oil-weighted production mix compared to many peers. Our limited exposure to lower NGL and natural gas prices gives us leverage in an oil price recovery. Murphy's well ramp-up strategy focuses on maximizing value by balancing early production rates with ultimate recovery. This strategy has led Murphy to have one of the highest levels of 2-year recovery per well across the play.
The Eagle Ford Shale is a valuable asset within our portfolio. The value of Eagle Ford to Murphy is enhanced by our early ground floor entry in the play. We have over 2,000 potential well locations remaining. We now estimate the total resource at near 750 million barrels equivalent, which is very similar to the entire reserve base of Murphy today. Needless to say, the field's going very, very well for us.
In Malaysia in the second quarter, we completed a five-well drilling program for natural gas at the Belum field and shallow water offshore Sarawak. The Belum field has low nitrogen content that will blend into our current gas production, allow us to derisk our 250 million per day contractual volume on demand going forward. We're currently drilling oil wells in the Permas shallow water development, and this operation's going well, with costs trending 20% under budget.
Sarawak gas production for the second quarter was 111 million cubic feet per day net, supported by strong gas nominations and liquid production at near 14,700 barrels of oil per day.
We successfully completed the planned outage in early second quarter at our Sarawak facilities to complete required inspections and major maintenance. 
Production offshore Sabah, averaging 30,900-barrel equivalents per day for the second quarter with 85% liquids. Planned maintenance activities at Kakap-Gumusut main facility to install gas handling and injection system commenced on June 9 and have recently been completed.
Earlier this month, we had a gas discovery at Permai exploration well in Block H, where we operate the well with 42% working interest, our eighth consecutive success in the area around that field.
This 200-plus Bcf discovery will allow optimization of the Floating LNG project and lower our development costs.
In the Gulf of Mexico, production for the quarter was over 22,900 barrel equivalents per day with 61% liquids. The Medusa two-well expansion achieved first oil in the second quarter, with the wells starting up late April and mid-June, respectively. We've exceeded our projected daily volumes and beat our scheduled targets. Field development work at the nonoperating Kodiak project continues, where the first of 2 wells have been drilled and completed to plan and modification of top-sub [ph] facilities and subsea executions underway.
The Sea Eagle prospect in Mississippi Canyon Block 692 failed to encounter commercial quantities of hydrocarbon and will be expensed as a dry hole. The well, which we operated with a 35% working interest, was not included in our second quarter guidance, as it was expected to reach total depth in the third quarter. Our drilling operations team completed the well 30 days ahead of schedule and $25 million gross under budget.
We have expanded into a new area in the Gulf of Mexico with our entry to the Wilcox play through a 20% working interest ground floor farm-in into the nonoperated Solomon prospect and Walker Ridge Block 225. The well has a gross pre-drill estimate of over 300 million barrels.
Looking at our drilling program for the rest of 2015 in the Gulf of Mexico, the Solomon well, which is currently projected to reach total depth sometime near the end of third quarter or early fourth quarter, has been included in our dry hole exposure for the third quarter.
BlackRhino has moved into a drill at lower risk prospect at Dalmatian South #2. The Transocean Discoverer Deep Seas is expected to complete required inspections by the middle of August, and is slated to sidetrack the Thunder Bird discovery, which will be a subsea tieback to our nearby Thunder Hawk facility.
Recognizing our lack of exploration success, we plan to focus rig commitments on our lower-risk appraisal wells and blocks where we have had prior exploration success. We'll allocate capital to higher return opportunities near existing infrastructure and not invest further in higher risk, higher cost wells at this time.
In Malaysia, we will focus on our gas discovery at Permai and deepwater Block H, with 2 shallow water oil prospects, Merapuh 5 and Marakas in Block SK 314A, adjacent to our very successful Sarawak oil and gas developments.
Later in the quarter, we will drill the Paus East in Block SK 2C offshore Sarawak. This well is near our prior discovery on the block and is located in our new focus areas. We plan to finish off the year with a nonoperated appraisal of our gas discoveries in Brunei. Our firm well commitments through 2016 are primarily in Malaysia, Brunei and Vietnam, which is one of our focus areas with lower cost exploration. Post 2016, we have only one required well commitment in the entire company, and an estimated net cost of only $4 million. We'll have capital allocation options for exploration in 2016 and beyond as we have worked off commitments made in prior years. 
We, like all deepwater operators, have deepwater rig commitments. The end of our rig commitments with the BlackRhino and Discoverer Deep Seas are expiring in February and November 2016, respectively.
Production for the third quarter is estimated to be 200,000 equivalents per day. We've increased our full year production guidance with the range of 200,000 to 208,000 barrel equivalents per day. Capital expenditures remain unchanged from our previous guidance and are currently forecast to be $2.3 billion in 2015.
Murphy Oil has returned significant value to its shareholders over the last 6 years through regular dividends, a special dividend, the spin-off of Murphy U.S.A. and share repurchases. Our strong balance sheet supports the current regular dividend and allows the company to carry out its capital programs and review opportunities.
At current prices, our dividend yield is near 4% above industry peer average. Share repurchases since 2012 have acquired our own proved reserves below our F&D cost and competitive to other acquisitions. While many companies are issuing equity or taking major impairments on their assets, Murphy, through its conservative nature, has been able to avoid significant write-downs in the business.
As takeaways today, our strong operational performance this year has allowed us to increase our production guidance for the year while staying within our capital spending budget. Our oil-weighted price advantage portfolio provides us with cash flow per BOE benefit over many of our peers. We're driving cost lower in our business through cost reductions and efficiency improvements in both our offshore and onshore segments. Our conservative balance sheet is a positive for us in the second price collapse in 9 months, and allows Murphy to maintain a continued focus on our shareholders, carry out capital programs and look for opportunities to improve our company going forward.
We'll now take your questions. Thank you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Leo Mariani with RBC.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Leo Mariani with RBC.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a longer-term question here on exploration. Obviously, you guys are sort of winding down some of the activity, it sounds like you'll have some activity next year as well, and minimal commitments. Are you guys considering replacing that, exploration c
componenttext: Just a longer-term question here on exploration. Obviously, you guys are sort of winding down some of the activity, it sounds like you'll have some activity next year as well, and minimal commitments. Are you guys considering replacing that, exploration component of the budget longer term, as we get out into 2017, '18, with acquisitions or onshore leasing, or how should we think about the strategy shift here?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think, the results, Leo, as you know, are not where we want to be, and we got back into the Gulf here and had 3 unsuccessful wells in a row that's leading us to take a pause there. We're not stopping exploration around the world, we're tak
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think, the results, Leo, as you know, are not where we want to be, and we got back into the Gulf here and had 3 unsuccessful wells in a row that's leading us to take a pause there. We're not stopping exploration around the world, we're taking a pause in the drilling to -- we can replenish that portfolio and make sure these investments, make sure the partners we're in and what type of wells, where will cost go, I think drilling rig costs will come down, and a pause here is warranted. It also, though, as you brought up, does allow us many capital allocation advantages, whether we would consider M&A in lieu of exploration, would we consider a component of production and exploration from that company? And I like to think of it as another price collapse coming, another budget year coming, not the success I needed, less commitments, very significantly low commitments in '17, practically none. And I think it just gives us an advantage to regroup and allows us capital allocation across the spectrum there.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And could you elaborate a little bit more on acquisitions? You guys still looking at sort of offshore Gulf of Mexico and kind of onshore oily stuff?
componenttext: Okay. And could you elaborate a little bit more on acquisitions? You guys still looking at sort of offshore Gulf of Mexico and kind of onshore oily stuff?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that would be fair. That would be fair. Probably not north of Oklahoma and Gulf of Mexico is still a place. Our unique strategy of offshore and onshore allows us to look at both. We have the ability to operate in both. And we look at many opportuniti
componenttext: Yes, that would be fair. That would be fair. Probably not north of Oklahoma and Gulf of Mexico is still a place. Our unique strategy of offshore and onshore allows us to look at both. We have the ability to operate in both. And we look at many opportunities, but we like to have a bit of return and strip up pricing, Leo. We're not interested in doing it for storing [ph].

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess with respect to your comment about moving some of the deepwater drilling to kind of lower risk opportunities, you had talked about sidetrack kind of offset at Dalmatian and also some work at Thunder Bird. Are those just kind of -- are th
componenttext: Okay. And I guess with respect to your comment about moving some of the deepwater drilling to kind of lower risk opportunities, you had talked about sidetrack kind of offset at Dalmatian and also some work at Thunder Bird. Are those just kind of -- are those kind of one-off well opportunities there? Is there more inventory behind that in the next few years?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's about 3 opportunities near Dalmatian that are like a F&D around $15 and have $40 to $50 breakeven, full life cycle, 10% rate of return. So consider those very good. It allows us to take a pause in the really expensive deep exploration wells for a
componenttext: There's about 3 opportunities near Dalmatian that are like a F&D around $15 and have $40 to $50 breakeven, full life cycle, 10% rate of return. So consider those very good. It allows us to take a pause in the really expensive deep exploration wells for a while until those costs come down further, it allows the regrouping of our partnering and our data and our total review of that business. I like these opportunities a lot. They're very accretive economically to us. We've seen a lot of success here with Medusa subsea expansion. We're going to have a nice success at Kodiak from an entry we made into that project and Dalmatian's been successful. So these have been around, and we have allocated capital to some exploration, and now we're reviewing that and putting our capital into these projects that fit in well with a low price environment in my view.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. And I guess, you've kind of outlined your exploration commitment in 2016. We've got some obligation wells and your deepwater rigs are going to roll off, I guess, in February, November. You threw out the dollar number in 2017, $4 million. Is the
componenttext: All right. And I guess, you've kind of outlined your exploration commitment in 2016. We've got some obligation wells and your deepwater rigs are going to roll off, I guess, in February, November. You threw out the dollar number in 2017, $4 million. Is there a dollar number for '16 on exploration?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's on that slide in our deck today. I think it's a little over 100 today for the wells that we need to drill with national oil companies. Some of these are very nice wells to drill in shallow water Sarawak, Malaysia. There's some further commitment well
componenttext: It's on that slide in our deck today. I think it's a little over 100 today for the wells that we need to drill with national oil companies. Some of these are very nice wells to drill in shallow water Sarawak, Malaysia. There's some further commitment wells in Block H, where we've been very, very successful. There's some commitment wells further in Brunei where we've had success. So I don't consider it a very high risk program. At this time, it gives us a lot of flexibility in our CapEx for '16 and enormous flexibility in '17.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Guy Baber with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Guy Baber with Simmons & Company.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Roger, you made an interesting comment that you see improved returns ahead in the deepwater. I believe you've mentioned before that you hadn't been seeing a lot of deflation offshore, so I was just hoping for an update on the deflation side, and then some
componenttext: Roger, you made an interesting comment that you see improved returns ahead in the deepwater. I believe you've mentioned before that you hadn't been seeing a lot of deflation offshore, so I was just hoping for an update on the deflation side, and then some more detail behind your comments calling for better returns. How much of that is due to self-help and Murphy getting more efficient? How much is due to what you're seeing on the macro side from a deflationary perspective? And then does that change the way you plan to allocate capital at all?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, like I said, from a capital allocation exploration perspective, we have these wells that were just asked about by Leo here, about some lower breakeven price wells that we can take a pause in exploration, which I think is nice, especially when rig ra
componenttext: Well, like I said, from a capital allocation exploration perspective, we have these wells that were just asked about by Leo here, about some lower breakeven price wells that we can take a pause in exploration, which I think is nice, especially when rig rates are high. I'm a deepwater person. I've been in deepwater my whole career, I understand the business fairly well. It's really a days business, more than a vendor cost-reduction business, where the onshore is a lot about vendor time and efficiency. But offshore is a day business. And I was a big believer in these big sixth-generation rigs, I thought they were too complex, too big, too much going on. I visited the one we had. It's one of the best wells I've ever seen in my career. And if we get that kind of performance to reduce these days, with all the subsea handling and the off-line work that these rigs can do, and you put that with lower day rates for these rigs, I'm absolutely certain that's going to lead to better returns, that's going to fit in better with our pause in exploration, the kind of wells we can get into out in the '17, '18 time frame, after we have the appropriate recalibration of our work in that effort.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Very helpful. And then I had a couple of CapEx questions. But you all have done a great job in keeping the CapEx down obviously, and then with the lower pace of completions in Eagle Ford over the back half of the year, I'm just wanting to und
componenttext: Okay, great. Very helpful. And then I had a couple of CapEx questions. But you all have done a great job in keeping the CapEx down obviously, and then with the lower pace of completions in Eagle Ford over the back half of the year, I'm just wanting to understand if there's perhaps downside to the existing capital spending guidance for this year or if we're missing something and perhaps there are increases internationally or elsewhere that we're not fully appreciating? And then as you think about 2016, understanding that it's early and that the macro environment is fluid, can you help us just kind of understand the framework as we try to gauge our expectations for 2016 CapEx, perhaps what the moving parts are, if there's anything going on internationally, moving one way or the other, and how your thinking about Eagle Ford and the 4-rig program going into 2016?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Golly, Guy, that's a lot of stuff there. I was wondering how long it would take for someone to get to '16. We've only been 10 minutes. First, on your first question, our CapEx is pretty firm where we are. It could be down slightly, but I can tell you they
componenttext: Golly, Guy, that's a lot of stuff there. I was wondering how long it would take for someone to get to '16. We've only been 10 minutes. First, on your first question, our CapEx is pretty firm where we are. It could be down slightly, but I can tell you they're doing everything not to increase it at all, especially with the latest price. The Eagle Ford Shale is doing very, very well for us. We are probably going to end the year with a little bigger inventory than we normally carry at Murphy, and we'll probably be looking at the typical front-end loading again next year. And we would have optionality there if the Eagle Ford continues to be efficient as it has been, did we want to use some of that to maintain our CapEx. That would be harder to do with prices low like this, but we feel comfortable with our guidance and our CapEx, and I would say it's slightly downward, but I'm not anticipating that to be that big. From a 2016 perspective, of course, that's very difficult to answer today. We were dealing a couple of months ago with a $65, $66 WTI in our business. We were, at that time, forecasting CapEx to be lower than we have this year, slightly lower. We're now looking at a $50 case, a lower case, if you will. I think it's a misnomer that our CapEx will be very high in that case. And as I look at it today, I don't have the breakout around the world in looking at a total cash flow CapEx perspective. And the way I look at this, and the reductions of that type of $50 case would cause, is that our debt levels as to our revolver -- we have $2.25 billion of bonds and we have a $2 billion revolver -- we would stay inside our revolver levels without repatriation of cash abroad, which we have cash, of course, in Canada, Malaysia, complex and timely oriented to repatriate that money that gives us optionality. And we're allowed to maintain our dividend, lower CapEx below this year and survive at a $50 world without changing, really, almost the debt levels that Murphy has today. So happy about that, and really not offering a lot more color than that at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: CapEx is a key issue for everyone as you go into next year, but I'll wait for your update and we'll see what prices do. You mentioned midstream assets, EBITDA for those? And how you monetize it?
componenttext: CapEx is a key issue for everyone as you go into next year, but I'll wait for your update and we'll see what prices do. You mentioned midstream assets, EBITDA for those? And how you monetize it?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't have it and -- I have it, but I'm not talking about the EBITDA right now with you. I mean, it would be a similar multiple that you would see, but I've seen nice multiples in that business. And when you see nice multiples and things happening, Murp
componenttext: I don't have it and -- I have it, but I'm not talking about the EBITDA right now with you. I mean, it would be a similar multiple that you would see, but I've seen nice multiples in that business. And when you see nice multiples and things happening, Murphy -- if you see other people doing things with nice multiples, we have it too here. So we have a very nice gas plant situation in Montney and great infrastructure there. It's very high uptime, an incredible asset. We also have many oil facilities in Eagle Ford Shale and we're contacted from time to time for our spars and pipelines that we own in Gulf of Mexico. So those typical multiples you would see would cause other things and would be similar to us and we're intrigued by this and are reviewing.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think, it makes sense to get cash in the door in these types of environment, because you'd certainly be able to do something with it. Just -- you mentioned the gas pumped up in the Montney and good reliability, I mean, obviously, along with
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think, it makes sense to get cash in the door in these types of environment, because you'd certainly be able to do something with it. Just -- you mentioned the gas pumped up in the Montney and good reliability, I mean, obviously, along with that is where do you reckon your acreage in the Montney now competes in terms of gas price, breakeven?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's still a tough business for us. It's an incredibly operated facility and managed facility. We've doubled our sanctioned Bcf there per well. It's going very well for us in that perspective, very disciplined. I guess AECO today is CAD 2.40, CAD 2.
componenttext: Well, it's still a tough business for us. It's an incredibly operated facility and managed facility. We've doubled our sanctioned Bcf there per well. It's going very well for us in that perspective, very disciplined. I guess AECO today is CAD 2.40, CAD 2.50, that's at our breakeven 10% return. You get caught in a situation where if you do not drill some level of wells, you allow -- production goes down and that impacts the OpEx. We do have some of our production sold, for lack of a better word, to others that use our facility. And that's the kind of economics we're in, and that's why this sale of a midstream would add return on capital employed to a situation that we would swap DD&A for OpEx commitment, if you will, bring that EBITDA forward. Also though, on a macro basis, I mean, we do still have LNG around the United States and exporting and what will that do to the big gas picture, what will happen to the LNG off the West Coast there on both Canadian and U.S. sides. And from a long-term macro perspective, when I first went to Malaysia in 1999, I was told we'd never sell gas in the gas system to Petronas. And I think we sold them 304 million a day today there. So there's a big LNG machine there that's being built, they don't have everything organized on it, but will that be an optionality for us one day? You never know, Ed.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a small question around the Eagle Ford. I mean, obviously, running 4 rigs, you can see from your charts that you would build a bit of inventory towards year end. But what sort of -- if you ran that level through next year, what kind of prod
componenttext: Okay. And then a small question around the Eagle Ford. I mean, obviously, running 4 rigs, you can see from your charts that you would build a bit of inventory towards year end. But what sort of -- if you ran that level through next year, what kind of production do you think you'd get from the Eagle Ford?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're just not ready to say. We originally thought we'd have to go to 6 rigs to maintain it. It's probably a little less than that now. Probably with prices that they are, we won't be able to do that. Some would say we should cut back some of our rigs now
componenttext: We're just not ready to say. We originally thought we'd have to go to 6 rigs to maintain it. It's probably a little less than that now. Probably with prices that they are, we won't be able to do that. Some would say we should cut back some of our rigs now and protect CapEx there, but I feel that a 4-rig, 2-spread deal is really, really working well for us, and there's some level of size to be in the game to continue with the incredible efficiency. So that's where we are now and see how many of these inventory wells we've drilled, see what our options are. A little early in the game to say production in Eagle Ford in August, but looking pretty good.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question, you guys decided to retain the second frac crew in Eagle Ford. I mean, is that a function of higher number of wells drilled due to drilling efficiencies and a desire not to build DUCs? Is that what drove that retention?
componenttext: My first question, you guys decided to retain the second frac crew in Eagle Ford. I mean, is that a function of higher number of wells drilled due to drilling efficiencies and a desire not to build DUCs? Is that what drove that retention?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So our CapEx there has been a little over $800 million all year, our efficiencies are going very well and I just got off the phone here with Ed, we're just building up a little higher inventory than we normally keep. That's even with the 2 frac spreads. S
componenttext: So our CapEx there has been a little over $800 million all year, our efficiencies are going very well and I just got off the phone here with Ed, we're just building up a little higher inventory than we normally keep. That's even with the 2 frac spreads. So the drilling is going really well for us there. We have different parts of the play, some drill faster than others, all of which are coming down below $5 million for D&C cost normalized across the field. Just maintaining our CapEx and having slightly higher production for the year. I think that's a good story. And I think I have some worry about dropping things and losing the efficiency gains ahead. And as I've said far back earlier in the questions here today, I think the offshore business is a days business, but there have been enormous savings from the vendors in the onshore business. So the cost for that equipment's cheaper, of course, than it was last year and the year before. And I just feel real comfortable with our team makeup and size and efficiency and machine we got rolling down there right now.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. That makes sense. I mean, in the Eagle Ford, do you have any kind of breakdown on the economics on your 2,000 locations? I mean, would you consider them economic on the strip or any kind of breakdown as you think about that?
componenttext: Great. That makes sense. I mean, in the Eagle Ford, do you have any kind of breakdown on the economics on your 2,000 locations? I mean, would you consider them economic on the strip or any kind of breakdown as you think about that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, going forward, economics, we got no trouble in today's prices in Eagle Ford Shale on anything we have, because we're on old player, not an NGL player at all, not a gas player or condensate player there. So that's not the issue. I think to get full o
componenttext: Well, going forward, economics, we got no trouble in today's prices in Eagle Ford Shale on anything we have, because we're on old player, not an NGL player at all, not a gas player or condensate player there. So that's not the issue. I think to get full on in income across your G&A and your amortization of leases, et cetera, et cetera, it's in the above $55 level. We're not far away from there, but the costs are getting better. We're starting to have some very high rates come out of some wells in these larger completions, even with our choking techniques that we have, which should lead to some higher EUR in some of the layers and lowering DD&A, and we have this Austin Chalk opportunity, so just kind of a macro thing looking pretty good and if -- the main point is if you think everybody else is looking good, mine's looking good, too.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's right. I was just questioning across all the locations, if that was the case.
componenttext: That's right. I was just questioning across all the locations, if that was the case.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not worried so much about that today.
componenttext: I'm not worried so much about that today.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sounds good. I mean, just one other question, if I could. You guys, you completed accelerated buyback in the quarter for $250 million, you've got more authorized, ample balance sheet. Can you just talk about your decision making process there for fur
componenttext: Yes, sounds good. I mean, just one other question, if I could. You guys, you completed accelerated buyback in the quarter for $250 million, you've got more authorized, ample balance sheet. Can you just talk about your decision making process there for further buybacks as you look at the different opportunities you have, as well as your funding?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we do have another $250 million available to us. It is sometimes nice, in my mind, to take some off the table at these low prices, especially when it gets down below some recent announced M&A, and we all know what those M&A deals are in onshore, esp
componenttext: Well, we do have another $250 million available to us. It is sometimes nice, in my mind, to take some off the table at these low prices, especially when it gets down below some recent announced M&A, and we all know what those M&A deals are in onshore, especially, which are heavy P2-related, and we're a heavy oil BOE outfit. It is a nice thing to do occasionally, and it's one of the things we're considering as we maintain our CapEx this year and get into next year, do we want to do that, and we do have an ample balance sheet to do it. You're absolutely correct. And it is something that's constantly reviewed with our board here at Murphy and my executive team.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I could slip one more, if I could. I know you guys recently had been in the shallow round for Mexico with partner. I mean, any kind of color on how that process and opportunity played out? And are there any other readthroughs as you think about a
componenttext: Maybe if I could slip one more, if I could. I know you guys recently had been in the shallow round for Mexico with partner. I mean, any kind of color on how that process and opportunity played out? And are there any other readthroughs as you think about an eventual deepwater round or is that related to kind of your reduction comments on offshore before?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're, like I said, taking a pause from the real deep subsalt Miocene expensive wells in the Gulf post what we have committed to right now, and of course, this Solomon well we've committed to, took many, many months to negotiate with our partner there, wh
componenttext: We're, like I said, taking a pause from the real deep subsalt Miocene expensive wells in the Gulf post what we have committed to right now, and of course, this Solomon well we've committed to, took many, many months to negotiate with our partner there, which we're pleased with that outcome. We were looking at shallow water Mexico and thought of it like a shallow water Malaysia play, it's very underexplored, a nice place to work. We're trying to focus back into Houston with lower G&A and less -- West Africa, less international formed [ph], that, of course, is international, being run out of Houston. We participated, it was a situation there where you bid various work programs and economic parts of the bid. As part of that, the government then released their minimum government take after the bids were submitted, and we were slightly below what they requested. So therefore, our bid didn't work out, and it didn't work out. And there are many bid rounds ahead there, there's deepwater coming. I think it's a very underexplored, nice place to work if you're concentrating people and cost into the Gulf of Mexico, it will be something out in time for well commitments for us, where we have virtually 0. So it wouldn't be a big issue to capital if oil prices were to stay down lower longer. So I like the timing of it, I like the underexplored nature of it, but it didn't work out that time. And we're going to review it going forward, like we do other low-cost drilling opportunities internationally.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Roger Read with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Roger Read with Wells Fargo.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd like to ask you a little more on the acquisition front. About this time last year, when the sale of the Malaysian assets was announced, expectation was a redeployment. Now I recognize quite a lot of things have changed since this time last yea
componenttext: I guess I'd like to ask you a little more on the acquisition front. About this time last year, when the sale of the Malaysian assets was announced, expectation was a redeployment. Now I recognize quite a lot of things have changed since this time last year. You mentioned south of Oklahoma, but maybe you could talk a little bit about just how things are moving from a sort of a bid-ask spread standpoint, I mean, with this double dip move here in crude prices?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, you're right, and we've looked at a lot of opportunities here and we look at 3 or 4 all the time in both offshore and onshore all the time here. So we have a big team working on this, we're very interested, and we monitor it very closely. An
componenttext: Well, I mean, you're right, and we've looked at a lot of opportunities here and we look at 3 or 4 all the time in both offshore and onshore all the time here. So we have a big team working on this, we're very interested, and we monitor it very closely. And the way to think about Murphy in that world is we have a strip price rate of return minimum of what we would like, and we have a post-oil price recovery rate of return we would like. And if we can't get that strip price rate of return we like, then we're going to be unsuccessful, and I think that early on, just a timing issue. We had a very nice hedging of oil for our shareholders at Murphy with the sell down in Malaysia. Then we come into a collapse in prices cumulating last Thanksgiving. And then we never saw the bid-ask spread organized for us to participate at that time, and here we are again with another collapse again, or a lot of volatility, a lot of noise around the mid-40s and things of that nature. And will that bid-ask spread be worked closer this time around, I would say, yes, I hope so. But we're not interested in taking on the sell down in Malaysia and also our balance sheet, which is very strong. We have a lot of ample room there, to all of our peers. We're not interested in doing this unless we get the return we need there, Roger. And that's kind of where that is right now, but we're very active in the plays.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks. And I guess as a follow-up on that and Evan's question about the share repurchases. Granted, a large enough transaction, you're probably willing to use equity as well as cash and debt. But should we think about anything you do as putting more of t
componenttext: Thanks. And I guess as a follow-up on that and Evan's question about the share repurchases. Granted, a large enough transaction, you're probably willing to use equity as well as cash and debt. But should we think about anything you do as putting more of the balance sheet in play and not putting equity to work at this point?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would hate to fence myself in on one way or another. We pride ourselves of being a company that hasn't offered equity since our initial public offering in 1956. So we're not a big believer in that. I prefer not to do it that way. And I think it matters
componenttext: I would hate to fence myself in on one way or another. We pride ourselves of being a company that hasn't offered equity since our initial public offering in 1956. So we're not a big believer in that. I prefer not to do it that way. And I think it matters a lot on who you're working with on the other side of the transaction. Are they private equity-backed and would like cash? Are they a shareholder of some type of merger, then maybe they would like shares. And what has happened to that as to debt or certain situations there in that onshore and both offshore businesses and I think each deal is different. We'd hate to say you would never use it, but we'd prefer not to, Roger.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Going back to the exploration, just to summarize, do you view the exploration prospects as not where you want to be to, the exploration strategy as not where you want to be or both, i.e. is it just a matter of replenishing the prospect inventory or is it
componenttext: Going back to the exploration, just to summarize, do you view the exploration prospects as not where you want to be to, the exploration strategy as not where you want to be or both, i.e. is it just a matter of replenishing the prospect inventory or is it bigger than that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have to take a pause and replenish our portfolio into wells that are moving up. And we have a detailed capital allocation process here, where we rank every opportunity in the breakeven oil pricing, NPV over I, et cetera, risk NPV and net gain. We need
componenttext: We have to take a pause and replenish our portfolio into wells that are moving up. And we have a detailed capital allocation process here, where we rank every opportunity in the breakeven oil pricing, NPV over I, et cetera, risk NPV and net gain. We need to take another look at all the technical work that we've done and all the prospects that we have and farm-in opportunities, our data sets, and take a pause in the Gulf of Mexico because today, with the rigs that we have, the wells are very expensive and we haven't done well like we need to do and we have to take a break in that business. We, at Murphy, do have a very diverse portfolio and business. We have some very low-cost wells. This discovery in Block H Malaysia probably costs $15 million gross or something like that. You can drill $40-million deepwater wells in Malaysia, where we've been very successful. But the wells in the Gulf of Mexico are very expensive. And we're not having the results I would like and I think it's a replenishment, a total relook at staff, processes and data and where we are, more than just a -- where our prospects are, Brian.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the Eagle Ford, as a percent of the total, you have some of the most oilier Eagle Ford out there. One thing we have noticed is that the percent oil from a very, very high base has been coming down slightly, and just wondered particularly
componenttext: Okay. And then on the Eagle Ford, as a percent of the total, you have some of the most oilier Eagle Ford out there. One thing we have noticed is that the percent oil from a very, very high base has been coming down slightly, and just wondered particularly as the rig count falls, if you have any projections or what you're thinking about the oiliness and if it kind of goes back to the 80%, 82% range or if it keeps coming down?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's only because we're gathering and capturing more gas. We had a lot of gas flaring when we early started as per emission standards in the State of Texas. But we now have hardly any gas flaring across all of that play with hundreds and hundreds of
componenttext: Well, it's only because we're gathering and capturing more gas. We had a lot of gas flaring when we early started as per emission standards in the State of Texas. But we now have hardly any gas flaring across all of that play with hundreds and hundreds of wells. It's so oily, Brian, that even you are going to have to start liking it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. I mean, one of the questions is certainly is does the gas rate and the mix start to go up over time? But your point is that you're not seeing it and you're not expecting it?
componenttext: That's great. I mean, one of the questions is certainly is does the gas rate and the mix start to go up over time? But your point is that you're not seeing it and you're not expecting it?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, and Brian, we got a long way to go to get to some of your favorites.
componenttext: No, and Brian, we got a long way to go to get to some of your favorites.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So maybe a high level one on strategy. You mentioned in the presentation that the remaining levers, the levers that remain on the portfolio adjustment. If you take a high look at your current portfolio, you've done a great job executing on the current ass
componenttext: So maybe a high level one on strategy. You mentioned in the presentation that the remaining levers, the levers that remain on the portfolio adjustment. If you take a high look at your current portfolio, you've done a great job executing on the current assets. But when you look at the portfolio in kind of a moderate crude world, is the portfolio weight what it needs to be or what you want it to be? What sort of levers outside of a potential acquisition is there? Or is there a larger restructuring or something that needs to take place to be competitive in a low to moderate crude price environment?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're a company that is doing okay in that environment. Our balance sheet and our oily nature, our cash flow for BOE is very good. And a real misnomer about Murphy is that our R/P collapses without exploration. That's not true. It's flat for a long,
componenttext: Well, we're a company that is doing okay in that environment. Our balance sheet and our oily nature, our cash flow for BOE is very good. And a real misnomer about Murphy is that our R/P collapses without exploration. That's not true. It's flat for a long, long time. It's never going to be the leader, but it's very, very highly acceptable from a cash flow BOE basis. As you would look at our onshore business, for example, you would find things that would be an outlier, primarily in Canada. And do we want to look at some of those assets, I've talked about some of that before publicly. But when you have another price collapse and 2 in a few months, it's difficult, the bid-ask spread for selling is as difficult as the bid-ask spread for buying. So I think that we have to continue to execute and look at what we have and take on the opportunities, when opportunities come, with our balance sheet, and do we need to then do things post that to get the portfolio in a more concentrated pure play basis, I think would be best. But again, not interested in just doing that for the sake of doing it at this time and probably won't. So I guess that answers your question, Ryan.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then maybe on the -- one more on the Eagle Ford. You guys have had great performance up to this point. You've been beating numbers. The outperformance that we've seen up to this point, is that largely a function of additional com
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then maybe on the -- one more on the Eagle Ford. You guys have had great performance up to this point. You've been beating numbers. The outperformance that we've seen up to this point, is that largely a function of additional completions? Is it better well performance, some combination of both? And maybe could you talk a little bit more in terms of potential for what you're seeing on improved well performance and some of the potential for additional resource and stacked plays and stuff?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're hitting on all cylinders there. We're very pleased with our EUR per wells is probably looking to increase in certain areas if we just get data on these new completions. Higher sand concentration completions are basically what they are, no matt
componenttext: Well, we're hitting on all cylinders there. We're very pleased with our EUR per wells is probably looking to increase in certain areas if we just get data on these new completions. Higher sand concentration completions are basically what they are, no matter what the fancy name is. With more sand, the concentrate is allowing us to open the well a little more aggressively than we have in the past, and we have a methodology around doing that with our folks there in Houston. And to maintain the same type of reservoir performance with the larger sand concentration is allowing us to have, for the first time, some really name-brand type of rate without having the well in massive decline, as you would see from some of our peers. That's supported by this 2-year production data advantage that Murphy carries forward. So we're pleased with that, I think that's something that our new data and our new fracs are just coming in. We are obviously doing very well in the Upper Eagle Ford situation there. We, like all players in that field, that massive field, have data that shows upper wells going along with lower wells. We have all those slides, and we have that too. It's going well for us. Our Catarina areas are flatter, longer than we originally thought. Very cheap drilling out in that part. Very -- from a capital allocation, just up there with Karnes. A totally different type of EUR shape, but very economic. So doing really well there, Upper Eagle Ford, Lower Eagle Ford, stacked on top of each other, new completion design, another new completion design coming. Really doing well down there, Ryan.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. And are you guys testing -- are you testing the spacing at all, or do you feel like you've downspaced about as far as you potentially can at this point?
componenttext: That's great. And are you guys testing -- are you testing the spacing at all, or do you feel like you've downspaced about as far as you potentially can at this point?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, when you're across a big play like us, and you're an oil player like us and you have various things to invest there, we haven't gotten below the 40s. We consider 40 pretty standard, and I think there's a lot of data around 40, and we're in that type o
componenttext: No, when you're across a big play like us, and you're an oil player like us and you have various things to invest there, we haven't gotten below the 40s. We consider 40 pretty standard, and I think there's a lot of data around 40, and we're in that type of development mode. And I guess you would say it's 20s if you 40s on top of each other. And we have some of that going on, not a lot, but when we do, the wells produce as you anticipate and we're pleased with those results. We don't have a negative pulldown of any kind going on in the Eagle Ford.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Cheng with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Cheng with Barclays.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Several quick questions. Sounds like in your exploration program, you're just taking a pause and you still believe the company, at the core, is an international explorer. Is that a fair characterization of the company?
componenttext: Several quick questions. Sounds like in your exploration program, you're just taking a pause and you still believe the company, at the core, is an international explorer. Is that a fair characterization of the company?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's fair, Paul. But I believe today, that we will be continuing to focus down more in the Gulf of Mexico, East Coast of Canada, where we would have tax benefits from international exploration, a very big focus area between Sarawak and Sabah, Malaysia a
componenttext: That's fair, Paul. But I believe today, that we will be continuing to focus down more in the Gulf of Mexico, East Coast of Canada, where we would have tax benefits from international exploration, a very big focus area between Sarawak and Sabah, Malaysia all the way to Vietnam. Have a big office in KL, and have an advantage on G&A and cost of exploration. I think you will consider a major pause in the real expensive wells in the Gulf as we recalibrate going forward, and a continuing focus down, knowing more about less areas. And in the past, I felt that we knew less about more areas, and we're getting totally away from that concept. So what you say, yes, but in a different way.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And secondly, that I think a lot of your peers started asking the same questions: what is the right split on the capital allocation between the short cycle and the long-cycle projects or assets? Roger, where do you stand on that? What do you think i
componenttext: Okay. And secondly, that I think a lot of your peers started asking the same questions: what is the right split on the capital allocation between the short cycle and the long-cycle projects or assets? Roger, where do you stand on that? What do you think is the proper split for Murphy?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've -- this year, we've been about $2.3 billion CapEx, $800 million, close to $900 million, in Eagle Ford, and we had about $300 million for exploration, I suppose, and the rest has to do with timing of various offshore projects in Malaysia and of
componenttext: Well, we've -- this year, we've been about $2.3 billion CapEx, $800 million, close to $900 million, in Eagle Ford, and we had about $300 million for exploration, I suppose, and the rest has to do with timing of various offshore projects in Malaysia and offshore Gulf. I would say the step down from that with less exploration next year and if we get in a $50 price world, we have very limited exploration next year, because like I said, we're taking a pause in that in some of the higher cost areas. So I would say that split's about the same. We're a 50-50 onshore, offshore player. We do have continued development work in Malaysia in shallow water, where we have been very successful. Our Eagle Ford is doing really well. I think it's a good story to have $800 million plus CapEx there and maintain production there. So I don't have some big significant split out and things changing there, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And in Eagle Ford, just curious, Roger. I mean, you clearly have tremendous success in the efficiency gains and everything, and they're showing in the data. Do you think that Murphy is alone or that it's way ahead of the industry trend? Or that you're see
componenttext: And in Eagle Ford, just curious, Roger. I mean, you clearly have tremendous success in the efficiency gains and everything, and they're showing in the data. Do you think that Murphy is alone or that it's way ahead of the industry trend? Or that you're seeing your peers also have that kind of success? Because it certainly makes a big difference in terms of what is the resiliency of the U.S. oil production may look like.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is true. Sometimes, I feel like we're part of the problem, we're so successful. I do see it flattening in U.S. onshore production in the last couple of months, which I think is positive for the long-term situation there. I know that when we cut back
componenttext: That is true. Sometimes, I feel like we're part of the problem, we're so successful. I do see it flattening in U.S. onshore production in the last couple of months, which I think is positive for the long-term situation there. I know that when we cut back our completed wells, we do see a decline. It is strictly from that, it's nothing to do with that well performance. So if the oil price continues here and people do have that, and I see how it impacts Murphy and we're very, very proud of our acreage and very happy with the results. It will cause less production, even though there has been efficiency. I think that we're a top quartile player in onshore. I think it shows that we built this team from scratch and can deliver. We are a very operationally-focused company. I'm very proud of that. I'm an operation-focused person. We have been successful in that play and I think we're as good as anyone in that play. And I think the misnomer, because we're not just an onshore player, that we're not a very good executor in the onshore, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, final question. Based on the comment -- 2 final questions. One, can you share with us how much is the capital you invest in the infrastructure in Eagle Ford?

componenttext: I'm not going to get too much further in '16. I would tell you, just to be straightforward with you, it's difficult for us to be cash flow/CapEx parity in a $50 world. That level of shortfall is probably not as significant as you think. We would make enormous cuts to our budget to do so, and I've already said, we're taking a pause in an expensive part of the world. And so as I said earlier, we, today, from a macro high level, haven't been -- it certainly hasn't been agreed with our board, we can keep our debt levels about -- within our revolver and have flexibility as to repatriation of a lot of cash we have abroad, Paul. And I think that's a pretty good situation if this thing goes $50 for the rest of the year and all of next year.
