componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.Please refer to the inform
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Please refer to the informational slides we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with our webcast today. 
Today's call will follow our usual format. John will begin by providing a review of third quarter 2015 financial results, and then Roger will then follow with an operational update, after which, questions will be taken. 
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussion of risk factors, see Murphy's 2014 annual report on Form 10-K on file with the SEC. Murphy takes no duty to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
I will now turn the call over to John for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly and good afternoon, everyone. Murphy Oil's consolidated results in the third quarter of 2015 were a loss of $1.6 billion, which equates to $9.26 per diluted share. That's compared to a profit of $246 million or $1.37 per diluted share a y
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly and good afternoon, everyone. Murphy Oil's consolidated results in the third quarter of 2015 were a loss of $1.6 billion, which equates to $9.26 per diluted share. That's compared to a profit of $246 million or $1.37 per diluted share a year ago. The third quarter 2015 results included non-cash property impairments of $2.3 billion, which after tax, has amounted to $1.54 million charge. These impairments were attributable to significant declines in future periods oil profits, which failed by as much as $15 per barrel at quarter end compared to 3 months earlier. The impairments were not related to reductions in the company's reported reserves. 
Adjusted earnings, which adjust our GAAP numbers for various items that affect comparability of earnings between periods, was a loss of $124 million in the third quarter of 2015, down from our profit of $205 million a year ago. This decline in adjusted earnings was primarily attributable to lower oil and natural gas sales prices in the current year. Our schedule of adjusted earnings is included as part of our earnings release, and the amounts in this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis. 
Company's average realized price for its crude oil production fell more than $43 per barrel in the third quarter compared to the prior year. This amounted to a 48% drop between periods in oil prices. Natural gas prices also were weaker in the third quarter 2015 compared to the prior year with average North American gas price realizations dropping $1.21 per Mcf or a decline of 33%. Realized natural gas prices offshore Sarawak also fell by 27%. 
Sales process continues to be soft in October, and therefore, revenues continue to be under pressure as quarter 4 2015 prices remain significantly below prices a year ago. 
The company continues to address its cost structure by aggressively reducing both operating and administrative cost. By year end 2015, we anticipate a 23% reduction in staffing levels compared to a year earlier. At December 30, 2015, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to approximately $3.3 billion, 35.6% of total capital employed, while net debt amounted to just over 25% at the end of the third quarter. 
At this time, I'll turn the call over to Roger for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Looking back at a solid operational third quarter, the following highlights standout. Our company remains in a favorable financial position with the healthy balance sheet that's flexible, take advantage of opportunities that arise both in
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Looking back at a solid operational third quarter, the following highlights standout. Our company remains in a favorable financial position with the healthy balance sheet that's flexible, take advantage of opportunities that arise both in onshore and offshore. With major pullback in oil prices, we've been able to maintain our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio at less than 1.5. Subsequent to the third quarter, we hedge for 2016, we currently have 20,000 barrels per day WTI contracts at an average price of $52 per barrel. 
On the cost side, we continued continue to make significant improvements in reducing both operating and G&A expenses on a year-to-year basis. We continue to review our portfolio as we still have many levers remaining to reposition the company going forward. We're currently reviewing the value of various midstream assets in North America. We're enthusiastic about the new area that we've recently formed into offshore Vietnam, which expanded our Vietnam footprint with a new block in a highly perspective oil-prone Cuu Long Basin. Our partnership group was successful in testing our first well and we're working to increase acreage in this carrier. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, we drilled the Dalmatian South #2. We like what we see here as it commercial hydrocarbons in 2 separate zones. Currently the well is being completed with first production expected early next year. In Malaysia, we achieved record average daily gross production for Sarawak gas at 291 million per day. In addition, we drilled the Marakas V and Marakas wells of positive results and process of evaluating both. In our onshore business, the Eagle Ford shale continues to outperform expectations where we delivered 33 new wells online in the third quarter, plus Montney production continues to be above plan. 
Our third quarter production is just over 207 500 barrel equivalents per day, and we're decreasing our 2015 annual production guidance to a range of 205,000 to 209,000 barrel equivalents per day. Over the course of the year, we've increased the midpoint of our production guidance from 201,000 barrels equivalents per day to 207,000, almost 3% increase. 
In operations, we're pleased with the ongoing efforts we're making on cost reductions. Our lease operating expenses for the third quarter 2015, excluding Syncrude, is $8.09 per BOE, showing a reduction of 23% from the third quarter of 2014. More importantly, we're posting a 45% reduction from full year 2013 on LOE. In Eagle Ford Shale, our third quarter operating expenses of just over $8 per BOE. This represents over $2 reduction from the second quarter of this year. 
On a cash margin basis, we're just over $19 per barrel equivalent in the third quarter, and our $20.28 per BOE for 9 months ended. This compares very favorably to our peers, and has been stable for Murphy for a long time due to our oil diverse portfolio. 
In production. Deposit production branch is 7,500-barrel equivalents a day for the quarter is attributable to Sarawak oil and natural gas deal is performing better, above plan performance on base decline. The eagle Ford Shale, new volume -- new well volume exceeding plan due to increased and completion performance and higher natural gas production from Montney. 
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter. Production guidance is estimated to be 199,000-barrel equivalents per day. Our third quarter actual production's higher than fourth quarter guidance due to higher risk SK natural gas nominations and planned downtime, natural well decline in the Gulf of Mexico and significant reduction in a number of completed wells in the Eagle Ford Shale. 
More importantly, we are maintaining our 2015 CapEx of $2.3 billion, some 32% below last year's level when taking to account the sale down in Malaysia. 
In Western Canada. Our natural gas production in Montney in the third quarter of 2015 was over 194 million per day. We've been successful in implementing fractured techniques from our Eagle Ford Shale work to the Montney. Our new completion zone with increased same concentrations continue to confirm our 8 to 11 Bcf EURs. Also, we continue to have positive result on our refrac pilot that is underway in some older, tougher wells. 
In Eagle Ford Shale, we're especially pleased with our results for the third quarter for production average over 63,000 barrels equivalent per day with about 33 new wells online in the third quarter, and we're planning to deliver 20 wells in the fourth for a total of 136 wells this year.  Our programs has been front-loaded as prior disclosed. Production for 2015 full year outlook is now expected to exceed 61,000 barrels equivalent per day, which is 8% above 2014 production. 
We continue adding to our total remaining resource in the play by downspacing wells, drilling longer laterals and optimizing completions, to name a few. We now estimate that our total remaining resource has grown to over 800 million barrels. And this growth even takes into account a total review of our resources from a price perspective. 
We successfully drilled our first Austin Chalk well in Collins County. Hopefully, we'll be moving this play concept westwards to our Catarina area. This will add 1/3 to word into our operand lower Eagle Ford Shale locations. We drilled the first of 3 well appraisal pilot and are currently analyzing corn logs to better understand the reservoir properties. Our current Austin Chalk appraisal well has a very successful flow rate of 1,500 barrel oil equivalent per day. We look forward to continuing to test Austin Chalk play in 2016. 
In Malaysia, we achieved record average daily gas production in Sarawak of 291 million a day. We successfully drilled 2 shallow water Sarawak oil prospects, the Merapuh 5 and Marakas wells had positive results where we're evaluating development options. These wells are in the Block SK314A area, adjacent to our successful Sarawak oil and gas developments. 
The Murphy operated Kakap-Gumusut well failed when counter commercial quantities of hydrocarbon was expensed into dry hole in the quarter. 
Offshore Vietnam, we signed a formal agreement in the shallow water 15-105 block in the prolific oil-prone Vietnam Cuu Long Basin. 2 discoveries have been made on the block. 
Murphy participated in the drilling and testing of LDP 4S well, which successfully tested 2 perspective zones. We're also working with PetroVietnam to advance our footprint into Cuu Long. This new block entry was made possible by our long-term relationship with our partner and our significant position as a successful operator in both deepwater and the shallow water in Malaysia. 
In the Gulf of Mexico, production for the quarter was over 27,200 barrel equivalents per day at 71% liquids. We spud the Dalmatian South #2-well during the quarter. We're now completing the wells we found commercial hydrocarbons with over 98 P2P in 2 zones, and we expect first production early next year. 
2 development work in the nonoperating Kodiak project continues with the first of 2 wells have been drilled and completed plant and modifications tops up facilities and subsea execution is underway. We're currently progressing the sub track of our Thunder Bird well to plan and all of our current Gulf of Mexico projects can withstand lower-for-longer prices. 
Looking at the drilling program for the fourth quarter 2015 in the Gulf, the nonoperating-ed Solomon well, which is currently projected to reach total depth sometime in the fourth quarter has been included in our dry hole exposure for the fourth quarter. We plan to finish up the year with an oil exploration well word located in Block H Malaysia with some non-operated well to appraise our oil-linked gas discoveries in Brunei. 
This time, we have 2 deepwater rigs under contract at Murphy. These contracts expire in 2016, 1 in February and the other in November. The continued low commodity prices we're experiencing an expected reduction in our 2016 CapEx program and an uncertainty about whether working interest partners will agree to participate in drilling programs, we're considering all options. Our current contractual commitments to the end of term for both rigs equals $277 million. 
In financials, Murphy has been able to maintain our investment grade BBB bond rating. We maintained our dividend policy through the year with current yield of 5%. We have $1 billion available under our current revolver. We have over $1.2 billion of cash abroad with marketable securities, and we achieved a net debt-to-EBITDA of less than 1.5. 
Production for the fourth quarter is estimated being 109,000 [ph] barrels equivalents a day. Again, we've increased our full year production guidance at the range of 205,000 to 209,000 equivalent per day. Capital expenditures remain unchanged from previous guidance, and are currently forecast to be $2.3 billion. 
To close in my comments today, I would like to leave with a few points. Murphy continues to have financial flexibility and strengths. The greatly lowered operating G&A expenses over the course of the year and cost reductions remains a priority. Our entry to the Eagle Ford Shale has been extremely successful addition to Murphy over the past few years. We've built an excellent high-performing team, now producing around 30% of our total volumes in just over 40 years. We, like most peers, continues the efficiency and cost-reduction in drilling and completion activity across all of our operating area. Our Gulf of Mexico projects generate sound economics at current prices. And over the quarter, we have participated in many positive well results from the Gulf of Mexico to shallow water Malaysia and to Vietnam and a very high rate oil test in the Austin Chalk area of Eagle Ford Shale. We continue to execute on all cylinders in a tough commodity environment. I'd like to now open it up the phone for your questions. And thank you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question for you. So softly I know, earlier in the year I know you guys talked about moving away from some of the exploration activity. I guess you guys are announcing that you're firing into a block in Vietnam here is sort of new area. I guess is
componenttext: Just a question for you. So softly I know, earlier in the year I know you guys talked about moving away from some of the exploration activity. I guess you guys are announcing that you're firing into a block in Vietnam here is sort of new area. I guess is this not really seen as sort of exploration? It sounds like there is some existing discoveries or do you guys just see this as lower risk exploration?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we see this is a little bit of both, Leo. We have had a pause in our exploration. When I say that, it's primarily related to the big $100 million-plus big wells in the Gulf of Mexico, they're very expensive, they have very high day rates. But we'r
componenttext: I think we see this is a little bit of both, Leo. We have had a pause in our exploration. When I say that, it's primarily related to the big $100 million-plus big wells in the Gulf of Mexico, they're very expensive, they have very high day rates. But we're not opposed to entering into lower risk opportunities. That was clear to us that the block did have prior discoveries. I mean, we entered into the block and participated in the delineation of both our discoveries. The delineation is going very, very well. We're very excited about it. We're talking about -- when we had -- you have 2 types of wells in the world, the big Gulf of Mexico, West Africa new entry type wells, and you have lower risk opportunities in a place like Vietnam where you can drill wells for $15 million and have a 50 million to 100 million barrel type prospects. So in that space, just from an F&D perspective, that's a very positive thing. And this is about our strategy, this is about our company. We do work internationally. We are a big major player in Malaysia. We have a strong relationship and a very strong reputation in Southeast Asia, and we're able to -- our expertise in shallow water development there and across other acreage in Vietnam, it's the reason we were able to get into this block. And it's a very favorable, but I do not consider it to be entry in a wild up place somewhere. It's very similar geology to what we're used to, very similar areas of operation, very similar cost, very similar well design, and a place where we work nearby. And it's something we're focused on in that area. I consider it not a new big wild entry into a far-off place, Leo.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have commitment wells in our business. We do not have commitments usually in the Gulf as you anticipate. So we've had these, and these are again, lower cost wells. The well on Block H has moved up in our schedule from what we thought prior. It's a
componenttext: Yes, we have commitment wells in our business. We do not have commitments usually in the Gulf as you anticipate. So we've had these, and these are again, lower cost wells. The well on Block H has moved up in our schedule from what we thought prior. It's a big world out there on rig contracts, and there's an opportunity for us to be subsidized and drill a very low cost well in that part of your world. So if you're in the game for a long time, both sides of the rig equation, I've been at that business a long time. And we have an opportunity to drill well cheaper due to that, and it's a very nice well to drill, it's probably a 60 million-barrel mean type project near the Conoco operated Kimbu Bagen area of Block H. It will be different from the Block H wells we drilled in the past from an exploration basis and totally different from our shallow flat spot gas amplitudes in which we've had enormous success. So we're going to drill that well. It's probably going to be $18 million to $20 million net to Murphy. It's disclosed in our cost here. Be [indiscernible] where we've been a nonoperated smaller partner of Brunei. We've had several successes there in a row. This is a continuation towards that commerciality of flowing LNG into Brunei. We do have the right type of partners there, meeting people that are across the value chain of LNG, and I consider also to be a lower risk, lower cost opportunity, which is what we're looking for. Not a big rank expensive wells at this particular time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's Merapuh and Marakas. If you lived over there 5 or 6 years, you can say really word, Leo, like me. So they're both nearby structures, near 2 very nice fields. Merapuh is a major former gas project in gas project and K gas, and the Marakas wells
componenttext: Well, it's Merapuh and Marakas. If you lived over there 5 or 6 years, you can say really word, Leo, like me. So they're both nearby structures, near 2 very nice fields. Merapuh is a major former gas project in gas project and K gas, and the Marakas wells is a western feature to the west of our south batches platform that does it very, very well. Marakas is a deeper section, I mean a higher pressure, deeper section that was successful, and we had to take those pressures and see how we're going to delineate that with the platform. It is not a 2016 event. This will be out in '17, '18 time, and would depend on capital allocation next year as we go through -- as what you can imagine a difficult budget cycle. The Merapuh well found extensions of some prior gas that we produce today in Merapuh and another structure so proved down the gas there and some up dip oil opportunities, both of them were a 10 million-barrel type thing. We probably drilled both wells for less than 20-something million dollars. It's gone fit in well with our nearby developments, and we're working on it, and they're successful.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, you sort of went through the math in terms of saying that your fourth quarter production was going to be a little bit lower than 3Q. And I know you had some maintenance in the third quarter. Just to be clear, I was expecting some incremental maintenance in the fourth quarter? Or are you just more sort of a risking in the fact that you're saying your nominations for your SK Gas are likely to be lower? Can you just maybe explain that a little better?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, SK Gas, play very, very good year. It's a place where we planned on being 250 -- 250 million a day, and we got up because 300 million a day this quarter prior it's a record quarter for us. It is a situation with many, many fields, filling into a ver
componenttext: Well, SK Gas, play very, very good year. It's a place where we planned on being 250 -- 250 million a day, and we got up because 300 million a day this quarter prior it's a record quarter for us. It is a situation with many, many fields, filling into a very large 9 train, incredible LNG facility. So there's ups and downs of nomination. We're known as a swing producer there and a very reliable swing producer with very high uptime. Again, this sale takes our strong relationship with Petronas. But things come and go there as to impurities of other fields such as nitrogen, H2S, and the management that makes it hard to predict the guidance for that field, it's one of the issues around our company, we have very high cash flow per barrel metrics, but with that becomes just not simple as an onshore situation, Leo. So we have to risk what our nominations will be there. We do have some downtime at that facility operates about Petronas that we've been notified of in November, December. Also the same situation make with our gas, associated gas that comes off of Kikeh. And we have some downtime in the Gulf at front runner that we have to repair some things, and we have some decline at some of our wells in the Gulf. The Gulfs are not really adding any wells there until early in '16. And this year -- and this quarter was a very good quarter for us, and all those come -- combine into that.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think -- it's Roger, I was preparing for that one, Pete. Putting with somebody else, but glad you called in today. You have to look at -- first off, you can't look at Murphy quarterly on that, we made a big change from year to year because we have offsh
componenttext: I think -- it's Roger, I was preparing for that one, Pete. Putting with somebody else, but glad you called in today. You have to look at -- first off, you can't look at Murphy quarterly on that, we made a big change from year to year because we have offshore operations subsea maintenance. We don't have just 1 singular place for work. And I think the real thing is we're looking at 9 65 this year without Syncrude and probably get knocked into very close to 9. I don't believe we can keep the trajectory of taking it to 7 right now. But our big growth in Eagle Ford is going to be looking at $8.50, the continued trending down and for all of next year, that's a big move in the last 2, 3 years. Now with that said, I'm very proud of getting this levels. We have an organization incredibly focused on lowering these cost, and we can't go on forever to $7 probably in our business with an offshore business and an offshore business. We're very happy about where it's headed, and on a year-to-year basis, I think it's quite positive.

And when we feel we can't get to the strip or some level of return, I would like to see this and we move to another, and we will continue that process, and it may work, it may not.

componenttextpreview: Okay, the tax leakage on that is not that great. We have foreign tax credits that would offset almost all of it. If we bring money home from Canada, if we do that, there's obviously a 5% withholding tax associated with that you can't get out of. It is a c
componenttext: Okay, the tax leakage on that is not that great. We have foreign tax credits that would offset almost all of it. If we bring money home from Canada, if we do that, there's obviously a 5% withholding tax associated with that you can't get out of. It is a credible tax against the U.S. taxes code. But you'd likely be out that 5% in a minimum, and really there's not that much leakage otherwise at the present time.

componenttext: Yes, Ed, I'm probably not going to be the leader on that, and I have a bet around here raise people who would ask that question. Obviously, we have Murphy kind of looking at the $45 debt deck and of course, you got to take that across all netbacks and natural gas deck, appropriate, et cetera. We're looking at cutting CapEx significantly, I don't think that'll be a surprise. Then we have to look at that CapEx as to what will happen with production. We have been working through a lot of that issue recently, a long-range plan in determining where we wanted to allocate capital, and we get through our quarter issue here to close out you guys. It's our next focus, and we approve our budget in December, but they significantly reduced. And when we do, when we do, do that, we'll look at and then do. We have several factors there. Dividend policy, we like to maintain. We have what will happen to production and what we can. I do feel that we are -- we're not saying flexible in this highlights, et cetera. What we do have flexibility, we have liquidity and ability to handle a $40 world in '16 and 45 in '17 and we got to make our commitments on our dividends. And having projections we might one production we probably not sharing here today. So I feel our liquidity situations and the leverage we have there are adequate to handle this, and we take some of that into real high-level of review at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The way it works in an offshore environment today, just around $1 million a day to run a rig. And if you have the day rate of the rig is 5 50 to 5 90 and you stop paying the other highs, then you have about the same level of CapEx. That is a very poor ret
componenttext: The way it works in an offshore environment today, just around $1 million a day to run a rig. And if you have the day rate of the rig is 5 50 to 5 90 and you stop paying the other highs, then you have about the same level of CapEx. That is a very poor return, one I'm not happy with, but I do not want to take this out of opportunity to drill 100% rank wells and add more CapEx. Probably I'm not interested in situations where our partners and help them and money to them, I'm not interested in that. The deepwater world is one that doesn't go well at 100%. And we take all that into account. We start looking at the options. And there are many, and we have different types of people who want to take on working interest on some of partners. We have people that offer us some level of very wild card exposure at an appropriate level of risk for us because the rate of return of paying it off is not good, as you would know. So we're looking at all those things but when I mentioned the liquidity in the $40 and $45 world, and our dividend and where -- what happens with our net debt and debt-to-cap, all these factors take into account the worst case scenario in that situation, and I'm not concerned about liquidity on that front.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Any G&A or not continue in event, Guy. It's significant though, 23% of staffing by the end of the year is very significant. That would be both employees and contractors and all types of changes around the company. And no, we would not want to see that con
componenttext: Any G&A or not continue in event, Guy. It's significant though, 23% of staffing by the end of the year is very significant. That would be both employees and contractors and all types of changes around the company. And no, we would not want to see that continue for another 23% [ph] next year, but we have not got the full estimate of that in this top actions or recent to Murphy, very recent over the last few days. And we needed to put that into our budget process, but we are looking at -- we do know that last year we spent $365 million on G&A, and this year we're in our internal work around $300 million, and then we will have -- and we do know that the staffing thing is in the mid-20s per million dollars per year, and we'll have a full how to that's our side. And we are very much significantly down from couple years back. On the operating expenses, I mean, we, like I said, earlier in the call, we made incredible improvements there, it's driven by a lot of great performance at Eagle Ford Shale, a lot of work in the offshore as well, a lot of sharing of helicopters. When things go difficult, many people work together to lower cost. And I'm very pleased on how my staff has performed in that. Incredible job for us. We're incredibly focused on it. Because we're trying to get to cash flow CapEx parity at $45 and every penny counts. And that's how we're working, and when you work on things with the good people I have, you will start seeing the results.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Thanks, Roger. And then focusing in on the Eagle Ford. You're now running 3 rigs there, which is down from 4 last quarter, and the production was better than we had expected this quarter. In a $45 world, $45 to $50 world, can you just talk
componenttext: That's helpful. Thanks, Roger. And then focusing in on the Eagle Ford. You're now running 3 rigs there, which is down from 4 last quarter, and the production was better than we had expected this quarter. In a $45 world, $45 to $50 world, can you just talk about the priorities which will govern the way you think about managing activity levels there over the next year? Is it about the returns of that specific play or is it more about the portfolio and cash flow CapEx parity and you're having flexibility there? So just your high-level thoughts will be appreciated. And then if you can help us out with what the implicit effect might be on the production profile, that would help as well?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have lots of flexible around production. I don't have it, like I said earlier, I don't have that finalized, and I'm probably not going to be the leader in that pack with the year we've had here. We have some really good wells to drill in Eagle Fo
componenttext: Well, we have lots of flexible around production. I don't have it, like I said earlier, I don't have that finalized, and I'm probably not going to be the leader in that pack with the year we've had here. We have some really good wells to drill in Eagle Ford shale. $45-based pricing, we have a lot of wells at a 30% rate of return, and I think that's pretty decent and the oil price are $50, we have many wells to drill at 45% rate of return. Incremental going forward, I don't like to do work that way, but this does help when you're allocating capital. So we're going to be allocating capital on the best areas that deliver the best return on that incrementally. We're also do not need a lot of rigs to protect our acreage. That's different than it was from times past, and we'll have to do some big capital allocations, middle of doing so about protecting acreage versus protecting efficiency. The reason we have such efficient operations, we've been running same number of rigs for a while now with the same teams. So if you go 4 to 0 to 2 to 3 to 4 to 0, it's hard to do that. Almost a situation of allocating capital to remain some level of efficiency, and we're really trying to get to preparing for lower prices here from a cash flow CapEx parity over other things because we cannot continue to outspend our CapEx, and wake up one day and be with the credit of other people. We have very good credit situation today, debt-to-cap, and we don't want to wake up with it like the norm and not have done something or looked to attempt to do something to add value to our shares, to our shareholders. So we're in the middle of all that, and obviously, at the Eagle Ford Shale, will be a key part of capital allocation. I think today, $2.3 billion CapEx for '14, our CapEx in Eagle Ford shale is 855, and we're going to be at that percent or more as we cut CapEx because of very valuable asset for us, it's going extremely well on everything you can imagine that's known and shale business. We, at Murphy, have that ability as well, and we are proud about it, and it too has incredible flexibility because if things were to get worse, we can reduce it and add to it. You want have the efficiency when you jumping at, but it's very nice thing to have, company of our size and I think very, very material.

componenttext: Maybe 1 quick follow up on -- I mean the Eagle Ford performance was impressive on the quarter with actually growing sequentially with fewer completions. Can you talk a little bit about what -- I mean, you referenced better productivity of the wells, higher EURs, some enhanced completions. Can you talk a little bit about some of the things you're seeing in the wells, how sustainable you think that is? What sort of confidence that gives you, I guess, in terms of maintaining better production levels in 2016?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've recently done a big steady in Eagle Ford shale started over with all of our puds and all of our proven locations and our reserves. We're doing very, very well reserved, I'm very pleased with that trajectory where I think this year will end. We
componenttext: Well, we've recently done a big steady in Eagle Ford shale started over with all of our puds and all of our proven locations and our reserves. We're doing very, very well reserved, I'm very pleased with that trajectory where I think this year will end. We had some gas acreage in the Eagle Ford Shale that we've taken off the table, of course. And we've made some big changes in EUR. I think that as I walk through a couple of the fields, I think that significant Karnes were very prolific area there, as you know, on that. We used to think that an 80-acre spacing well have about a 660,000 EUR, and now we've pulled at 660,000 to 600,000, but we're at 48 per spacing. Such an enormous change in resource both in upper and lower Eagle Ford Shale. Tilden will be the same way we're do a lot of work with a longer lateral there, being very sand. Today, from back to '12, 2012, we're talking about the same situation where EURs continue to improve there, probably not so much as Karnes. But the big improvement for us is Catarina, which most Western area, which is a very organized -- we went ground for there, so we don't have the perfect word, sections of land that, but Catarina is very, very organized from that perspective. And we have improved EURs there. We have 3 big ranches there. One area from 210,000 a day, 210,000 equivalent EUR to over 400,000 with less spacing. And then another area from 210,000 to over 550,000. Again, with less spacing. And another area from 210,000 to 600,000. This is enormous change in an area where we drilled wells for only 4-point-something million dollars. This is a big deal. And we may not have it all modeled in yet, but our trajectory and where we're headed there, it's very, very positive, in my view.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks. That was very helpful. And then maybe if I could -- one more, I guess, from a little bit of a strategy point of view. I think one of the concerns that people have had with Murphy has been maybe depth of resource and what would drive, in an oil pri
componenttext: Thanks. That was very helpful. And then maybe if I could -- one more, I guess, from a little bit of a strategy point of view. I think one of the concerns that people have had with Murphy has been maybe depth of resource and what would drive, in an oil price recovery, what are you assets or the resources that are going to drive growth again, when you returned the plan off as opposed to the defense. And I guess as you think about that and you think about the resource you have in your portfolio, what would you see -- the Eagle Ford is certainly going to be one, but what do you see is kind of the resource that will drive -- that will be kind of a driver that the next leg of growth for the company, and I guess in that context, and how does the M&A fit in terms of other complementing or competing with that resource for kind of the next cycle of Murphy?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, clearly when we do M&A, we look at how it affects our long-range plans and how it increase our income, our cash flow per share and every top metrics, including word, but I think what you're speaking I say about our very frustrating to me and
componenttext: Well, I mean, clearly when we do M&A, we look at how it affects our long-range plans and how it increase our income, our cash flow per share and every top metrics, including word, but I think what you're speaking I say about our very frustrating to me and 8 for a long time, it's going to be 8 for a long time. But from an oil-weighted perspective, were probably fifth-place out of 16 peers, if you take the all reputed truly, truly with very limited NGL RDP player and very, very low on natural gas, that's quite frustrating to me, view that we don't have locations. This year, in Eagle Ford Shale, we're going to drill and operate about 136 wells, bring online 136 wells, and we probably have 3,000 locations to go. So it's obvious that Eagle Ford shale is not material for a company that has 756 million barrels approved and now resource size remaining of 800 million barrels, it's mind-boggling to me, and it's very well-known how this project models. But outside of that, I mean prices like Vietnam, we -- we have focused, very tight ramp where we want to bring that focused tighter. Projects like Kodiak, Kodiak, Vietnam, and things in coffer available to us, not large and many change here capital structure that deals that's very helpful. On that adding barrels. We do have Floating LNG coming online, which is going very well. As I mentioned we took a core there and do well this quarter to continue to confirm our outstanding resource available and we're further within BD LNG player in the world, Petronas, which some big deal. So small things alive Kodiak, big ones like Vietnam, M&A on top of all that, but we do not have collapsing RFP in this company. If you take a look at the long-range plan of the company, we do not have significantly drop ever our RFP. We just don't have the 12 because we don't have a lot of the gas to make it 12. So no, that's -- I think it's a misnomer a bit about the resources we have, and we probably need to do a better job of outlining those resources. But it's hard to do that in 2 years and oil price collapsed twice. That's not the time to go out, set expectations when you lower CapEx, have their own expectations work that way. So it's hard to get that into that vision that you are asking in this incredible, total oil price time. If you want to maintain balance sheet to do transformational things for the company, you can initially outspend and grow production and in that not having a transformational changes is very easy. I can just pick up the phone and do that. So I decided not to do it that way at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: That's great. I appreciate that. I mean it's safe to say that this probably more resources than the market declined word but maybe one last one on that produced the Gulf of Mexico, there's a lot of -- you've had some recent successful wells there anything over the next couple of years as if the play that's probably a little bit harder for us to model out, how do you think about production in the Gulf of Mexico over the next couple of years? headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're not probably -- we are -- if you could get partners to participate in our rows and have ability and income to do so and cash flow, we could grow production there. And that's hard to deal with at this particular time. We have some really nice low-ris
componenttext: We're not probably -- we are -- if you could get partners to participate in our rows and have ability and income to do so and cash flow, we could grow production there. And that's hard to deal with at this particular time. We have some really nice low-risk opportunity there like Medusa, we are pleased 2 wells on Montney, doing very, very well. So we have some additional locations there. It'll be a matter an oil price recovery. However, tiebacks like Dalmatian South #2 and various other things, tiebacks in the Gulf of Mexico are right up there with returns you have in the Eagle Ford, if you take full cycle into account, meaning the drilling of the well, the pipeline, et cetera, these things are very economic. We did higher -- we need a higher -- in EBITDA higher oil price want to get into the facility building be desperation successful things, or we can enter into a well or enter into thanks, unique pullback as we have the balance sheet to be able to do so. Those need oil to be a lower or higher, higher you can participate into the Gulf and many, many favorable projects today. So our ability to operate in there, work there, long history of being there and have our business, that way very advantageous for us right now. So we have great Eagle Ford Shale business going, we can executing incredibly well on keep the team for years and we hired been able to look at those opportunity, have a long-standing deepwater opportunity where we're not exploring today, but the factor is how do you get comfortable in changing staffing to do that again, another day when oil prices recover if they choose to do so. But there's a lot of opportunity in both and we're very, very advantaged to look at both word, and I don't know if many people have that.

Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the call over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.Please refer to the inform
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Please refer to the informational slides we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with our webcast today. 
Today's call will follow our usual format. John will begin by providing a view of third quarter 2015 financial results, and then Roger will follow with an operational update, after which, questions will be taken.
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For further discussion of risk factors, see Murphy's 2014 annual report on Form K (sic) [ Form 10-K ] on file with the SEC. Murphy takes no duty to publicly update or revise any public -- any forward-looking statements.
I will now turn the call over to John for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone. Murphy Oil's consolidated results in the third quarter of 2015 were a loss of $1.6 billion, which equates to $9.26 per diluted share. That's compared to a profit of $246 million or $1.37 per diluted share
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone. Murphy Oil's consolidated results in the third quarter of 2015 were a loss of $1.6 billion, which equates to $9.26 per diluted share. That's compared to a profit of $246 million or $1.37 per diluted share a year ago. The third quarter 2015 results included noncash property impairments of $2.3 billion, which, after tax, has amounted to $1.54 billion charge. These impairments were attributable to significant declines in future periods oil prices, which failed by as much as $15 per barrel at quarter end compared to 3 months earlier. The impairments were not related to reductions in the company's reported reserves.
Adjusted earnings, which adjust our GAAP numbers for various items that affect comparability of earnings between periods was a loss of $124 million in the third quarter of 2015, down from our profit of $205 million a year ago. This decline in adjusted earnings was primarily attributable to lower oil and natural gas sales prices in the current year. Our schedule of adjusted earnings is included as part of our earnings release, and the amounts in this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis.
Company's average realized price for its crude oil production fell more than $43 per barrel in the third quarter compared to the prior year. This amounted to a 48% drop between periods in oil prices. Natural gas prices also were weaker in the third quarter 2015 compared to the prior year with average North American gas price realizations dropping $1.21 per Mcf or a decline of 33%. Realized natural gas prices offshore Sarawak also fell by 27%.
Sales process continued to be soft in October, and therefore, revenues continue to be under pressure as quarter 4 2015 prices remain significantly below prices a year ago.
The company continues to address its cost structure by aggressively reducing both operating and administrative cost. By year-end 2015, we anticipate a 23% reduction in staffing levels compared to a year earlier. At September 30, 2015, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to approximately $3.3 billion, 35.6% of total capital employed, while net debt amounted to just over 25% at the end of the third quarter.
At this time, I'll turn the call over to Roger for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Looking back a solid operational third quarter, the following highlights standout. Our company remains in a favorable financial position with a healthy balance sheet that's flexible, take advantage of opportunities that arise both in onsh
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Looking back a solid operational third quarter, the following highlights standout. Our company remains in a favorable financial position with a healthy balance sheet that's flexible, take advantage of opportunities that arise both in onshore and offshore. With a major pullback in oil prices, we've been able to maintain our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio at less than 1.5. Subsequent to the third quarter we hedge for 2016, we currently have 20,000 barrels per day WTI contracts at an average price of $52 per barrel.
On the costs side, we continue to make significant improvements in reducing both operating and G&A expenses on a year-to-year basis. We continue to review our portfolio. As we still have many levers remaining to reposition the company going forward, we're currently reviewing the value of various midstream assets in North America. We're enthusiastic about the new area that we've recently formed into Offshore Vietnam, which expanded our Vietnam footprint with a new block in a highly perspective, oil-prone Cuu Long Basin. Our partnership group was successful in testing our first well, and we're working to increase acreage in this prolific area.
In the Gulf of Mexico, we drilled the Dalmatian South #2. We like what we see here as it has commercial hydrocarbons in 2 separate zones. Currently, the well is being completed with first production expected early next year.
In Malaysia, we achieved record average daily gross production for Sarawak Gas at 291 million per day. In addition, we drilled the Merapuh 5 and Marakas wells with positive results and process of evaluating both.
In our onshore business, the Eagle Ford Shale continues to outperform expectations where we delivered 33 new wells online in the third quarter, plus Montney production continues to be above plan.
Our third quarter production is just over 207,500 barrel equivalents per day, and we're increasing our 2015 annual production guidance to a range of 205,000 to 209,000 barrel equivalents per day. Over the course of the year, we've increased the midpoint of our production guidance from 201,000 barrels equivalents per day to 207,000, almost 3% increase.
In operations, we're pleased with the ongoing efforts we're making on cost reductions. Our lease operating expenses for the third quarter 2015, excluding Syncrude, is $8.09 per BOE, showing a reduction of 23% from the third quarter of 2014. More importantly, we're posting a 45% reduction from full year 2013 on LOE.
In Eagle Ford Shale, our third quarter operating expenses are just over $8 per BOE. This represents over $2 reduction from the second quarter of this year.
On a cash margin basis, we are just over $19 per barrel equivalent in third quarter, and our $20.28 per BOE for 9 months ended. This compares very favorably to our peers and has been stable for Murphy for a long time due to our already-diverse portfolio.
In production, deposit production branch of 7,500 barrel equivalents per day for the quarter is attributable to Sarawak oil, and natural gas deal is performing better, above plan performance on base decline. The Eagle Ford Shale, new volume well -- new well volume's exceeding plan due to EUR increases and completion performance and higher natural gas production from Montney.
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter. Production guidance is estimated to be 199,000 barrel equivalents per day. Our third quarter actual production's higher than our fourth quarter guidance due to higher risk SK natural gas nominations and planned downtime, natural well decline in the Gulf of Mexico and significant reduction in a number of completed wells in the Eagle Ford Shale.
More importantly, we are maintaining our 2015 CapEx of $2.3 billion, some 32% below last year's level when taking to account the sell-down in Malaysia.
In Western Canada. Our natural gas production in Montney in the third quarter of 2015 was over 194 million per day. We've been successful in implementing fractured techniques from our Eagle Ford Shale work to the Montney. Our new completion design with increased same concentrations continued to confirm our 8 to 11 Bcf EURs. Also, we continue to have positive results on our refrac pilot that is underway in some older, tougher wells.
In the Eagle Ford Shale, we're especially pleased with our results for the third quarter, for production average over 63,000 barrels equivalent per day. We brought about 33 new wells online in the third quarter, and we're planning to deliver 20 wells in the fourth, for a total of 136 wells this year.
Our program has been front-loaded as prior disclosed. Production for 2015 full year outlook is now expected to exceed 61,000 barrels equivalent per day, which is 8% above 2014 production.
We continue adding to our total remaining resource in the play by downspacing wells, drilling longer laterals and optimizing completions, to name a few. We now estimate that our total remaining resource has grown to over 800 million barrels. And this growth even takes into account a total review of our resources from a price perspective.
We successfully drilled our first Austin Chalk well in Karnes County, and we're hopeful -- hopefully, we'll be moving this play concept westward to our Catarina area. This will add 1/3 horizon to our Upper and Lower Eagle Ford Shale locations. We drilled the first of 3 well appraisal pilot and are currently analyzing corn logs to better understand the reservoir properties. Our current Austin Chalk appraisal well has a very successful flow rate of 1,500 barrel oil equivalent per day. We look forward to continuing to test Austin Chalk play in 2016.
In Malaysia, we achieved record average daily gas production in Sarawak of 291 million a day. We successfully drilled 2 shallow-water Sarawak oil prospects. The Merapuh 5 and Marakas wells had positive results where we're evaluating development options. These wells are in the Block SK314A area, adjacent to our successful Sarawak oil and gas developments.
The Murphy-operated Paus-Kelasa well failed to encounter commercial quantities of hydrocarbon and was expensed as a dry hole in the quarter.
Offshore Vietnam, we signed a farm-in agreement in the shallow water 15-1/05 block in the prolific, oil-prone Vietnam Cuu Long Basin. 2 discoveries have been made on the block. Murphy participated in the drilling and testing of the LDV-4X well, which successfully tested 2 prospective zones. We're also working with PetroVietnam to advance our footprint in the Cuu Long. This new block entry was made possible by our long-term relationship with our partner and our significant position as a successful operator in both deepwater and shallow water in Malaysia.
In the Gulf of Mexico, production for the quarter was over 27,200 barrel equivalents per day at 71% liquids. We spud the Dalmatian South #2 well during the quarter. We're now completing the wells we found commercial hydrocarbons with over 98 free-to-pay in 2 zones, and we expect first production early next year.
Field development work on the nonoperating Kodiak project continues where the first of 2 wells had been drilled and completed the plan, and modification of topside facilities and subsea execution is underway. We're currently progressing the sidetrack of our Thunder Bird well to plan, and all of our current Gulf of Mexico projects can withstand lower-for-longer prices.
Looking at the drilling program for the fourth quarter 2015 in the Gulf, the nonoperated Solomon well, which is currently projected to reach total depth some time in the fourth quarter, has been included in our dry hole exposure for the fourth quarter. We plan to finish up the year with an oil exploration well, Senyum, located in Block H Malaysia with some nonoperated well to appraise our oil-linked gas discoveries in Brunei.
This time, we have 2 deepwater rigs under contract at Murphy. These contracts expire in 2016, 1 in February; and the other in November. With the continued low commodity prices we're experiencing, an expected reduction in our 2016 CapEx program and an uncertainty about whether working interest partners will agree to participate in drilling programs, we're considering all options. Our current contractual commitments to the end of term for both rigs equals $277 million.
In financials, Murphy has been able to maintain our investment-grade BBB bond rating. We maintained our dividend policy through the year with current yield of 5%. We have $1 billion available under our current revolver. We have over $1.2 billion of cash abroad with marketable securities, and we achieved a net debt-to-EBITDA of less than 1.5.
Production for the fourth quarter is estimated to be 199,000 barrel equivalents per day. Again, we have increased our full year production guidance with a range of 205,000 to 209,000 equivalent per day. Capital expenditures remain unchanged from previous guidance and are currently forecasted to be $2.3 billion.
To close in my comments today, I would like to leave with a few points. Murphy continues to have financial flexibility and strength. We have greatly lowered operating and G&A expenses over the course of the year, and cost reductions remain a priority. Our entry to the Eagle Ford Shale has been an extremely successful addition to Murphy over the past few years. We've built an excellent high-performing team, now producing around 30% of our total volumes in just over 40 years. We, like most peers, continues the efficiencies in cost reductions in drilling and completion activity across all of our operating areas. Our Gulf of Mexico projects generate sound economics at current prices. And over the quarter, we have participated in many positive well results, from the Gulf of Mexico to shallow water Malaysia and to Vietnam and a very high-rate oil test in the Austin Chalk area of Eagle Ford Shale. We continue to execute on all cylinders in a tough commodity environment.
I'd like to now open up the phone for your questions, and thank you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Leo Mariani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Leo Mariani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question for you. A little softly I know earlier in the year you guys talked about moving away from some of the exploration activity. I guess you guys are announcing that you're firing into a block, and Vietnam here is sort of new area. I guess has
componenttext: Just a question for you. A little softly I know earlier in the year you guys talked about moving away from some of the exploration activity. I guess you guys are announcing that you're firing into a block, and Vietnam here is sort of new area. I guess has this not really seen any sort of exploration? It sounds like there's some existing discoveries? Or do you guys just see this as lower-risk exploration?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we see it as a little bit of both, Leo. We have had a pause in our exploration. When I say that, it's primarily related to the big $100 million-plus big wells in the Gulf of Mexico. They're very expensive. They have very high day rates. But we're
componenttext: I think we see it as a little bit of both, Leo. We have had a pause in our exploration. When I say that, it's primarily related to the big $100 million-plus big wells in the Gulf of Mexico. They're very expensive. They have very high day rates. But we're not opposed to entering into lower-risk opportunities. That was clear to us that the block did have prior discoveries on them, and we entered into the block and participated in the delineation with all the discoveries. The delineation is going very, very well. We're very excited about it. We're talking about -- when we had -- you have 2 types of wells in the world, the big Gulf of Mexico, West Africa, new entry-type wells, and you have lower-risk opportunities in a place like Vietnam where you can drill a well for $15 million and have a 50 million to 100 million barrel-type prospect. So in that space system and F&D perspective, that's a very positive thing. And this is about our strategy, just as about our company. We do work internationally. We are a big major player in Malaysia. We have a strong relationship and a very strong reputation in Southeast Asia, and we were able to -- our expertise in shallow water development there and across other acreage in Vietnam, is the reason we were able to get into this block. And it's very favorable. But I do not consider it to be entry in a wild-up place somewhere. It's very similar geology, what we're used to, very similar areas of operation, very similar cost, very similar well design and a place where we work nearby. And it's something we're focused on in that area. I consider it not a new, big, wild entry into a far-off place, Leo.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can you give us a little bit more color about this exploration well you're drilling in Malaysia towards the end of the year? And you also mentioned another well in Brunei, which, I guess, is not up. Can you give us a little more color around those?
componenttext: Okay. Can you give us a little bit more color about this exploration well you're drilling in Malaysia towards the end of the year? And you also mentioned another well in Brunei, which, I guess, is not up. Can you give us a little more color around those?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have commitment wells in our business. We do not have commitments usually in the Gulf as you anticipate. So we've had these, and these are, again, lower-cost wells. The well on Block H has moved up in our schedule from what we thought prior. It's
componenttext: Yes. We have commitment wells in our business. We do not have commitments usually in the Gulf as you anticipate. So we've had these, and these are, again, lower-cost wells. The well on Block H has moved up in our schedule from what we thought prior. It's a big world out there on rig contracts, and there's an opportunity for us to be subsidized and drill a very low-cost well in that part of the world. So if you're in the game for a long time, you know on both sides of the rig equation. I've been in -- at that business a long time. And that we have an opportunity to drill well cheaper due to that. And it's a very nice well to drill. It's probably a 60 million barrel, mean-type project near the Conoco-operated Kimbu Bagen [ph] area of Block H. It would be different from the Block H wells we drilled in the past from an exploration basis and totally different from our shallow flat spot gas amplitudes in which we've had enormous success. So we're going to drill that well. It's probably $18 million to $20 million net to Murphy. It's disclosed in our costs here. In Keratau where we've been a nonoperated smaller partner of Brunei, we've had several successes there in a row. This is a continuation towards that commerciality of flowing LNG into Brunei. We do have the right type of partners there, meaning, people that are across the value chain of LNG. And I consider it also to be a lower-risk, lower-cost opportunity, which is what we're looking for, not the big-rank, expensive wells at this particular time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess you guys also mentioned that you had 2 recent successes at Sarawak on the oil side. I don't know if I can pronounce the 2 names of these wells. They both begin with an M. Can you give us a little bit more just color around there? I guess it sounds like you're still appraising them? What do you see -- what else that potentially could come online in your future, like 2016? What else can you tell us about those?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's called the Merapuh and Marakas. If you lived over there 5 or 6 years, you can say it really easily, Leo, like me. So they're both nearby structures, near 2 very nice fields. Merapuh is a major part of our gas project in SK Gas. And the Marakas
componenttext: Well, it's called the Merapuh and Marakas. If you lived over there 5 or 6 years, you can say it really easily, Leo, like me. So they're both nearby structures, near 2 very nice fields. Merapuh is a major part of our gas project in SK Gas. And the Marakas well is a western feature to the west of our South Acis platform that does very, very well. Marakas is a deeper section. I mean, a higher pressure, deeper section that was successful, and we had to take those pressures and see how we're going to delineate that with the platform. It is not a 2016 event. This would be out in '17, '18 time and would depend on capital allocation next year as we go through -- as you -- what you can imagine a difficult budget cycle. The Merapuh well found extensions of some prior gas that we produce today in Merapuh and another structure, so improved down-dip gas there and some up-dip oil opportunities. Both of them were a 10 million barrel type thing. We probably drilled both wells for less than $20-something million. It's going to fit in well with our nearby developments, and we're working on it, and they're successful.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, you sort of went through the math in terms of saying that your fourth quarter production was going to be a little bit lower than 3Q. And I know you had some maintenance in the third quarter. Just to be clear, are you exp
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess, you sort of went through the math in terms of saying that your fourth quarter production was going to be a little bit lower than 3Q. And I know you had some maintenance in the third quarter. Just to be clear, are you expecting some incremental maintenance in fourth quarter? Or are you just more just sort of a risking in the fact that you're saying your nominations for your SK Gas are likely to be lower? Can you just maybe explain that a little better?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, SK Gas plays so much [ph]. We'd had a very, very good year. It's a place where we planned on being 250 -- 250 million a day, and then we got up because it's a 300 million a day this quarter prior. It's a record quarter for us. It is a situation with
componenttext: Well, SK Gas plays so much [ph]. We'd had a very, very good year. It's a place where we planned on being 250 -- 250 million a day, and then we got up because it's a 300 million a day this quarter prior. It's a record quarter for us. It is a situation with many, many fields, filling into a very large 9 train, incredible LNG facility. So there's ups and downs of nomination. We're known as a swing producer there and a very reliable swing producer with very high uptime. Again, the sale takes our strong relationship with Petronas. But things come and go there as to impurities of other fields such as nitrogen, H2S, and the management that makes it a little hard to predict. The guidance for that field, it's one of the issues around our company. We have very high cash flow per barrel metrics, but with that, it becomes just not simple as an onshore situation, Leo. So we have to risk what our nominations will be there. We do have some downtime at that facility. You operate about Petronas that we've been notified of in November, December. Also the same situation with our gas, associated gas that comes off of Kikeh. And we have some downtime in the Gulf at Front Runner. I think we have to repair some things, and we have some decline about some of our wells in the Gulf because we're not really adding any wells there until early in '16. And this year -- and this quarter was a very good quarter for us, and all those come -- combine into that.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think -- it's Roger. I'll -- I was preparing for that one, Pete. I've put it with somebody else, but glad you called in today. You have to look at -- first off, you can't look at Murphy quarterly on that where we made big change from year to year becaus
componenttext: I think -- it's Roger. I'll -- I was preparing for that one, Pete. I've put it with somebody else, but glad you called in today. You have to look at -- first off, you can't look at Murphy quarterly on that where we made big change from year to year because we have offshore operations, subsea maintenance. We don't have just one singular place for work. And I think the real thing is we're looking at $9.65 this year without Syncrude and probably getting that into very close to $9. I don't believe we can keep the trajectory of taking it to $7 right now. But our big growth in Eagle Ford is going to be looking at $8.50 and continued trending down and for all of next year. That's a big move from the last 2, 3 years. Now with that said, I'm very proud of getting at these levels. We have an organization incredibly focused on lowering these costs, and we can't go on forever to $7 probably in our business with an offshore business and an onshore business. But very happy about where it's headed, and on a year-to-year basis, I think it's quite positive.

componenttext: There's just everything in the above there. You have some public situations. You have private equity situations and probably have a vision of a more return of their multiple, and probably it's to be able to offer the returns that we would like. The Midland area is very, very frothy. Delaware getting a little better, I'd say. Offshore opportunities in the Gulf are the key ones for value adds. And we're expanding a little bit across North America to make sure we touch every place for value, and not necessarily focused -- I think we're not quite as singularly focused as we were before. And we -- like I said to Pete here, I mean, we have a certain criteria we're looking for, and we execute on that and keeps something going. And when we decide we can't make a return, we have a process of looking at the NAV or the rate of return of the investment, Roger, on strip and a price recovery deck that we have. We have 4 price decks here at Murphy. And when we feel we can't get to the strip or some level of return, I would like to see this [ph], and we move to another one. And we will continue that process, and it may work, it may not.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's -- I'm really not going to probably say that, Roger. It would -- you anticipate some level of return on a price recovery deck. It would have to be far in excess the cost of capital. And the reason you can't just say exactly what it is because it's mo
componenttext: It's -- I'm really not going to probably say that, Roger. It would -- you anticipate some level of return on a price recovery deck. It would have to be far in excess the cost of capital. And the reason you can't just say exactly what it is because it's more complicated, that depends on the reserves that would be, what are those price for those barrels that they have flowing production that you could have some level of CapEx without hurting your capitalization of the company and just a list of issues that would have different types of terms for different types of things.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. The tax leakage on that is not that great. We have foreign tax credits that would offset almost all of it. If we bring money home from Canada, if we do that, there's obviously a 5% withholding tax associated with that, you can't get out of. It is a
componenttext: Okay. The tax leakage on that is not that great. We have foreign tax credits that would offset almost all of it. If we bring money home from Canada, if we do that, there's obviously a 5% withholding tax associated with that, you can't get out of. It is a credible tax against the U.S. taxes owed. But you'd likely be out that 5% at a minimum. And really, there's not that much leakage otherwise at the present time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: I mean, I guess the key focus is the cash flow outspend. I mean, you've got a balance sheet that, obviously, prices are low. People will worry about it, so you got a CapEx for this year of $2.3 billion. You've talked about potentially dropping rigs. Maybe walk through what are the big deltas that you see from this year to next year. I appreciate you may not want to give a specific number, but what should we be thinking about?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ed. I'm probably not going to be the leader in that, and I have a bed around here today of the different ways people would ask that question. Obviously, we at Murphy are kind of -- we're going to be looking at a $45 WTI deck. And of course, you got t
componenttext: Yes, Ed. I'm probably not going to be the leader in that, and I have a bed around here today of the different ways people would ask that question. Obviously, we at Murphy are kind of -- we're going to be looking at a $45 WTI deck. And of course, you got to take that across all your netbacks and natural gas deck, appropriate deck, et cetera. And we're looking at cutting CapEx significantly. I don't think that would be a surprise. Then we have to look at that CapEx as to what will happen with production. We have been working through a lot of that issue recently, a long-range plan in determining where we wanted to allocate capital, then we get through our quarter issue here to close out you guys. It's our next focus, and we, as usual, approve our budget in December, but it may significantly reduce. And when we do, when we do, do that, we'll look at it and do it. We are -- we have several factors there. The dividend policy, we'd like to maintain. We have what will happen to production and what we can. I do feel that we are -- we're not saying flexible in these highlights, et cetera. We do have flexibility. We have liquidity and ability to handle a $40 world in '16 and $45 in '17, and we got to make our commitments on our dividends. And having put in some projections we now have one production, and we probably aren't sharing here today. So I feel our liquidity situation and the leverage we have there are adequate to handle this, and we -- we're taking that into a real high-level of review at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so then coming to the rig comment you made in the opening remarks, you said one rolls off, I think, in spring and one in November, and considering all options, how much are you spending if you, say, drop both those rigs? What would that be impac
componenttext: Okay. And so then coming to the rig comment you made in the opening remarks, you said one rolls off, I think, in spring and one in November, and considering all options, how much are you spending if you, say, drop both those rigs? What would that be impact -- what would the impact be about?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The way it works in an offshore and in a lot environment today, it's just around $1 million a day to run a rig. And if you have -- the day rate of the rig is $5.50 to $5.90 and you stop paying the other half, then you have about the same level of CapEx. T
componenttext: The way it works in an offshore and in a lot environment today, it's just around $1 million a day to run a rig. And if you have -- the day rate of the rig is $5.50 to $5.90 and you stop paying the other half, then you have about the same level of CapEx. That is a very poor return and one I'm not happy with. But I do not want to take this opportunity to drill 100% [indiscernible] that wells and add more CapEx. Probably I'm not interested in situations where I carry partners and help them, hand more money to them. I'm not interested in that. The deepwater world is one that doesn't go well at 100%. And we take all that to account. We start looking at the options. And there are many, and we have an different -- we have different types of people who want to take on working interest on some of our partners. And we have people that offer us some level of very wild cat exposure at an appropriate level of risk for us because the rate of return of paying it off is not good, as you would know. So we are looking at all of those things. But when I mention the liquidity in the $40 and $45 world and our dividend and where -- what happens with our net debt and our cap -- debt-to-cap, all these factors take into account the worst case scenario in that situation. And I'm not concerned about liquidity on that front.

componenttext: No. But I consider it significant. And we continue to work there [ph]. And that we're not a company that throws around MLPs who does all this wild stuff all the time. And it, too, would be another liquidity situation that I have not factored in, in a discussion I just had with you a few minutes ago.
