componenttext: Roger, I wanted to talk a little bit more about the performance, which was impressive. And apologies if I missed this, but do you have an estimate of the split between the cost gains and efficiencies you've -- you have achieved, which you might be classified as or which you might classify as more cyclical versus what is more structural in the result of what Murphy specifically is doing differently?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Any G&A or not continuing an event, Guy, it's significant, though. 23% of staffing by the end of the year is very significant. That would be both employees and contractors and all types of changes around the company. And no, we would not want to see that
componenttext: Any G&A or not continuing an event, Guy, it's significant, though. 23% of staffing by the end of the year is very significant. That would be both employees and contractors and all types of changes around the company. And no, we would not want to see that continue for another 23% next year. But we have not got the full estimate of that in this top actions or recent to Murphy, very recent, over the last few days. And we need to put that into our budget process, but we are looking at -- we do know that last year, we spent $365 million on G&A, and this year, we're in our internal work around $300 million. And then we will have -- and we do know that the staffing thing is in the mid-20s per million -- million dollars per year, and we'll have a full help to that through our side. And we are very much significantly down from a couple years back. On the operating expenses, I mean, we -- like I said, earlier in the call, we made incredible improvements there. It's driven by a lot of great performance at Eagle Ford Shale, a lot of work in the offshore as well, a lot of sharing of helicopters, sharing -- when things go difficult, many people work together to lower the cost. And I'm very pleased on how my staff has performed in that. It's an incredible job for us. We're incredibly focused on it because we're trying to get to cash flow CapEx parity at $45 and every penny counts. And that's how we're working. And when you work on things with the good people I have, you'll start seeing the results.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Roger. And then focusing in on the Eagle Ford, you're now running 3 rigs there, which is down from 4 last quarter, and the production was better than we had expected this quarter. In a $45 world, $45 to $50 world, can you just talk about t
componenttext: That's helpful, Roger. And then focusing in on the Eagle Ford, you're now running 3 rigs there, which is down from 4 last quarter, and the production was better than we had expected this quarter. In a $45 world, $45 to $50 world, can you just talk about the priorities, which will govern the way you think about managing activity levels there over the next year? Is it about the returns of that specific play? Or is it more about the portfolio and cash flow CapEx parity and you having flexibility there? So just your high-level thoughts there would be appreciated. And then if you could help us out with what the implicit effect might be on the production profile, that would help as well.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a lot of flexible around production. I don't have it. Like I said earlier, I don't have that finalized, and I'm probably not going to be the leader in that pack with the year we've had here. We have some really good wells to drill in Eagle F
componenttext: Well, we have a lot of flexible around production. I don't have it. Like I said earlier, I don't have that finalized, and I'm probably not going to be the leader in that pack with the year we've had here. We have some really good wells to drill in Eagle Ford Shale. A $45 base pricing, we have a lot of wells at a 30% rate of return, and that -- and I think that's pretty decent. And the oil prices are $50. We have many wells to drill at 45% rate of return. Incremental going forward, I don't like to do work that way, but this does help when you're allocating capital. So we're going to be allocating capital on the best areas that deliver the best return on that incrementally. We also do not need a lot of rigs to protect our acreage. That's different than it was for -- in times past, and we'll have to do some big capital allocations, study them in the middle of doing so about protecting acreage versus protecting efficiency. The reason we have such efficient operations, we've been running same numbers of rigs for a while now with the same teams. So if you go 4 to 0 to 2 to 3 to 4 to 0, it's hard to do that. So it's almost a situation of allocating capital to remain some level of efficiency, and we're really trying to get to preparing for lower prices here from a cash flow CapEx parity over other things because we cannot continue to outspend our CapEx and wake up one day and be with the credit of other people. We have very good credit situation today, debt-to-cap, and we don't want to wake up with it like the norm and not have done something or looked or attempted to do something to add value to our shares -- to our shareholders. So we're in the middle of all that, and obviously, the Eagle Ford Shale, will be a key part of capital allocation. I think, today, $2.3 billion CapEx for '14, our CapEx in Eagle Ford shale is $855 million, and we're going to be at that percent or more as we cut CapEx because it's a very valuable asset for us. It's going extremely well on everything you can imagine that's known in shale business. We at Murphy have that ability as well, and we are proud about it. And it, too, has incredible flexibility because if things were to get worse, you can reduce it and add to it. You won't have the efficiency when you jump and add, but it's a very nice thing to have, our company of our size and I think very, very material.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe one quick follow-up on -- I mean, the Eagle Ford performance was impressive on the quarter with actually growing sequentially with fewer completions. Can you talk a little bit about what -- I mean, you referenced better productivity of the wells, hi
componenttext: Maybe one quick follow-up on -- I mean, the Eagle Ford performance was impressive on the quarter with actually growing sequentially with fewer completions. Can you talk a little bit about what -- I mean, you referenced better productivity of the wells, high EURs, some enhanced completions. Can you talk a little about some of the things that you're seeing in the wells? How sustainable do you think that is? And what sort of confidence that gives you, I guess, in terms of maintaining better production levels in 2016?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've recently done a big steady in Eagle Ford Shale. We started over with all of our puds, all of our proven locations and our reserves. We're doing very, very well in reserved, find them very pleased with that trajectory where I think this year wi
componenttext: Well, we've recently done a big steady in Eagle Ford Shale. We started over with all of our puds, all of our proven locations and our reserves. We're doing very, very well in reserved, find them very pleased with that trajectory where I think this year will end. We have a -- we had some gas acreage in Eagle Ford Shale that we've taken off the table, of course. And we've made some big changes in EUR. I think that as I walk through a couple of the fields, I think it's significant. Karnes where -- is a very prolific area there, as you know, Ryan. We used to think that an 80-acre spacing well would have about a 660,000 EUR. And now we've pulled at 660,000 to 600,000, but we're at 40-acre spacing, so it's an enormous change in resource, both in Upper and Lower Eagle Ford Shale. Tilden would be the same way. We're doing a lot of work with longer laterals there, bigger sand. Today, from back to '12, 2012, we're talking about the same situation where EURs continue to improve there, probably not so much as Karnes. But the big improvement for us is Catarina, which is our most western area, which is a very organized -- we went ground floor there, so we don't have the perfect, giant sections of land that. But Catarina is very, very organized from that perspective. And we have improved the EURs there. We have 3 big ranches there. One area from 210,000 a day -- 210,000 equivalent EUR to over 400,000 with less spacing; and then another area from 210,000 to over 550,000, again, with less spacing; and another area from 210,000 to 600,000. This is enormous change in an area that we drill wells for only $4-point-something million. This is a big deal. And that we may not have it all modeled in yet, but our trajectory and where we're headed there, it's a -- it's very, very positive, in my view.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That was very helpful. And then maybe if I could talk -- one more, I guess, from a little bit of a strategy point of view. I mean, I think one of the concerns that people have had with Murphy has been maybe depth of resource and what would drive -- in an
componenttext: That was very helpful. And then maybe if I could talk -- one more, I guess, from a little bit of a strategy point of view. I mean, I think one of the concerns that people have had with Murphy has been maybe depth of resource and what would drive -- in an oil price recovery, what are going to be the assets or the resources that's going to drive when -- growth again, when you return the planned offense as opposed to defense? And I guess as you think about that and you think about the resources you have in your portfolio, what would -- what would you see -- the Eagle Ford is clearly going to be one, but what would you see as kind of the resource that'll drive -- that'll be the kind of the driver within the next leg of growth for the company? And I guess in that context -- and how does M&A fit in terms of other complementing or competing with that resource for kind of the next cycle of Murphy?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, clearly, when we do M&A, we look at how it affects our long-range plans and how it increase our income, our cash flow per share and every top metrics, including R/P. I think when you speak in a nice way about the R/P, you that it's very frus
componenttext: Well, I mean, clearly, when we do M&A, we look at how it affects our long-range plans and how it increase our income, our cash flow per share and every top metrics, including R/P. I think when you speak in a nice way about the R/P, you that it's very frustrating to me. The R/P has been 8 for a long time. It's going to be 8 for a long time. But from an oil-weighted perspective, we're probably fifth place out of 16 peers. If you take the R/P, that's really truly oil. We're very limited. We're probably the NGL R/P player and very, very low on natural gas. That's quite frustrating to me because it's viewed that we don't have relocations. If -- this year, in Eagle Ford Shale, we're going to drill and operate about 136 wells. Now we already [ph] bring online 136 wells, and we probably have 3,000 locations to go. So it's obvious [ph] that Eagle Ford Shale is not material for a company that has 756 million barrels approved and now a resource size remaining of 800 million barrels. It's mind-boggling to me, and it's very well-known how this project models. But outside of that, I mean, places like Vietnam, we may -- we have focus there is a very tight around where we want to work. We want to bring that focus tighter. Projects like Kodiak, Kodiak, Vietnam and things in the Gulf are available to us that are not large M&A change your entire capital structure type deals, but they're very helpful on adding barrels. And we do have a Floating LNG coming online. [indiscernible] is going very well. But I mentioned when we took a core there and a well this quarter to continue to confirm our outstanding resource available, and we're partnered with the leading LNG player in the world, Petronas, which is a big deal. So small things like Kodiak, big ones like Vietnam, M&A on top of all that, but we do not have a collapsing R/P in this company. If you take a look at the long-range plan of the company, we do not significantly drop ever our R/P. We just don't have the 12 because we don't have a lot of the gas to make it 12. So that's -- I think it's a misnomer a bit about the resources we have, and we probably need to do a better job of outlining those resources. But it's hard to do that in 2 years when oil prices collapse twice. That's not the time to go out and set expectations. I mean, when you lower CapEx, you have the wrong expectations. It doesn't work well that way. So it's hard to get into that vision that you're asking in these incredible file [ph] of total oil price times. If you want to maintain balance sheet to do transformational things for the company, you can easily outspend and grow production, and in that, not having a transformational change is very easy. I can just pick up the phone and do that. So I decided not to do it that way at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. I appreciate that. And maybe -- I mean, I guess it's -- I mean, it's safe to say that you -- that there's probably more resources of debt [ph] than the market you can afford. But on -- maybe on -- one last one on that, is the Gulf of Mexico
componenttext: That's great. I appreciate that. And maybe -- I mean, I guess it's -- I mean, it's safe to say that you -- that there's probably more resources of debt [ph] than the market you can afford. But on -- maybe on -- one last one on that, is the Gulf of Mexico -- I mean, there's a lot of -- you've had some recent successful wells there. And as you think over the next couple of years that the play that I think it's probably a little bit harder for us to model out, how do you think about production in the Gulf of Mexico over the next couple of years?  Are these -- as you tie in these wells, will these effectively hold production flat or drive moderate growth or moderate declines? Or how should we think about that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're not probably -- we are -- if we could get partners to participate in our wells that had have ability and income to do so and cash flow, we could grow production there. And that's hard to deal with at this particular time. We have some really nice lo
componenttext: We're not probably -- we are -- if we could get partners to participate in our wells that had have ability and income to do so and cash flow, we could grow production there. And that's hard to deal with at this particular time. We have some really nice low-risk opportunity there, like Medusa, replaced 2 wells on Montney and doing very, very well. So we have some additional locations there. It'll be a matter of an oil price recovery. However, tiebacks like Dalmatian South #2 and various other things, tiebacks in the Gulf of Mexico are right up there with returns you have in the Eagle Ford, if you take full cycle into account, meaning, the drilling of the well, the pipeline, et cetera, these things are very economic. We did a higher -- we need a higher oil price run to get into the facility building big exploration successful things, or where we can enter into a well or enter into [indiscernible] during this unique pullback as we have the balance sheet to be able to do so. Those who need oil to be a able to go higher, so if you have a higher vision of oil [ph], you can participate into the Gulf in many, many available projects today. So our ability to operate there, work there and long history of being there and have our business set up that way is very advantageous for us right now. So we have great Eagle Ford Shale business going, and we're executing incredibly well on it. You got to keep in mind, we've built the team 40 years. It's incredible. And then we had been able to look at those opportunities, that long-standing deepwater opportunity where we're not exploring today. But the factor is how do you get comfortable in changing staffing and do that -- to do that again another day when oil prices recover if we choose to do so. But there's a lot of opportunities in, both, and we're very advantaged to be able to look at both of them. And I don't know if many people have that.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov with Raymond James.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: You talked about your entry into Vietnam as an exploration opportunity. Are there any components of your exploration portfolio that you are considering not staying in or either divesting or simply exiting in 2016?
componenttext: You talked about your entry into Vietnam as an exploration opportunity. Are there any components of your exploration portfolio that you are considering not staying in or either divesting or simply exiting in 2016?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, that's all I'm saying.
componenttext: Yes. Yes, that's all I'm saying.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. Let me try it this way. Given the diverse scope of your kind of geographic footprint and the different host country or relationships, have you noticed more willingness on the part of governments and NOCs to improve the fiscal terms for
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. Let me try it this way. Given the diverse scope of your kind of geographic footprint and the different host country or relationships, have you noticed more willingness on the part of governments and NOCs to improve the fiscal terms for you guys, specifically, or if you want to talk about the industry, in general?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I found that in Southeast Asia, Petronas is such a leader there. That their fiscal terms are very similar, and we've been very successful. We greatly understand that, that's going fine. I think that will come. It takes a while for it. And I have a lot of
componenttext: I found that in Southeast Asia, Petronas is such a leader there. That their fiscal terms are very similar, and we've been very successful. We greatly understand that, that's going fine. I think that will come. It takes a while for it. And I have a lot of experience with NOCs. It's takes long time for them to have do their government to change the situations. I think it will greatly improve into next year probably. But -- so I believe that's coming. And we at Murphy are really trying to focus down on less [ph] places. And we're doing so, and that's why we will have the access that we will talk about after this. And so I think we're doing all the things that you're suggesting like in [ph] question that we probably should look at, and we are. And I believe that the NOC help will come. This is not exactly documented today, but clearly, that -- everyone in the industry has to make a change around everything they're doing. Oil prices used to be $100 the day before it dropped [ph].

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Specifically, in Vietnam, were you able to get better terms than you think you would have gotten, let's say, 6 or 12 months ago?
componenttext: Specifically, in Vietnam, were you able to get better terms than you think you would have gotten, let's say, 6 or 12 months ago?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I don't. So they -- like I say, we're sold [ph] after day [indiscernible] incredible relationship within. We've been in [indiscernible] building in this relationship. We find the terms to be very similar with shallow water in Malaysia. We're very fami
componenttext: No, I don't. So they -- like I say, we're sold [ph] after day [indiscernible] incredible relationship within. We've been in [indiscernible] building in this relationship. We find the terms to be very similar with shallow water in Malaysia. We're very familiar with how they work. I consider them fair. I don't feel incredibly changed of late. It takes a long time to do and feel like this. So it takes longer to do it than oil price recovery takes. So we're very happy about it. It is a block that had success on it. This is not some new entry rank while cutting block in the middle of nowhere. So it's totally -- after this one, the bigger oilfields, anywhere in offshore that's discovered in the '70s by Mobil. This is a $4 billion to $5 billion type resource. They make almost 300,000 barrels a day in an area in Vietnam. This is a key crown jewel of Vietnam, and we're very fortunate to be [indiscernible] and to be in.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your op costs have seen some wild quarter-to-quarter swings, but as you've highlighted here, there was a consistency of strong cost performance here in the third quarter. But when we look at the Eagle Ford production cost at $8, the rest of the U.S. at $8
componenttext: Your op costs have seen some wild quarter-to-quarter swings, but as you've highlighted here, there was a consistency of strong cost performance here in the third quarter. But when we look at the Eagle Ford production cost at $8, the rest of the U.S. at $8, Canada, ex Syncrude, sub-$6, is this the new ceiling and base case where costs come down from here? And if your production declines in places like the Eagle Ford or elsewhere, how would that have an impact on the unit of cost?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in the onshore, we're going very, very well in that regard. I mean, looking back to '14, I'm talking about just LOE, Brian. That's the taxes and all that. There's different aspects of this, as you know. Last year, around $11, this year in Ea
componenttext: Well, I think in the onshore, we're going very, very well in that regard. I mean, looking back to '14, I'm talking about just LOE, Brian. That's the taxes and all that. There's different aspects of this, as you know. Last year, around $11, this year in Eagle Ford Shale, looking at $10, $10.20 or so for the year, all year end because we had some higher costs pull over into the first quarter. And next year, we're probably looking at $8 and change. That's really good. I think in Canada, we made incredible OpEx improvements at both Montney and Seal. Seal, of course, is very challenged from a pricing perspective. And so onshore areas I think are good -- there are ups and downs in an offshore business. You have to model it, Brian, a little bit to get that value. And so we had a good year in offshore, especially in the Gulf, and then it will come. You have 17 [ph] inspections, big [ph] intelligent [indiscernible], and it makes the quarter a little bit jumpy in that regard. But overall, as a company, I think that we're in -- like I said earlier in the call, we're looking at $9.65, which is probably a record year of LOE and then looking at right around $9 for all of [indiscernible] of our business. So that's -- we've probably done a lot of that heavy lifting. That would account for, if there are levels of production, dropping of whatever due to capital, which will be the rage the next few months. That can handle that, in my opinion.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. And shifting to the Eagle Ford, I just had another follow-up on one of the earlier questions. As you have the push versus pull of budget versus efficiencies, is there a minimum level of completion cadence that you see is needed per quarter i
componenttext: That's great. And shifting to the Eagle Ford, I just had another follow-up on one of the earlier questions. As you have the push versus pull of budget versus efficiencies, is there a minimum level of completion cadence that you see is needed per quarter in the Eagle Ford to retain a minimum level of efficiencies? And should we expect that production to decline?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Obviously, if you go -- to answer your question, I see you need to keep 2 rigs running. And if you have to drill wells, then that'd probably lead to 1 frac spread, and you can always pick up [indiscernible] needed. We're not a company with a lot of drille
componenttext: Obviously, if you go -- to answer your question, I see you need to keep 2 rigs running. And if you have to drill wells, then that'd probably lead to 1 frac spread, and you can always pick up [indiscernible] needed. We're not a company with a lot of drilled, uncompleted wells. I think we only have 30. And I'm not a god to be able to have hundreds of those things. I don't believe that's appropriate thing to do with capital. And so with that said, I mean, obviously, we'd have production decline, Brian, if you go from 8 to 6 to 4 to 2. There would have to be a decline, which is, as your firm speaks about often, which should lead to -- which I guess, your firm doesn't believe, but it will lead to an oil price recovery, I would hope.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And our final question comes from Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The -- Roger, just had a couple of -- you've been through several permutations of the options and you've talked about transformational deeper resource inventory that you get credit for, et cetera, et cetera. I Just had 2 questions for you. One was to be c
componenttext: The -- Roger, just had a couple of -- you've been through several permutations of the options and you've talked about transformational deeper resource inventory that you get credit for, et cetera, et cetera. I Just had 2 questions for you. One was to be considered a merger of equals with someone else, is it transformational deal? And the second is, would there be the potential for you just to take Montney private?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, those are unusual, complex questions, Paul. That's a board -- complete Board of Directors of Murphy, in which I am one. We have not, in my view -- if you look at my desk today, piled with papers. I do not have a merger document there nor goi
componenttext: Well, I mean, those are unusual, complex questions, Paul. That's a board -- complete Board of Directors of Murphy, in which I am one. We have not, in my view -- if you look at my desk today, piled with papers. I do not have a merger document there nor going private document. So my focus is to -- it's real hard with these big price collapses, with very difficult budget last year, coming upon a tough one again this year, making stand about trying to get the cash flow CapEx parity and going from there. It's my focus today over mergers in that effect. That we'll always be available to any publicly traded company, of course, but it's not the focus I have today to be honest.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I understand. And so the clear frustration you've got is the share price is low and the multiple is so low. How do we change that?
componenttext: I understand. And so the clear frustration you've got is the share price is low and the multiple is so low. How do we change that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we changed that by continuing to -- when you're in a -- get back to cash flow CapEx parity and do that first and continuing to focus on cost, you can only go so far with that. But we're going to see working on those 2 matters, and we do have singles
componenttext: Well, we changed that by continuing to -- when you're in a -- get back to cash flow CapEx parity and do that first and continuing to focus on cost, you can only go so far with that. But we're going to see working on those 2 matters, and we do have singles and doubles here that we've been hitting. [indiscernible] doing that again. These are not -- it's pretty big gross type resource retouch in this quarter, Dalmatian $10 million, $10 million each for the shallow water well, significant well in Vietnam and so we got some things going our way there. And we're -- we feel like we're pretty well positioned. But in my view today, we have to maintain the balance sheet that we have. And at some point, I suppose, there'll be a time when we try to do M&A and have return for our shareholders. And when we feel we're unable to do that anymore, then we could look at other things. So I feel good about where we are in a pretty poor price environment, and we're working on that, is the answer, Paul.

Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Murphy Oil Corporation Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the call over to Kelly Whitley, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.Please refer to the inform
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. With me are Roger Jenkins, President and Chief Executive Officer; and John Eckart, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Please refer to the informational slides we have placed on the Investor Relations section of our website as you follow along with our webcast today. 
Today's call will follow our usual format. John will begin by providing a view of third quarter 2015 financial results, and then Roger will follow with an operational update, after which, questions will be taken.
Please keep in mind that some of the comments made during this call will be considered forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. As such, no assurances can be given that these events will occur or that the projections will be attained. A variety of factors exist that may cause actual results to differ. For a further discussion of risk factors, see Murphy's 2014 annual report on Form K (sic) [ Form 10-K ] on file with the SEC. Murphy takes no duty to publicly update or revise any public -- any forward-looking statements.
I will now turn the call over to John for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone. Murphy Oil's consolidated results in the third quarter of 2015 were a loss of $1.6 billion, which equates to $9.26 per diluted share. That's compared to a profit of $246 million or $1.37 per diluted share
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly, and good afternoon to everyone. Murphy Oil's consolidated results in the third quarter of 2015 were a loss of $1.6 billion, which equates to $9.26 per diluted share. That's compared to a profit of $246 million or $1.37 per diluted share a year ago. The third quarter 2015 results included noncash property impairments of $2.3 billion, which after taxes, amounted to $1.54 billion charge. These impairments were attributable to significant declines in future periods oil prices, which fell by as much as $15 per barrel at quarter end compared to 3 months earlier. The impairments were not related to reductions in the company's reported reserves.
Adjusted earnings, which adjust our GAAP numbers for various items that affect comparability of earnings between periods was a loss of $124 million in the third quarter of 2015, down from our profit of $205 million a year ago. This decline in adjusted earnings was primarily attributable to lower oil and natural gas sales prices in the current year. Our schedule of adjusted earnings is included as part of our earnings release, and the amounts in this schedule are reported on an after-tax basis.
The company's average realized price for its crude oil production fell more than $43 per barrel in the third quarter compared to the prior year. This amounted to a 48% drop between periods in oil prices. Natural gas prices also were weaker in the third quarter 2015 compared to the prior year with average North American gas price realizations dropping $1.21 per Mcf or a decline of 33%. Realized natural gas prices offshore Sarawak also fell by 27%.
Sales prices continued to be soft in October, and therefore, revenues continue to be under pressure as quarter 4 2015 prices remain significantly below prices a year ago.
The company continues to address its cost structure by aggressively reducing both operating and administrative cost. By year-end 2015, we anticipate a 23% reduction in staffing levels compared to a year earlier. At September 30, 2015, Murphy's long-term debt amounted to approximately $3.3 billion, 35.6% of total capital employed, while net debt amounted to just over 25% at the end of the third quarter.
At this time, I'll turn the call over to Roger for his comments.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Looking back at a solid operational third quarter, the following highlights stand out. Our company remains in a favorable financial position with a healthy balance sheet that's flexible to take advantage of opportunities that arise both i
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Looking back at a solid operational third quarter, the following highlights stand out. Our company remains in a favorable financial position with a healthy balance sheet that's flexible to take advantage of opportunities that arise both in onshore and offshore. With a major pullback in oil prices, we've been able to maintain our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio at less than 1.5. Subsequent to the third quarter, we hedged for 2016 and currently have 20,000 barrels per day in WTI contracts at an average price of $52 per barrel.
On the cost side, we continue to make significant improvements in reducing both operating and G&A expenses on a year-to-year basis. We continue to review our portfolio, as we still have many levers remaining to reposition the company going forward. We're currently reviewing the value of various midstream assets in North America. We're enthusiastic about a new area that we've recently formed into Offshore Vietnam, which expanded our Vietnam footprint with a new block in the highly prospective, oil-prone Cuu Long Basin. Our partnership group was successful in testing our first well, and we're working to increase acreage in this prolific area.
In the Gulf of Mexico, we drilled the Dalmatian South #2. We like what we see here as it has commercial hydrocarbons in 2 separate zones. Currently, the well is being completed with first production expected early next year.
In Malaysia, we achieved record average daily gross production for Sarawak Gas at 291 million per day. In addition, we drilled the Merapuh 5 and Marakas wells with positive results and in the process of evaluating both.
In our onshore business, the Eagle Ford Shale continues to outperform expectations, where we delivered 33 new wells online in the third quarter, plus Montney production continues to be above plan.
Our third quarter production is just over 207,500 barrel equivalents per day, and we're increasing our 2015 annual production guidance to a range of 205,000 to 209,000 barrel equivalents per day. Over the course of the year, we've increased the midpoint of our production guidance from 201,000 barrels equivalents per day to 207,000, almost a 3% increase.
In operations, we're pleased with the ongoing efforts we're making on cost reductions. Our lease operating expenses for the third quarter 2015, excluding Syncrude, is $8.09 per BOE, showing a reduction of 23% from the third quarter of 2014. More importantly, we're posting a 45% reduction from full year 2013 on LOE.
In Eagle Ford Shale, our third quarter operating expenses are just over $8 per BOE. This represents over a $2 reduction from the second quarter of this year.
On a cash margin basis, we are just over $19 per barrel equivalent in third quarter, and our $20.28 per BOE for 9 months ended. This compares very favorably to our peers and has been stable for Murphy for a long time due to our oil-weighted diverse portfolio.
In production, the positive production variance of 7,500 barrel equivalents a day for the quarter is attributable to Sarawak oil and natural gas fields performing better, above-plan performance on base decline, the Eagle Ford Shale new volume well -- new well volumes exceeding plan due to EUR increases and completion performance and higher natural gas production from Montney.
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter. Production guidance is estimated to be 199,000 barrel equivalents per day. Our third quarter actual production's higher than our fourth quarter guidance due to higher-risk SK natural gas nominations and planned downtime, natural well decline in the Gulf of Mexico and significant reduction in the number of completed wells in the Eagle Ford Shale.
More importantly, we are maintaining our 2015 CapEx of $2.3 billion, some 32% below last year's level, when taking into account the sell-down in Malaysia.
In Western Canada, our natural gas production in the Montney in the third quarter of 2015 was over 194 million per day. We've been successful in implementing fracture techniques from our Eagle Ford Shale work to the Montney and our new completion design with increased sand concentrations continued to confirm our 8 to 11 Bcf EURs. Also, we continue to have positive results on our refrac pilot that is underway in some older, tougher wells.
In the Eagle Ford Shale, we're especially pleased with our results for the third quarter, where production averaged over 63,000 barrels equivalent per day. We brought 33 new wells online in the third quarter, and we're planning to deliver 20 wells in the fourth, for a total of 136 wells this year.
Our program has been front-loaded as prior disclosed. Production for 2015 full year outlook is now expected to exceed 61,000 barrels equivalent per day, which is 8% above 2014 production.
We continue adding to our total remaining resource in the play by downspacing wells, drilling longer laterals and optimizing completions, to name a few. We now estimate that our total remaining resource has grown to over 800 million barrels. And this growth even takes into account a total review of our resources from a price perspective.
We successfully drilled our first Austin Chalk well in Karnes County, and we're hopeful -- hopefully, we'll be moving this play concept westward to our Catarina area. This would add a third horizon to our Upper and Lower Eagle Ford Shale locations. We drilled the first of 3 well appraisal pilot and are currently analyzing core logs to better understand the reservoir properties. Our Karnes Austin Chalk appraisal well has a very successful flow rate of 1,500 barrel oil equivalent per day. We look forward to continuing to test the Austin Chalk play in 2016.
In Malaysia, we achieved record average daily gas production in Sarawak of 291 million a day. We successfully drilled 2 shallow-water Sarawak oil prospects. The Merapuh 5 and Marakas wells had positive results, where we are evaluating development options. These wells are in the Block SK 314A area, adjacent to our successful Sarawak oil and gas developments.
The Murphy-operated Paus-Kelasa well failed to encounter commercial quantities of hydrocarbon and was expensed as a dry hole in the quarter.
Offshore Vietnam, we signed a farm-in agreement in the shallow water 15-1/05 block in the prolific, oil-prone Vietnam Cuu Long Basin. Two discoveries have been made in the block. Murphy participated in the drilling and testing of the LDV-4X well, which successfully tested 2 prospective zones. We're also working with PetroVietnam to advance our footprint in the Cuu Long. This new block entry was made possible by our long-term relationship with our partner and our significant position as a successful operator in both deepwater and shallow water in Malaysia.
In the Gulf of Mexico, production for the quarter was over 27,200 barrel equivalents per day at 71% liquids. We spud the Dalmatian South #2 well during the quarter. We're now completing the wells we found commercial hydrocarbons with over 98 feet of pay in 2 zones, and we expect first production early next year.
Field development work on the nonoperated Kodiak project continues, where the first of 2 wells have been drilled and completed to plan, and modification of topside facilities and subsea execution is underway. We're currently progressing the sidetrack of our Thunder Bird well to plan, and all of our current Gulf of Mexico projects can withstand lower-for-longer prices.
Looking at the drilling program for the fourth quarter 2015 in the Gulf, the nonoperated Solomon well, which is currently projected to reach total depth some time in the fourth quarter, has been included in our dry hole exposure for the fourth quarter. We plan to finish off the year with an oil exploration well, Senyum, located in Block H Malaysia, plus an nonoperated well to appraise our oil-linked gas discoveries in Brunei.
At this time, we have 2 deepwater rigs under contract at Murphy. These contracts expire in 2016, one in February and the other in November. With the continued low commodity prices we're experiencing, an expected reduction in our 2016 CapEx program and uncertainty about whether working interest partners will agree to participate in drilling programs, we're considering all options. Our current contractual commitments to the end of term for both rigs equals $277 million.
In financials, Murphy has been able to maintain our investment-grade BBB bond rating. We maintained our dividend policy through the year with current yields of 5%. We have $1 billion available under our current revolver. We have over $1.2 billion of cash abroad with marketable securities, and we achieved a net debt-to-EBITDA of less than 1.5.
Production for the fourth quarter is estimated to be 199,000 barrel equivalents a day. Again, we have increased our full year production guidance at the range of 205,000 to 209,000 equivalent per day. Capital expenditures remain unchanged from previous guidance and are currently forecasted to be $2.3 billion.
To close on my comments today, I would like to leave with a few points. Murphy continues to have financial flexibility and strength. We have greatly lowered operating and G&A expenses over the course of the year, and cost reductions remain a priority. Our entry into the Eagle Ford Shale has been an extremely successful addition to Murphy over the past few years. We've built an excellent high-performing team, now producing around 30% of our total volumes in just over 4 years. We, like most peers, continue to see efficiencies and cost reductions in drilling and completion activity across all of our operating areas. Our Gulf of Mexico projects generate sound economics at current prices. And over the quarter, we have participated in many positive well results, from the Gulf of Mexico to shallow water Malaysia and to Vietnam and a very high-rate well test in the Austin Chalk area of Eagle Ford Shale. We continue to execute on all cylinders in a tough commodity environment.
I'd like to now open up the phone for your questions, and thank you.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Leo Mariani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Leo Mariani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question for you. Still softly, I know earlier in the year you guys talked about moving away from some of the exploration activity. I guess you guys are announcing that you're firing into a block, and Vietnam here is sort of a new area. I guess is
componenttext: Just a question for you. Still softly, I know earlier in the year you guys talked about moving away from some of the exploration activity. I guess you guys are announcing that you're firing into a block, and Vietnam here is sort of a new area. I guess is this not really seen as sort of exploration? It sounds like there's some existing discoveries? Or do you guys just see this as lower-risk exploration?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we see it as a little bit of both, Leo. We have had a pause in our exploration. When I say that, it's primarily related to the big $100 million-plus big wells in the Gulf of Mexico. They're very expensive. They have very high day rates. But we're
componenttext: I think we see it as a little bit of both, Leo. We have had a pause in our exploration. When I say that, it's primarily related to the big $100 million-plus big wells in the Gulf of Mexico. They're very expensive. They have very high day rates. But we're not opposed to entering into lower-risk opportunities. It was clear to us that the block did have prior discoveries on them, and we entered into the block and participated in the delineation of both those discoveries. That delineation has gone very, very well. We're very excited about it. We're talking about -- when we had -- you have 2 types of wells in the world, the big Gulf of Mexico, West Africa, new entry-type wells, and you have lower-risk opportunities in a place like Vietnam where you can drill a well for $15 million and have a 50 million to 100 million barrel-type prospect. So on that basis, on an F&D perspective, that's a very positive thing. And this is about our strategy, it's about our company. We do work internationally. We are a big major player in Malaysia. We have a strong relationship and a very strong reputation in Southeast Asia, and we were able to -- our expertise in shallow water development there and across other acreage in Vietnam, is the reason we were able to get into this block. And it's very favorable. But I do not consider it to be entry in a wild off place somewhere. It's a very similar geology, what we're used to, very similar areas of operation, very similar cost, very similar well design and a place where we work nearby. And it's something we're focused on in that area. I consider it not a new, big, wild entry into a far-off place, Leo.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can you give us a little bit more color about this exploration well you're drilling in Malaysia towards the end of the year? And you also mentioned another well in Brunei, which I guess is not up. Can you give us a little more color around those?
componenttext: Okay. Can you give us a little bit more color about this exploration well you're drilling in Malaysia towards the end of the year? And you also mentioned another well in Brunei, which I guess is not up. Can you give us a little more color around those?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have commitment wells in our business. We do not have commitments usually in the Gulf as you anticipate. So we've had these, and these are, again, lower-cost wells. The well on Block H has moved up in our schedule from what we thought prior. It's
componenttext: Yes. We have commitment wells in our business. We do not have commitments usually in the Gulf as you anticipate. So we've had these, and these are, again, lower-cost wells. The well on Block H has moved up in our schedule from what we thought prior. It's a big world out there on rig contracts, and there's an opportunity for us to be subsidized and drill a very low-cost well in that part of the world. So if you're in the game for a long time, you're on both sides of the rig equation. I've been in -- at that business a long time. And we have an opportunity to drill the well cheaper due to that. And it's a very nice well to drill. It's probably a 60 million barrel, mean-type project near the Conoco-operated Kebabangan area of Block H. It would be different from the Block H wells we drilled in the past from an exploration basis and totally different from our shallow flat spot gas amplitudes in which we've had enormous success. So we're going to drill that well. It's probably be $18 million to $20 million net to Murphy. It's disclosed in our costs here. In Keratau where we've been a nonoperated smaller partner off Brunei, we've had several successes there in a row. This is a continuation towards that commerciality of flowing LNG into Brunei. We do have the right type of partners there, meaning people that are across the value chain of LNG. And I consider it also to be a lower-risk, lower-cost opportunity, which is what we're looking for, not the big-rank, expensive wells at this particular time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess you guys also mentioned that you had 2 recent successes at Sarawak on the oil side. I don't know if I can pronounce the 2 names of these wells. They both begin with an M. Can you give us a little bit more just color aroun
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess you guys also mentioned that you had 2 recent successes at Sarawak on the oil side. I don't know if I can pronounce the 2 names of these wells. They both begin with an M. Can you give us a little bit more just color around there? I guess it sounds like you're still appraising them? Would these be wells that potentially could come online in the near future, like 2016? What else can you tell us about those?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's called Merapuh and Marakas. If you live over there 5 or 6 years, you can say it really easily, Leo, like me. So they're both nearby structures, near 2 very nice fields. Merapuh is a major part of our gas project in SK Gas. And the Marakas well
componenttext: Well, it's called Merapuh and Marakas. If you live over there 5 or 6 years, you can say it really easily, Leo, like me. So they're both nearby structures, near 2 very nice fields. Merapuh is a major part of our gas project in SK Gas. And the Marakas well is a western feature to the west of our South Acis platform that does very, very well. Marakas is a deeper section, I mean, a higher pressure, deeper section that was successful, and we have to take those pressures and see how we're going to delineate that with the platform. It is not a 2016 event. This would be out in '17, '18 time and would depend on capital allocation next year as we go through -- as you -- what you can imagine a difficult budget cycle. The Merapuh well found extensions of some prior gas that we produce today in Merapuh in another structure, so we proved down-dip gas there and some up-dip oil opportunities. Both of them were a 10 million barrel type thing. We probably drilled both wells for less than $20-something million. It's going to fit in well with our nearby developments, and we're working on it and they're successful.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess you sort of went through the math in terms of saying that your fourth quarter production was going to be a little bit lower than 3Q. And I know you had some maintenance in the third quarter. Just to be clear, are you expe
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess you sort of went through the math in terms of saying that your fourth quarter production was going to be a little bit lower than 3Q. And I know you had some maintenance in the third quarter. Just to be clear, are you expecting some incremental maintenance in fourth quarter? Or is this more just sort of a risking in the fact that you're saying your nominations for your SK Gas are likely to be lower? Can you just maybe explain that a little better?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, SK Gas is a place in which we've had a very, very good year. It's a place where we planned on being 250 -- 250 million a day, and then we got up close to 300 million a day this quarter, probably. It's a record quarter for us. It is a situation with
componenttext: Well, SK Gas is a place in which we've had a very, very good year. It's a place where we planned on being 250 -- 250 million a day, and then we got up close to 300 million a day this quarter, probably. It's a record quarter for us. It is a situation with many, many fields filling into a very large 9-train, incredible LNG facility. So there's ups and downs of nomination. We're known as a swing producer there and a very reliable swing producer with very high uptime. Again, it facilitates our strong relationship with Petronas. But things come and go there as to impurities of other fields such as nitrogen, H2S, and the management of that makes it a little hard to predict. The guidance for that field, it's one of the issues around our company. We have very high cash flow per barrel metrics, but with that becomes just not as simple as an onshore situation, Leo. So we have to risk what our nominations will be there. We do have some downtime at that facility operated by Petronas that we've been notified of in November, December. Also the same situation with our gas, associated gas that comes off of Kikeh. And we have some downtime in the Gulf at Front Runner. I think we have to repair some things, and we have some decline of some of our wells in the Gulf because we're not really adding any wells there until early in '16. And this year -- and this quarter was a very good quarter for us, and all those come -- combine into that.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's an extension involved with the block, and we're just on the tail end. This well happened in September, Pete, and we're working with them on that. It's possible we could have an exploration well there. This is a pretty complex commerciality field d
componenttext: There's an extension involved with the block, and we're just on the tail end. This well happened in September, Pete, and we're working with them on that. It's possible we could have an exploration well there. This is a pretty complex commerciality field development plan process at PetroVietnam. We're used to that working with Petronas in Malaysia. We're talking about probably spend on that in the 17, 18 range and not next year. Very aggressive [ph] in there in my view, but we're very excited about this field here.

componenttext: Got you, okay. And then, Roger, I know you've been pretty actively looking at a lot of different M&A potential this year. Does the decision to go into Vietnam a bit more aggressively change your stance a little bit? Or are you still pretty actively looking for other assets elsewhere?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oh, no, it has nothing to do with that. This is a very -- I'm not at liberty today to talk about the cost. But it's a $2-type finding cost number and an F&D number on this project of about $14, $15, that's pretty good. It's not an incredible CapEx for us.
componenttext: Oh, no, it has nothing to do with that. This is a very -- I'm not at liberty today to talk about the cost. But it's a $2-type finding cost number and an F&D number on this project of about $14, $15, that's pretty good. It's not an incredible CapEx for us. We have a lot of cash, if you will, in Malaysia and through our subsidiary arrangements of moving money in that situation. This has nothing to do with our incredible focus on both offshore and onshore opportunities today. But we want to have value. We want to have return for our shareholders. And we're constantly working 3 or 4 of them with a full team of people, and we'll continue to do so.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay, Roger. And maybe one quick question for John, too. With regards to cost, you've had a very successful year of lowering your costs. And just wondering, how much more is there to go from here, both on the OpEx side and the CapEx side? Is it i
componenttext: Got you. Okay, Roger. And maybe one quick question for John, too. With regards to cost, you've had a very successful year of lowering your costs. And just wondering, how much more is there to go from here, both on the OpEx side and the CapEx side? Is it in the 5% to 10% range that's still likely? Or something a bit bigger or less than that, maybe?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think -- it's Roger. I'll -- I was preparing for that one, Pete. I didn't think it'd be you, I thought it'd be somebody else, but I'm glad you called in today. You have to look at -- first off, you can't look at Murphy quarterly on LOE. We made a big ch
componenttext: I think -- it's Roger. I'll -- I was preparing for that one, Pete. I didn't think it'd be you, I thought it'd be somebody else, but I'm glad you called in today. You have to look at -- first off, you can't look at Murphy quarterly on LOE. We made a big change from year to year because we have offshore operations, subsea maintenance. We don't have just one singular place where we work. And I think the real thing is we're looking at $9.65 this year without Syncrude and probably getting that into very close to $9. I don't believe we can keep the trajectory of taking it to $7 right now. But our big growth in Eagle Ford is going to be looking at a $8.50 and continue trending down for all of next year. That's a big move from the last 2, 3 years. Now with that said, I'm very proud of getting at these levels. We have an organization incredibly focused on lowering these costs, but we can't go on forever to $7, probably, Pete, here in our business, with an offshore business and an onshore business. But very happy about where it's headed, and on a year-to-year basis, I think it's quite positive.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Kind of following up on the M&A question before. What are you -- I know you don't want to get into the specifics of the property, but what are you seeing in terms of cost, bid-ask spreads? Has there been an increase in the properties that are available to look at in terms of data rooms, that sort of thing?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's just everything in the above there. You have some public situations. You have private equity situations and probably have a vision of a more of a turn of their multiple, and probably if it's able to offer the returns that we would like. The Midlan
componenttext: There's just everything in the above there. You have some public situations. You have private equity situations and probably have a vision of a more of a turn of their multiple, and probably if it's able to offer the returns that we would like. The Midland area is very, very frothy. Delaware getting a little better, I'd say. Offshore opportunities in the Gulf are the key ones for value adds. And we're expanding a little bit across North America to make sure we touched every place for value, and not necessarily focused -- I think we're not quite as singularly focused as we were before. And we -- like I said to Pete here, I mean, we have a certain criteria we're looking for, and we execute on that and keep  some going. And when we decide we can't make a return, we have a process of looking at the NAV or the rate of return of the investment, Roger, on strip and a price recovery deck that we have. We have 4 price decks here at Murphy. And when we feel we can't get to the strip or some level of return, I would likely cede [ph] those and we move to another one. And we will continue that process, and it may work, and it may not.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. And in terms of the return you would be looking for on one of these acquisitions, what's -- to the extent you can share with us, what would be the hurdle rate for something like a meaningful transaction?
componenttext: Sure. And in terms of the return you would be looking for on one of these acquisitions, what's -- to the extent you can share with us, what would be the hurdle rate for something like a meaningful transaction?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's -- I'm really not going to probably say that, Roger. It would -- you anticipate some level of return on a price recovery deck. It would have to be far in excess the cost of capital. And the reason you can't just say exactly what it is because it's mo
componenttext: It's -- I'm really not going to probably say that, Roger. It would -- you anticipate some level of return on a price recovery deck. It would have to be far in excess the cost of capital. And the reason you can't just say exactly what it is because it's more complicated, that depends on the reserves that would be, what are those price for those barrels that they have flowing production that you could have some level of CapEx without hurting your capitalization of the company and just a list of issues that would have different types of turns for different types of things.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just my last question. In terms of the cash that's overseas that you could repatriate, can you remind us what the potential tax leakage on that would be?
componenttext: Okay. And then just my last question. In terms of the cash that's overseas that you could repatriate, can you remind us what the potential tax leakage on that would be?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. The tax leakage on that is not that great. We have foreign tax credits that would offset almost all of it. If we bring money home from Canada, if we do that, there's obviously a 5% withholding tax associated with that, you can't get out of. It is a
componenttext: Okay. The tax leakage on that is not that great. We have foreign tax credits that would offset almost all of it. If we bring money home from Canada, if we do that, there's obviously a 5% withholding tax associated with that, you can't get out of. It is a creditable tax against U.S. taxes owed. But you'd likely be out that 5% at a minimum. And really, there's not that much leakage otherwise at the present time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Edward Westlake with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Edward Westlake with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I guess the key focus is the cash flow outspend. I mean, you've got a balance sheet, but obviously, prices are low. People will worry about it. So you've got a CapEx for this year of $2.3 billion. You've talked about potentially dropping rigs. May
componenttext: I mean, I guess the key focus is the cash flow outspend. I mean, you've got a balance sheet, but obviously, prices are low. People will worry about it. So you've got a CapEx for this year of $2.3 billion. You've talked about potentially dropping rigs. Maybe walk through what are the big deltas that you see from this year to next year. I appreciate you may not want to give a specific number, but what should we be thinking about?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ed. I'm probably not going to be the leader in that, and I have a bet around here today of the different ways people would ask that question. Obviously, we at Murphy are kind of -- we're going to be looking at a $45 WTI deck. And of course, you got t
componenttext: Yes, Ed. I'm probably not going to be the leader in that, and I have a bet around here today of the different ways people would ask that question. Obviously, we at Murphy are kind of -- we're going to be looking at a $45 WTI deck. And of course, you got to take that across all your netbacks and natural gas deck, appropriate deck, et cetera. And we're looking at cutting CapEx significantly. I don't think that would be a surprise. Then we have to look at that CapEx as to what will happen with production. We have been working through a lot of that issue recently, our long-range plan, determining where we wanted to allocate capital, then we get through our quarter issue here to close out you guys. It's our next focus, and we, as usual, approve our budget in December, but it may significantly reduce. And when we do, when we do, do that, we'll look at it and do it. We are -- we have several factors there. The dividend policy, we'd like to maintain. We have what will happen to production and what we can. I do feel that we are -- when I say flexible in these highlights, et cetera, we do have flexibility. We have liquidity and ability to handle a $40 world in '16 and $45 in '17, and make our commitments and our dividend. And that includes projections we might would have on production, and we probably aren't sharing here today. So I feel our liquidity situation and the levers we have there are adequate to handle this, and we -- we're taking that to a real high level of review at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so then coming to the rig comment you made in the opening remarks, you said one rolls off, I think, in spring and one in November, and considering all options. How much are you spending if you, say, drop both those rigs? What would that be impac
componenttext: Okay. And so then coming to the rig comment you made in the opening remarks, you said one rolls off, I think, in spring and one in November, and considering all options. How much are you spending if you, say, drop both those rigs? What would that be impact -- what would the impact be?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The way it works in an offshore deepwater environment today, it's just around $1 million a day to run a rig. And if you have -- the day rate of the rig is 550 to 590 and you stop paying the other half, then you have about the same level of CapEx. That is
componenttext: The way it works in an offshore deepwater environment today, it's just around $1 million a day to run a rig. And if you have -- the day rate of the rig is 550 to 590 and you stop paying the other half, then you have about the same level of CapEx. That is a very poor return and one I'm not happy with. But I do not want to take this as an opportunity to drill 100% rank wildcat wells and add more CapEx. Probably I'm not interested in situations where I carry partners and help them, hand more money to them. I'm not interested in that. The deepwater world is one that doesn't go well at 100%. And we take all that into account. We start looking at the options. And there are many, and we have a different -- we have different types of people who want to take non-working interest on some of our partners. And we have people that offer us some level of a wildcat exposure at an appropriate level of risk for us because the rate of return of paying it off is not good, as you would know. So we are looking at all of those things. But when I mention the liquidity in the $40 and $45 world and our dividend and where -- what happens with our net debt and our cap -- debt-to-cap, all these factors take into account the worst case scenario in that situation. And I'm not concerned about liquidity on that front.

componenttext: No, but I consider it significant. And we continue to work that. And we're not a company that throws around MLPs who does all this wild stuff all the time. So we're taking a measured approach at that. We're very pleased with how that's going, and it would be a termination of the terms and conditions and how that's going to go. And it, too, would be another liquidity situation that I have not factored in, in the discussion I just had with you a few minutes ago.
