headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Roger, I wanted to talk a little bit more about the performance, which was impressive. And apologies if I missed this, but do you have an estimate of the split between the cost gains and efficiencies you've -- you have achieved, which you might be classif
componenttext: Roger, I wanted to talk a little bit more about the performance, which was impressive. And apologies if I missed this, but do you have an estimate of the split between the cost gains and efficiencies you've -- you have achieved, which you might be classified as or which you might classify as more cyclical versus what is more structural in the result of what Murphy specifically is doing differently?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Any G&A are not a continuing event, Guy. It's significant, though, 23% of staffing by the end of the year is very significant. That would be both employees and contractors and all types of changes around the company. And no, we would not want to see that
componenttext: Any G&A are not a continuing event, Guy. It's significant, though, 23% of staffing by the end of the year is very significant. That would be both employees and contractors and all types of changes around the company. And no, we would not want to see that continue for another 23% next year. But we have not got the full estimate of that. And this type of actions are recent to Murphy, very recent, over the last few days. And we need to put that into our budget process, but we are looking at -- we do know that last year, we spent $365 million on G&A, and this year, we're in our internal work around $300 million. And then we will have -- and we do know that the staffing thing is in the mid-20s per million -- million dollars per year, and we'll have a full help to that to our side. And we are very much significantly down from a couple years back. On the operating expenses, I mean, we -- like I said earlier in the call, we made incredible improvements there. It's driven by a lot of great performance at Eagle Ford Shale, a lot of work in the offshore as well, a lot of sharing of helicopters, sharing -- when things go difficult, many people work together to lower the cost. And I'm very pleased on how my staff has performed in that. It's an incredible job for us. We're incredibly focused on it because we're trying to get to cash flow CapEx parity at $45 and every penny counts. And that's how we're working it. And when you work on things with the good people I have, you'll start seeing the results.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Roger. And then focusing in on the Eagle Ford, you're now running 3 rigs there, which is down from 4 last quarter, and the production was better than we had expected this quarter. In a $45 world, $45 to $50 world, can you just talk about t
componenttext: That's helpful, Roger. And then focusing in on the Eagle Ford, you're now running 3 rigs there, which is down from 4 last quarter, and the production was better than we had expected this quarter. In a $45 world, $45 to $50 world, can you just talk about the priorities which will govern the way you think about managing activity levels there over the next year? Is it about the returns of that specific play? Or is it more about the portfolio and cash flow CapEx parity and you having flexibility there? So just your high-level thoughts there would be appreciated. And then if you could help us out with what the implicit effect might be on the production profile, that would help as well.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a lot of flexibility around production. I don't have it. Like I said earlier, I don't have that finalized, and I'm probably not going to be the leader in that pack with the year we've had here. We have some really good wells to drill in Eagl
componenttext: Well, we have a lot of flexibility around production. I don't have it. Like I said earlier, I don't have that finalized, and I'm probably not going to be the leader in that pack with the year we've had here. We have some really good wells to drill in Eagle Ford Shale. At $45 base pricing, we have a lot of wells that are 30% rate of return, and that -- and I think that's pretty decent. And if oil prices are $50, we have many wells to drill at 45% rate of return. Incremental going forward, I don't like to do work that way, but this does help when you're allocating capital. So we're going to be allocating capital on the best areas that deliver the best return on that incrementally. We also do not need a lot of rigs to protect our acreage. That's different than it was for -- in times past, and we'll have to do some big capital allocations, study them. We're in the middle of doing so, about protecting acreage versus protecting efficiency. The reason we have such efficient operations, we've been running same numbers of rigs for a while now with the same teams. So if you go 4 to 0 to 2 to 3 to 4 to 0, it's hard to do that. So it's almost a situation of allocating capital to remain some level of efficiency, and we're really trying to get to preparing for lower prices here from a cash flow CapEx parity over other things because we cannot continue to outspend our CapEx and wake up one day and be with the credit of other people. We have very good credit situation today, debt-to-cap, and we don't want to wake up with it like the norm and not have done something or looked or attempted to do something to add value to our shares -- to our shareholders. So we're in the middle of all that, and obviously, the Eagle Ford Shale will be a key part of capital allocation. I think today, $2.3 billion CapEx for '14, our CapEx in Eagle Ford shale is $855 million, and we're going to be at that percent or more as we cut CapEx, because it's a very valuable asset for us. It's going extremely well on everything you can imagine that's known in the shale business. We at Murphy have that ability as well, and real proud about it. And it, too, has incredible flexibility because if things were to get worse, you can reduce it and add to it. You won't have the efficiency when you jump and add, but it's a very nice thing to have, for a company of our size and I think very, very material.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe one quick follow-up on -- I mean, the Eagle Ford performance was impressive on the quarter with actually growing sequentially with fewer completions. Can you talk a little bit about what -- I mean, you referenced better productivity of the wells, hi
componenttext: Maybe one quick follow-up on -- I mean, the Eagle Ford performance was impressive on the quarter with actually growing sequentially with fewer completions. Can you talk a little bit about what -- I mean, you referenced better productivity of the wells, high EURs, some enhanced completions. Can you talk a little about some of the things that you're seeing in the wells? How sustainable do you think that is? And what sort of confidence that gives you, I guess, in terms of maintaining better production levels in 2016?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've recently done a big study in Eagle Ford Shale. We started over with all of our puds, all of our proven locations and our reserves. We're doing very, very well in reserve, find them very pleased with that trajectory where I think this year will
componenttext: Well, we've recently done a big study in Eagle Ford Shale. We started over with all of our puds, all of our proven locations and our reserves. We're doing very, very well in reserve, find them very pleased with that trajectory where I think this year will end. We have a -- we had some gas acreage in Eagle Ford Shale that we've taken off the table, of course. And we've made some big changes in EUR. I think that as I walk through a couple of the fields, I think it's significant. Karnes, where -- is a very prolific area there, as you know, Ryan. We used to think that an 80-acre spacing well would have about a 660,000 EUR. And now we've pulled that 660,000 to 600,000, but we're at 40-acre spacing, so it's an enormous change in resource, both in Upper and Lower Eagle Ford Shale. Tilden would be the same way. We're doing a lot of work with longer laterals there, bigger sand. Today, from back to '12, 2012, we're talking about the same situation where EURs continue to improve there, probably not so much as Karnes. But the big improvement for us is Catarina, which is our most western area, which is a very organized -- we went ground floor there, so we don't have the perfect, giant sections of land. But Catarina is very, very organized from that perspective. And we have improved the EURs there. We have 3 big ranches there. One area from 210,000 a day -- 210,000 equivalent EUR to over 400,000 with less spacing; and then another area from 210,000 to over 550,000, again with less spacing; and another area from 210,000 to 600,000. This is enormous change in an area that we drill wells for only 4-point-something million dollars. This is a big deal. And that we may not have it all modeled in yet, but our trajectory and where we're headed there, it's a -- it's very, very positive, in my view.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That was very helpful. And then maybe if I could talk -- one more, I guess, from a little bit of a strategy point of view. I mean, I think one of the concerns that people have had with Murphy has been maybe depth of resource and what would drive -- in an
componenttext: That was very helpful. And then maybe if I could talk -- one more, I guess, from a little bit of a strategy point of view. I mean, I think one of the concerns that people have had with Murphy has been maybe depth of resource and what would drive -- in an oil price recovery, what are going to be the assets or the resources that's going to drive when -- growth again, when you return to playing offense as opposed to defense? And I guess as you think about that and you think about the resources you have in your portfolio, what would -- what would you see -- the Eagle Ford is clearly going to be one, but what would you see as kind of the resource that'll drive -- that'll be the kind of the drivers of the next leg of growth for the company? And I guess in that context -- and how does M&A fit in terms of either complementing or competing with that resource for kind of the next cycle of Murphy?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, clearly, when we do M&A, we look at how it affects our long-range plans and how it increases our income, our cash flow per share and every type of metric, including R/P. I think when you speak in a nice way about the R/P, you know that's ver
componenttext: Well, I mean, clearly, when we do M&A, we look at how it affects our long-range plans and how it increases our income, our cash flow per share and every type of metric, including R/P. I think when you speak in a nice way about the R/P, you know that's very frustrating to me. The R/P has been 8 for a long time. It's going to be 8 for a long time. But from an oil-weighted perspective, we're probably fifth place out of 16 peers. If you take the R/P that's really truly oil. We're very limited. We'd probably be the lowest NGL R/P player and very, very low on natural gas. That's quite frustrating to me because it's a view that we don't have any locations. If this year, in the Eagle Ford Shale, we're going to drill and operate about 136 wells down there, or bring online 136 wells, and we probably have 3,000 locations to go. So this idea that Eagle Ford Shale is not material for a company that has 756 million barrels of proven and now a resource size remaining of 800 million barrels is mind-boggling to me, and it's very well-known how this project models. But outside of that, I mean, places like Vietnam, we may -- we have focus there, it's very tight around where we want to work. We want to bring that focus tighter. Projects like Kodiak, Kodiak, Vietnam and things in the Gulf are available to us that are not large M&A, change your entire capital structure type deals, but they're very helpful on adding barrels. And we do have the Floating LNG coming online. Malaysia is going very well. I didn't mention it, but we took a core there in a well there this quarter to continue to confirm our outstanding resource available, and we're partnered with the leading LNG player in the world, Petronas, which is a big deal. So small things like Kodiak, big ones like Vietnam, M&A on top of all that, but we do not have a collapsing R/P in this company. If you take a look at the long-range plan of the company, we do not significantly drop ever our R/P. We just don't have the 12 because we don't have a lot of gas to make it 12. So that's -- I think it's a misnomer a bit about the resources we have, and we probably need to do a better job of outlining those resources. But it's hard to do that in 2 years when oil prices collapse twice. That's not the time to go out and set expectations. And then when you lower CapEx, you have the wrong expectations. It doesn't work well that way. So it's hard to get into that vision that you're asking in these incredible volatile oil price times. If you want to maintain balance sheet to do transformational things in the company, you can easily outspend and grow production, and end up not having a transformational change. It's very easy. I can just pick up the phone and do that. So decided not to do it that way at this time.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. I appreciate that. And maybe -- I mean, I guess it's -- I mean, it's safe to say that you -- that there's probably more resource depth than the market gives you credit for. But on -- maybe on -- one last one on that, in the Gulf of Mexico --
componenttext: That's great. I appreciate that. And maybe -- I mean, I guess it's -- I mean, it's safe to say that you -- that there's probably more resource depth than the market gives you credit for. But on -- maybe on -- one last one on that, in the Gulf of Mexico -- I mean, there's a lot of -- you've had some recent successful wells there. And as you think over the next couple of years, as it's the play that I think is probably a little bit harder for us to model out, how do you think about production in the Gulf of Mexico over the next couple of years?  Are these -- as you tie in these wells, will these effectively hold production flat, will it drive moderate growth or moderate declines? Or how should we think about that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're not probably -- we are -- if we could get partners to participate in our wells that have ability and income to do so and cash flow, we could grow production there. And that's hard to deal with at this particular time. We have some really nice low-ri
componenttext: We're not probably -- we are -- if we could get partners to participate in our wells that have ability and income to do so and cash flow, we could grow production there. And that's hard to deal with at this particular time. We have some really nice low-risk opportunities there, like Medusa, where we placed 2 wells online and doing very, very well. So we have some additional locations there. It'll be a matter of an oil price recovery. However, tiebacks like Dalmatian South #2 and various other things, tiebacks in the Gulf of Mexico are right up there with returns you have in Eagle Ford, if you take full cycle into account, meaning the drilling of the well, the pipeline, et cetera, these things are very economic. We'd need a higher -- we need a higher oil price, Ryan, to get into facility building big exploration successful things, or where we can enter into a well or enter into a [indiscernible] ground floor during this unique pullback because we have the balance sheet to be able to do so. Those need oil to be a little higher, so if you have a higher vision of oil, you can participate into the Gulf in many, many available projects today. So our ability to operate there, work there and long history of being there and have our business set up that way is very advantageous for us right now. So we have great Eagle Ford Shale business going, and we're executing incredibly well on it. You got to keep in mind, we've built this team in 4 years. It's incredible. And then we have been able to look at those opportunities.  We have a longstanding deepwater team, where we're not exploring today. But the factor is how do we get comfortable in changing staffing and doing that -- to do that again another day when oil prices recover if we choose to do so. But there's a lot of opportunities in both, and we're very advantaged to be able to look at both of them. And I don't know if many people have that.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov with Raymond James.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: You talked about your entry into Vietnam as an exploration opportunity. Are there any components of your exploration portfolio that you are considering not staying in or either divesting or simply exiting in 2016?
componenttext: You talked about your entry into Vietnam as an exploration opportunity. Are there any components of your exploration portfolio that you are considering not staying in or either divesting or simply exiting in 2016?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, that's all I'm saying.
componenttext: Yes. Yes, that's all I'm saying.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. Let me try it this way. Given the diverse scope of your kind of geographic footprint and the different host country relationships, have you noticed more willingness on the part of governments and NOCs to improve the fiscal terms for you
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. Let me try it this way. Given the diverse scope of your kind of geographic footprint and the different host country relationships, have you noticed more willingness on the part of governments and NOCs to improve the fiscal terms for you guys, specifically, or if you want to talk about the industry in general?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I've found that in Southeast Asia, Petronas is such a leader there that their fiscal terms are very similar, and we've been very successful. We greatly understand it and that's going fine. I think that will come. It takes a while for a -- And I have a lot
componenttext: I've found that in Southeast Asia, Petronas is such a leader there that their fiscal terms are very similar, and we've been very successful. We greatly understand it and that's going fine. I think that will come. It takes a while for a -- And I have a lot of experience with NOCs -- it takes a long time for them to have, through their government, to change these situations. I think it will greatly improve into next year probably. But -- so I believe that's coming. And we at Murphy are really trying to focus down on less places. And we're doing so, and that's why we will have exits that we will talk about when they're exited. And so I think we're doing all the things that you're suggesting by your question, that we probably should look at, and we are. And I believe that the NOC help will come, but it's not exactly documented today, but clearly, that -- everyone in the industry has to make a change around everything they're doing when oil prices used to be $100, today they're $45.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Specifically in Vietnam, were you able to get better terms than you think you would have gotten, let's say, 6 or 12 months ago?
componenttext: Specifically in Vietnam, were you able to get better terms than you think you would have gotten, let's say, 6 or 12 months ago?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I doubt so. They -- like I say, we're sought after there by them, we have an incredible relationship with them. We've been there building this relationship. We find the terms to be very similar with shallow water in Malaysia. We're very familiar with
componenttext: No, I doubt so. They -- like I say, we're sought after there by them, we have an incredible relationship with them. We've been there building this relationship. We find the terms to be very similar with shallow water in Malaysia. We're very familiar with how they work. I consider them fair. I don't think they're incredibly changed of late. It takes a long time to do a deal like this. So it takes longer to do it than oil price recovery takes. So we're very happy about it. It is a block that had success on it. This is not some new entry rank wildcatting block in the middle of nowhere. This is totally -- this is one of the bigger oilfields anywhere in offshore, it's discovered in the '70s by Mobil. This is a $4 billion to $5 billion type resource. They make almost 300,000 barrels a day in an area in Vietnam. This is a key crown jewel of Vietnam, and we're very fortunate to be invited to be in.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your op costs have seen some wild quarter-to-quarter swings, but as was highlighted here, there was a consistency of strong cost performance here in the third quarter. When we look at the Eagle Ford production cost at $8, the rest of the U.S. at $8, Canad
componenttext: Your op costs have seen some wild quarter-to-quarter swings, but as was highlighted here, there was a consistency of strong cost performance here in the third quarter. When we look at the Eagle Ford production cost at $8, the rest of the U.S. at $8, Canada, ex Syncrude, sub-$6, is this the new ceiling and base case where costs come down from here? And if your production declines in places like the Eagle Ford or elsewhere, how would that have an impact on the unit op cost?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in the onshore, we're doing very, very well in that regard. I mean, looking back to '14, I'm talking about just LOE, Brian. Not with taxes and all that. You know there's different aspects of this, as you know. Last year, around $11, this yea
componenttext: Well, I think in the onshore, we're doing very, very well in that regard. I mean, looking back to '14, I'm talking about just LOE, Brian. Not with taxes and all that. You know there's different aspects of this, as you know. Last year, around $11, this year in Eagle Ford Shale, looking at $10, $10.20 or so for the year, all year-end, because we had some higher costs pull over into the first quarter. And next year, we're probably looking at $8 and change. That's really good. I think in Canada, we made incredible OpEx improvements at both Montney and Seal. Seal, of course, is very challenged from a pricing perspective. And so onshore areas I think are good -- the ups and downs are in an offshore business. You have to model it, Brian, a little bit to get that value. And so we had a good year in offshore, especially in the Gulf, and then it will come. You have subsea inspections, peak, intelligent peaking of pipelines and it makes the quarter a little bit jumpy in that regard. But overall, as a company, I think that we're, like I said earlier in the call, we're looking at $9.65, which is probably a record here of LOE and then looking at right around $9 for all of the year, all of our business. So that's -- we've probably done a lot of that heavy lifting. That would account for, if there are levels of production, dropping of whatever due to capital, which will be the rage of the next few months. That can handle that, in my opinion.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. And shifting to the Eagle Ford, just another follow-up on one of the earlier questions. As you have this push versus pull of budget versus efficiencies, is there a minimum level of completions cadence that you see is needed per quarter in th
componenttext: That's great. And shifting to the Eagle Ford, just another follow-up on one of the earlier questions. As you have this push versus pull of budget versus efficiencies, is there a minimum level of completions cadence that you see is needed per quarter in the Eagle Ford to retain a minimum level of efficiencies? And should we expect that production to decline?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Obviously, if you go -- to answer your question, I say you need to keep 2 rigs running. And if you have to drill wells, then that'd probably lead to 1 frac spread, and you can always pick up other ones as needed. We're not a company with a lot of drilled,
componenttext: Obviously, if you go -- to answer your question, I say you need to keep 2 rigs running. And if you have to drill wells, then that'd probably lead to 1 frac spread, and you can always pick up other ones as needed. We're not a company with a lot of drilled, uncompleted wells. I think we only have 30. And I'm not a guy that builds up hundreds of those things. I don't believe that's an appropriate thing to do with capital. And so with that said, I mean, obviously, we'd have production decline, Brian, if you go from 8 to 6 to 4 to 2. There would have to be a decline, which is, as your firm speaks about often, which should lead to -- which I guess, your firm doesn't believe, but it will lead to an oil price recovery, I would hope.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And our final question comes from Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The -- Roger, just had a couple of -- you've been through several permutations of the options and you've talked about transformational deeper resource inventory that you get credit for, et cetera, et cetera. I just had 2 questions for you. One was have yo
componenttext: The -- Roger, just had a couple of -- you've been through several permutations of the options and you've talked about transformational deeper resource inventory that you get credit for, et cetera, et cetera. I just had 2 questions for you. One was have you considered a merger of equals with someone else  as a transformational deal? And the second is, would there be the potential for you just to take Murphy private?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, those are unusual, complex questions, Paul. That's a board -- complete Board of Directors of Murphy, in which I am one. We have not, in my view -- if you look at my desk today, piled with papers. I do not have a merger document there nor a g
componenttext: Well, I mean, those are unusual, complex questions, Paul. That's a board -- complete Board of Directors of Murphy, in which I am one. We have not, in my view -- if you look at my desk today, piled with papers. I do not have a merger document there nor a going private document. So my focus is to -- it's real hard with these big price collapses, we had a very difficult budget last year, coming upon a tough one again this year, making a stand about trying to get to cash flow CapEx parity and going from there. Is my focus today over mergers in that effect? That will always be available to any publicly traded company, of course, but it's not the focus I have today, to be honest.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I understand. And so the clear frustration you've got is the share price is low and the multiple is so low. How do we change that?
componenttext: I understand. And so the clear frustration you've got is the share price is low and the multiple is so low. How do we change that?

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we change that by continuing to -- when you're in a -- get back to cash flow CapEx parity and do that first and continuing to focus on cost, you can only go so far with that. But we're going to keep working on those 2 matters, and we do have singles
componenttext: Well, we change that by continuing to -- when you're in a -- get back to cash flow CapEx parity and do that first and continuing to focus on cost, you can only go so far with that. But we're going to keep working on those 2 matters, and we do have singles and doubles here that we've been hitting. [indiscernible] and we're back doing that again. These are not -- it's pretty big gross type resource we're touching this quarter, Dalmatian $10 million, $10 million each for the shallow water well, significant well in Vietnam and so we got some things going our way there. And we're -- we feel like we're pretty well positioned. But in my view today, we have to maintain the balance sheet that we have. And at some point, I suppose, there'll be a time when we try to do M&A and have return for our shareholders. And when we feel we're unable to do that anymore, then we could look at other things. So I feel good about where we are in a pretty poor price environment, and we're working on that, is the answer, Paul.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that concludes the question-and-answer session. I'd like to turn the conference back over to Roger Jenkins for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: And that concludes the question-and-answer session. I'd like to turn the conference back over to Roger Jenkins for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We appreciate everyone calling in today with some active questions today. I loved participating with you in it and I think we did have a good quarter. And we'll be back with you again after the holidays, and we'll go from there, and I appreciate it.
componenttext: We appreciate everyone calling in today with some active questions today. I loved participating with you in it and I think we did have a good quarter. And we'll be back with you again after the holidays, and we'll go from there, and I appreciate it.

headline: Murphy Oil Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And that does conclude today's presentation. Thank you for your participation.
componenttext: Thank you. And that does conclude today's presentation. Thank you for your participation.
